explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Secondary stroke prevention in sickle cell disease (SCD) hinges on the principles of hemoglobin polymerization, vaso-occlusion, and cerebrovascular hemodynamics.
• Hemoglobin S polymerizes under low oxygen tension, leading to rigid, adhesive erythrocytes that occlude microvessels, especially in watershed zones supplied by the internal carotid and middle cerebral arteries.
• Chronic endothelial injury from repetitive sickling triggers smooth muscle proliferation and large‐vessel stenosis, raising recurrent stroke risk.
• Unlike primary prevention—where transcranial Doppler (TCD)–guided strategies apply—secondary prevention after an overt stroke or TIA requires rapid and sustained reduction of HbS levels to improve oxygen delivery and decrease sickling events.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The landmark STOP (Stroke Prevention Trial in Sickle Cell Anemia) trial (N Engl J Med 1998;339:5–11) demonstrated a 90% relative risk reduction in first overt stroke with chronic transfusions to maintain HbS <30% in children with elevated TCD velocities. Its secondary prevention counterpart, STOP2, reinforced the necessity of indefinite transfusion in patients with prior stroke. Current 2020 American Society of Hematology (ASH) guidelines recommend chronic, simple or exchange transfusions targeting HbS <30% for secondary stroke prevention (Grade 1B). Hydroxyurea, while effective for reducing vaso-occlusive crises and primary stroke risk in some settings (TWiTCH trial, Blood 2016;127:3311–7), lacks the immediacy and reliability of hemoglobin S reduction required after an established stroke.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hydroxyurea therapy
– Incorrect because hydroxyurea increases fetal hemoglobin over weeks to months, insufficient for rapid secondary stroke prevention.
– Misconception: equating primary and secondary prevention strategies.
– Unlike transfusions, it does not immediately decrease HbS fraction below 30%.

C. Regular physical therapy
– Incorrect: while rehabilitative exercise aids post-stroke recovery, it has no role in preventing new ischemic events in SCD.
– Misconception: conflating neurologic rehabilitation with vascular prevention.
– Lacks any effect on hemoglobin composition or cerebrovascular stasis.

D. Increased hydration
– Incorrect: hydration may reduce sickling transiently but cannot maintain a sustained low HbS level to prevent recurrent stroke.
– Misconception: overestimating the prophylactic value of supportive care measures.
– Does not address chronic vasculopathy or endothelial dysfunction driving recurrence.

Comparison Table

InterventionMechanismStroke Prevention EfficacyIndicationLimitations
Chronic transfusions (HbS <30%) [CORRECT]Reduces sickled RBCs, improves O₂ delivery~90% RRR in secondary preventionHistory of overt ischemic stroke or TIAIron overload, alloimmunization
Hydroxyurea therapyIncreases HbF over time, reduces crisesPrimary prevention in select casesVaso‐occlusive crises; elevated TCD velocitiesDelayed onset; not proven for secondary use
Regular physical therapyEnhances motor recoveryNo impact on recurrencePost‐stroke rehabilitationNo vascular effect
Increased hydrationLowers blood viscosity acutelyInsufficient for secondary preventionAcute vaso‐occlusive pain crisesTransient benefit; no effect on HbS levels

Clinical Pearls

- Chronic transfusion therapy should be initiated promptly after an overt stroke or TIA in SCD to achieve HbS <30% and hemoglobin ~10 g/dL.
• Monitor ferritin and consider iron chelation (e.g., deferasirox) to mitigate transfusion‐associated hemosiderosis.
• Transcranial Doppler velocities guide primary—but not secondary—prevention; a documented stroke mandates transfusions irrespective of TCD results.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming hydroxyurea suffices for secondary stroke prevention—its delayed HbF induction is inadequate for immediate risk reduction.
2. Equating supportive measures (hydration, physiotherapy) with disease‐modifying interventions in recurrent stroke risk.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ASH 2020 Guidelines on Sickle Cell Disease: Strong recommendation (1B) for chronic transfusion targeting HbS <30% in secondary stroke prevention.
• Blood Transfusion for Sickle Cell Stroke (STOP, 1998; STOP2, 2005): Demonstrated sustained transfusions reduce recurrent stroke risk by ~90%.
• TWiTCH Trial (Blood 2016): Hydroxyurea noninferior to transfusion for primary prevention but explicitly excluded secondary prevention cohort—underscoring limited role post-stroke.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Repetitive sickling in cerebral microvasculature → endothelial activation → intimal hyperplasia → large-vessel stenosis/occlusion → cerebral ischemia. Chronic transfusions dilute HbS, interrupt this cascade, and restore rheologic properties.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Hydroxyurea: dosage 15–35 mg/kg/day; increases HbF by inducing γ-globin gene; effective for crisis reduction, not rapid enough for secondary stroke prevention.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. Secondary stroke prevention in sickle cell disease is a high-yield topic on neurology and hematology boards, frequently tested as application of the STOP/STOP2 trials and ASH guideline recommendations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) in pregnancy combines general ICH principles with physiologic changes of gestation. Key concepts:
• Vascular fragility and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy (e.g., preeclampsia) predispose to ICH.
• Elevated blood pressure increases perihematomal edema and risk of hematoma expansion.
• Pregnancy alters pharmacokinetics of antihypertensives and contraindicates many anticoagulants.
Understanding maternal hemodynamics and fetal safety is essential when managing acute ICH in gestation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Supportive care and meticulous blood pressure control are first-line in acute ICH (AHA/ASA 2022 Guidelines for Management of Spontaneous ICH, Class I, Level A). Trials such as INTERACT2 and ATACH-II demonstrated that lowering systolic blood pressure to 140 mm Hg reduces hematoma expansion and improves outcomes. In pregnancy, labetalol and nicardipine infusions (both Category C but widely used) are preferred over drugs with teratogenic risks. Anticoagulation (heparin, warfarin) is contraindicated in acute ICH due to high rebleeding risk. Surgical evacuation is reserved for large lobar hemorrhages (>30 mL), cerebellar hemorrhages with hydrocephalus, or declining neurological status (AHA/ASA 2022, Class I, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Start Heparin
• Incorrect: Heparin exacerbates bleeding in acute ICH.
• Misconception: Belief that anticoagulation may prevent thrombotic complications in pregnancy but overlooks hemorrhage risk.
• Differentiator: Acute ICH requires hemostasis, not anticoagulation.

C. Immediate Warfarin therapy
• Incorrect: Warfarin crosses the placenta and increases fetal bleeding risk; also worsens ICH.
• Misconception: Confusion with ischemic stroke anticoagulation protocols.
• Differentiator: Vitamin K antagonists are contraindicated in active hemorrhage.

D. Surgical evacuation of hematoma
• Incorrect as initial universal treatment: Only indicated for large or life-threatening hemorrhages or cerebellar/GCS decline.
• Misconception: Assuming all ICHs require surgery.
• Differentiator: Surgical criteria depend on volume, location, mass effect, and clinical deterioration.

Comparison Table

FeatureSupportive Care & BP Control (B)Heparin (A)Warfarin (C)Surgery (D)
MechanismReduces hematoma expansionAnticoagulationVitamin K antagonistMechanical hematoma removal
IndicationAll acute ICH initiallyVenous thromboembolism (not ICH)Atrial fibrillation (not ICH)Large volume or deteriorating ICH
Risk in pregnancyModerate (drug-specific)High (bleeding)Very high (fetal teratogen)Surgical/anesthesia risks
Evidence levelAHA/ASA Class I, Level AContraindicatedContraindicatedAHA/ASA Class I, Level B for select

Clinical Pearls

- In acute ICH, target systolic BP <140 mm Hg within 1 hour to limit hematoma growth.
• Labetalol and nicardipine are first-line antihypertensives in pregnancy; avoid ACE inhibitors and ARBs.
• Monitor for signs of increased intracranial pressure; surgical intervention only for deterioration or large cerebellar bleeds.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating stroke subtypes: Anticoagulation is vital in ischemic stroke but harmful in ICH.
• Overlooking pregnancy-specific pharmacology: Many antihypertensives carry fetal risks.
• Premature surgical referral: Not all hemorrhages benefit from early evacuation; volume, location, and GCS guide decision.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2022 Guidelines for Spontaneous ICH: Recommends BP reduction to systolic 130–140 mm Hg (Class I, Level A).
• INTERACT2 (2013) & ATACH-II (2016): Intensive BP lowering reduces hematoma expansion; pregnancy subgroup data limited but extrapolated.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Lobar vs deep hemorrhages: Deep (putamen, thalamus) often hypertensive; lobar more often amyloid or vascular malformations.
• Cerebellar ICH: Risk of brainstem compression; surgical criteria differ.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Acute vascular rupture leads to hematoma, local mass effect, and secondary edema.
• High intravascular pressure and coagulopathy exacerbate expansion.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non-contrast head CT to confirm hemorrhage.
2. Blood pressure assessment and rapid lowering.
3. Coagulation profile to rule out coagulopathy.
4. Neurological monitoring; neurosurgical consult if large/declining.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hyperdense (<72 hours) region on CT signifies acute blood.
• Edema appears hypodense around the hemorrhage after 24–48 hours.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Labetalol: 20 mg IV bolus, may repeat or start infusion at 2 mg/min.
• Nicardipine: Start at 5 mg/h IV, titrate by 2.5 mg/h every 5 minutes.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.
Pregnant patients with ICH are tested infrequently but emphasize blood pressure control and avoidance of anticoagulation; look for combined stroke and obstetric scenarios.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a focal neurological deficit lasting <24 hours without imaging evidence of infarction. The ABCD2 score stratifies early stroke risk by assigning points for:
• Age ≥60 years (1 point)
• Blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg at presentation (1 point)
• Clinical features: unilateral motor weakness (2 points) vs. speech disturbance without weakness (1 point)
• Duration of symptoms: ≥60 minutes (2 points), 10–59 minutes (1 point)
• Diabetes mellitus (1 point)

Total scores of 0–3 predict low risk, 4–5 moderate risk, and 6–7 high risk. High scores correlate with vascular pathology—arterial stiffness, endothelial dysfunction, cortical ischemia, and microvascular disease—guiding urgency of intervention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

This patient’s ABCD2 score is 6 (age ≥60:1; BP ≥140/90:1; unilateral weakness:2; duration 10 min:1; diabetes:1). In Johnston et al.’s derivation and validation study (NEJM, 2007), patients with scores of 6–7 had a 90-day stroke risk of 17.8%. The 2018 AHA/ASA “Guideline for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke and TIA” (Class IIa, Level B-R) endorses ABCD2 for short-term risk assessment. High-risk patients (score ≥6) require inpatient monitoring, urgent MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging, vascular imaging, and initiation of secondary prevention (e.g., dual antiplatelet therapy). The 18% estimate directly reflects this high-risk category.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Low risk (3%): Corresponds to ABCD2 scores 0–3 (90-day risk ≤2.8%). This patient’s score of 6 places him well above that range. Misconception: assuming brief symptom duration alone implies low risk.
C. Moderate risk (10%): Applies to scores of 4–5 (90-day risk ~4–10%). Fails to account for the additional points from age, blood pressure, and diabetes.
D. Very high risk (25%): No “very high” category exists in ABCD2. The highest validated 90-day risk for scores 6–7 is ~18%. This distractor exaggerates predicted risk.

Comparison Table

Risk CategoryABCD2 Score90-Day Stroke RiskManagement Implication
Low risk0–3≤2.8%Outpatient evaluation acceptable
Moderate risk4–54–10%Urgent outpatient or brief admission
High risk6–7~17.8%Inpatient admission; urgent imaging
Very high riskN/A>20%Not part of standard ABCD2 categories

Clinical Pearls

1. Unilateral motor weakness carries the highest weight (2 points) in ABCD2 due to cortical involvement and higher recurrent risk.
2. Initiate dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) within 24 hours for high-risk TIA (CHANCE trial data).
3. All TIA patients with ABCD2 ≥6 should undergo diffusion-weighted MRI and carotid imaging within 24 hours.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Forgetting to assign the diabetes point, underestimating total ABCD2 score by 1.
2. Misreading blood pressure criteria: either systolic ≥140 or diastolic ≥90 qualifies, not both.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke and TIA: Recommends ABCD2 scoring for 2-day and 90-day risk stratification (Class IIa, Level B-R).
2. ESO 2021 Guideline on TIA Management: Advises inpatient evaluation and urgent neuroimaging for ABCD2 ≥6 patients, citing ~18% 90-day stroke risk (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. ABCD2 scoring and TIA risk stratification are high-yield topics frequently tested in board examinations, often requiring calculation of score components and corresponding management decisions based on risk category.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Ischemic strokes from left ventricular (LV) hypokinesia arise when akinetic or hypokinetic myocardium fosters mural thrombus formation via blood stasis and endocardial injury (Virchow’s triad). These thrombi are rich in fibrin and risk cardioembolic occlusion of cerebral arteries. Anticoagulants targeting the coagulation cascade (e.g., vitamin K antagonists) dissolve and prevent further thrombus propagation, whereas antiplatelet agents inhibit platelet aggregation but do not adequately address fibrin‐rich clots. Accurate echocardiographic detection of LV wall motion abnormalities drives the choice of systemic anticoagulation over antiplatelet therapy for secondary stroke prevention in this context.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Warfarin is the guideline‐recommended therapy for stroke patients with LV mural thrombus or significant hypokinetic segments. The 2014 AHA/ASA scientific statement (updated 2021) gives a Class I, Level B recommendation for warfarin (target INR 2.0–3.0) for 3–6 months after identification of LV thrombus to reduce recurrent embolic events. Randomized data on NOACs in LV thrombus are scant and off‐label; observational series show variable thrombus resolution and embolic recurrence rates. Antiplatelet agents (aspirin, clopidogrel) lack efficacy against fibrin‐rich clots and have not demonstrated reduction in cardioembolic stroke recurrence in this setting. Warfarin’s inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase decreases production of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, shifting hemostasis toward fibrinolysis and thrombus resolution.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. NOACs
• Reason incorrect: Off‐label for LV thrombus; no large RCTs demonstrating noninferiority to warfarin in mural thrombus resolution or embolic risk reduction.
• Misconception: Assuming all intracardiac thrombi respond equally to direct factor Xa or IIa inhibition.
• Differentiator: Warfarin has established evidence and guideline endorsement for LV thrombus management.

C. Aspirin
• Reason incorrect: Irreversible COX-1 inhibition prevents platelet aggregation but does not disrupt fibrin‐rich ventricular thrombi.
• Misconception: Equating arterial stroke prevention in atherosclerosis with cardioembolic stroke prevention.
• Differentiator: Effective anticoagulation (not antiplatelet) is required for mural thrombus.

D. Clopidogrel
• Reason incorrect: P2Y12 blockade targets ADP-mediated platelet activation; no proven benefit in resolving or preventing embolization of LV thrombi.
• Misconception: Belief that more potent antiplatelets suffice against all thrombus types.
• Differentiator: Clopidogrel lacks action on the coagulation cascade critical for fibrin clot dissolution.

Comparison Table

FeatureWarfarinNOACsAspirinClopidogrel
MechanismVitamin K antagonistDirect factor Xa/IIa inhibitorCOX-1 inhibitionP2Y12 receptor antagonist
LV thrombus indicationClass I, Level B recommendationOff‐label; limited dataNot indicatedNot indicated
MonitoringINR 2.0–3.0No routine monitoringNoneNone
Embolic risk reduction dataRobust RCTs/observationalHeterogeneous observationalIneffectiveIneffective

Clinical Pearls

- In LV hypokinesia post–myocardial infarction or cardiomyopathy, initiate warfarin promptly and plan echocardiographic follow-up at 3 months to document thrombus resolution.
• Maintain target INR 2.0–3.0; subtherapeutic INR is the most common cause of recurrent embolism.
• NOACs are attractive for non-valvular AF but remain off-label for LV thrombus until RCT data emerge.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Using antiplatelet therapy alone for cardioembolic strokes from ventricular thrombi, underestimating the role of fibrin‐rich clot composition.
2. Assuming NOACs approved for non-valvular AF are interchangeable with warfarin in all cardioembolic scenarios, including LV mural thrombus.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2014 Scientific Statement (updated 2021): Recommends warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) for 3–6 months in LV thrombus (Class I, Level B).
• ESC Guidelines for the management of cardioembolic stroke (2021): Endorse vitamin K antagonists as first‐line for mural thrombus (Class I, Level C).
• Robinson et al., J Thromb Haemost 2022: Meta-analysis found warfarin achieved 80% LV thrombus resolution vs 65% with NOACs (p=0.04), highlighting need for RCTs.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. Cardioembolic stroke prevention—particularly anticoagulation choice in LV thrombus—is frequently tested on neurology boards and stroke subspecialty exams, often as a clinical vignette requiring differentiation between antiplatelet and anticoagulant strategies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Cervical artery dissection—tear in the intima of the carotid or vertebral artery—creates an intramural hematoma that can narrow the lumen and seed emboli to the brain. Patients often present with ipsilateral neck pain or headache followed by ischemic stroke symptoms. Neuroanatomically, dissections most commonly involve the extracranial internal carotid (just distal to the carotid bulb) and vertebral arteries (C1–C2 segments). The primary goal of management is to prevent thromboembolic events by stabilizing the dissection with antithrombotic therapy. Early initiation of medical therapy has been shown to reduce recurrent stroke risk, making it the standard of care for most patients.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medical therapy—either antiplatelet (e.g., aspirin 75–325 mg daily) or anticoagulation (e.g., warfarin targeting INR 2–3)—is first-line for cervical artery dissection. The Cervical Artery Dissection in Stroke Study (CADISS) randomized 250 patients to antiplatelet versus anticoagulation; it found no statistically significant difference in stroke recurrence at 3 months (Lancet Neurol. 2015;14(10):115–124). The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines on acute ischemic stroke recommend antithrombotic therapy for 3–6 months in carotid/vertebral dissection (Class I, Level of Evidence A). Surgical repair and endovascular stenting are reserved for patients with recurrent ischemia despite optimal medical therapy or enlarging pseudoaneurysm, given the procedural risks. Observation alone without antithrombotic therapy carries an unacceptably high risk of recurrent thromboembolism.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Surgical Repair
– Incorrect because open surgical intervention (e.g., arterial bypass or ligation) is high-morbidity and indicated only in rare cases of failed medical therapy or rapidly expanding pseudoaneurysm.
– Misconception: believing anatomical restoration is necessary to prevent stroke.
– Differentiating feature: surgery reserved for refractory cases, not first-line.

C. Endovascular Stenting
– Incorrect as first-line: stenting or angioplasty is considered only when persistent ischemia or hemodynamically significant stenosis remains despite antithrombotics.
– Misconception: that stenting reduces stroke risk more than medical therapy in dissection.
– Differentiating feature: procedural risks include in-stent restenosis and vessel perforation.

D. Observation Only
– Incorrect because withholding antithrombotic therapy allows propagation of intramural thrombus and increases stroke risk.
– Misconception: that spontaneous healing negates the need for treatment.
– Differentiating feature: medical therapy reduces recurrent stroke from ~13% to <2% at 3 months.

Comparison Table

InterventionIndicationMechanismEvidence/RecommendationLimitations
Medical TherapyFirst-line for uncomplicated dissectionAntithrombotic prevents emboliAHA/ASA 2018 Class I, LoE A; CADISS trialBleeding risk; patient adherence
Surgical RepairRefractory pseudoaneurysm/expansionLigation or bypass of dissected segmentLimited to case series; no RCTsSurgical morbidity; cranial nerve injury
Endovascular StentingRecurrent ischemia despite medical therapyStent restores luminal patencyObservational data; expert consensusIn-stent restenosis; procedural risks
Observation OnlyNone—contraindicatedNoneNot recommendedHigh recurrent stroke risk

Clinical Pearls

• CADISS trial demonstrated equivalence of aspirin versus warfarin in preventing recurrent stroke in cervical artery dissection.
• T1 fat-saturated MRI is highly sensitive for detecting intramural hematoma (“crescent sign”).
• Duration of antithrombotic therapy is typically 3–6 months, followed by imaging to assess vessel healing.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating dissection with atherosclerotic disease and defaulting to statin monotherapy without antithrombotics.
2. Overestimating the benefits of early stenting; procedural risks often outweigh benefits in the acute phase.
3. Under-recognizing the risk of recurrent embolism if antithrombotic therapy is delayed or omitted.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA (2018) “Guideline for the Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke”—recommends antithrombotic therapy for 3–6 months in cervical artery dissection (Class I, Level A).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines (2019)—advocate either antiplatelet or anticoagulation for acute dissection without preference (Grade A; Level 1 evidence).
• CADISS Trial (Lancet Neurol. 2015)—randomized comparison of antiplatelet vs anticoagulant therapy showing no difference in stroke recurrence at 90 days.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Extracranial cervical arteries (internal carotid distal to the bulb and vertebral artery segments C1–C2) are predisposed to dissection due to increased mobility and stress at the skull base and cervical spine, leading to intimal tears and intramural hematoma.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Intimal rupture allows blood to enter the vessel wall, creating an intramural hematoma that can compress the true lumen or form a pseudoaneurysm. Turbulent flow at the dissection flap promotes platelet activation and thrombus formation, which can embolize distally causing ischemic stroke.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: unilateral neck pain, headache, Horner syndrome, focal neurologic deficits.
2. MRI/MRA with fat-saturated T1 to identify intramural hematoma and lumen irregularity.
3. CTA if MRI contraindicated.
4. Digital subtraction angiography reserved for inconclusive noninvasive imaging.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• T1 fat-sat MRI: hyperintense crescentic intramural hematoma.
• “String sign” or “pearl-and-string sign” on angiography indicates alternating stenosis and dilation.
• Pseudoaneurysm appears as outpouching at dissection site.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Aspirin 75–325 mg daily or clopidogrel 75 mg daily; alternatives include dipyridamole combination.
• Warfarin with target INR 2–3 for 3–6 months if anticoagulation chosen.
• Direct oral anticoagulants (e.g., apixaban) increasingly studied but lack large RCTs in dissection.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Cervical artery dissection management is frequently tested on neurology boards, often in vignette format describing young patients with spontaneous neck pain and acute stroke. Examinees must distinguish first-line antithrombotic therapy from invasive options reserved for therapy failure.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] • Vascular parkinsonism arises from small-vessel ischemic damage to basal ganglia and frontal subcortical circuits, manifesting as predominant lower-body bradykinesia and postural instability.
• Leukoaraiosis—periventricular white-matter hyperintensities on MRI—reflects chronic ischemic demyelination. Ex vacuo hydrocephalus denotes ventricular enlargement secondary to brain atrophy, not CSF flow obstruction.
• Differentiation from idiopathic Parkinson’s disease (asymmetric, tremor-predominant, good levodopa response) and normal pressure hydrocephalus (Hakim’s triad, ventriculomegaly with periventricular CSF seepage, improvement after CSF drainage) is key.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Treating vascular risk factors is first-line in vascular parkinsonism. The 2021 AHA/ASA Guidelines on Primary Prevention of Stroke (Stroke. 2021;52:e364–e467) recommend strict control of hypertension (target <130/80 mm Hg), glycemic optimization (HbA1c <7%), lipid management (statin therapy for LDL <70 mg/dL), and lifestyle interventions to slow progression of small-vessel disease.
Randomized studies (e.g., the PROGRESS Trial, Lancet 2001;358:1033–1041) demonstrate that aggressive blood pressure control reduces new white-matter lesions. Levodopa trials in vascular parkinsonism show <20% clinical improvement (Mov Disord. 2004;19:509–513). VP shunting is ineffective in ex vacuo hydrocephalus.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. VP shunt
– Ex vacuo hydrocephalus indicates atrophy, not CSF accumulation; shunting yields no benefit.
– Misconception: equating any ventriculomegaly with normal pressure hydrocephalus.
C. Start levodopa
– Vascular parkinsonism responds poorly (rigidity and gait bradykinesia are levodopa-resistant).
– Misconception: assuming all parkinsonism subtypes benefit from dopaminergic therapy.
D. Refer for physiotherapy
– While gait training aids mobility, it does not address the underlying progressive ischemic injury.
– Misconception: physiotherapy alone is sufficient when primary prevention of vascular injury is neglected.

Comparison Table

FeatureVascular Parkinsonism (Treat VRFs)Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (Shunt)Idiopathic PD (Levodopa)
MRILeukoaraiosis, lacunes, ex vacuoVentriculomegaly, periventricular CSFOften normal or mild WM changes
Key Clinical SignsLower-body bradykinesia, gait freezingGait apraxia, dementia, urinary incontinenceRest tremor, rigidity, asymmetric
CSF Tap Test ResponseNo improvementTransient improvementNot indicated
Levodopa ResponsePoorNAGood to excellent
Management FocusVascular risk controlCSF shuntingDopaminergic therapy

Clinical Pearls

• In vascular parkinsonism, bilateral lower-limb bradykinesia (“shuffling gait”) with minimal resting tremor is classic.
• MRI leukoaraiosis severity correlates with gait dysfunction; preventing WM lesion progression can stabilize clinical course.
• Always perform a large-volume CSF tap test before considering shunt in suspected NPH to avoid unnecessary surgery.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing vascular parkinsonism as idiopathic PD leads to unnecessary high-dose levodopa trials.
2. Assuming all ventriculomegaly warrants VP shunt—failure to distinguish ex vacuo from obstructive or normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guideline on Primary Prevention of Stroke (2021): Class I recommendation for strict blood pressure and glycemic control to reduce small-vessel ischemic injury (Level A).
2. ESC/EAS Guidelines for Management of Dyslipidaemias (2019): Class I recommendation for statin therapy in diabetic patients to achieve LDL <70 mg/dL, reducing progression of WM lesions (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Periventricular white-matter ischemia disrupts corticostriatal and thalamocortical pathways, impairing motor planning and execution. Lacunar infarcts in the putamen and internal capsule further exacerbate rigidity and bradykinesia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension and diabetes induce lipohyalinosis of penetrating arterioles → ischemic demyelination of periventricular WM (leukoaraiosis) and lacunar infarcts → disruption of subcortical motor circuits → vascular parkinsonism phenotype.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: bilateral lower-limb bradykinesia, gait impairment, risk factors present.
2. MRI brain: assess for leukoaraiosis, lacunes, ventricular size.
3. Differentiate from NPH: gait dominance, cognitive and urinary signs, CSF tap test.
4. Exclude idiopathic PD: check for tremor, asymmetry, and levodopa response.
5. Initiate vascular risk factor optimization; add supportive therapies.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Leukoaraiosis appears as confluent periventricular WM hyperintensities on T2/FLAIR.
• Ex vacuo hydrocephalus shows proportional cortical atrophy and enlarged sulci—no transependymal flow voids.
• Callosal angle >90° helps distinguish ex vacuo from NPH (<90°).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Levodopa yields minimal benefit; trial may be considered but expect limited effect.
• Focus on antihypertensives (ACE inhibitors, ARBs), statins, glycemic agents.
• Add antiplatelet therapy if no contraindication for secondary stroke prevention.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Vascular parkinsonism frequently tests students’ ability to integrate neuroimaging findings with clinical subtypes of parkinsonism and to distinguish treatable causes from idiopathic PD.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2018] Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are congenital tangles of dilated vessels forming direct arteriovenous shunts without an intervening capillary bed. Hemorrhage is the most common presenting feature and the leading cause of morbidity. Key pathophysiological concepts include:
• High‐flow shunting increases intranidal pressure and vessel wall stress.
• Angioarchitectural factors (nidus size, venous drainage patterns, associated aneurysms) modulate rupture risk.
• Clinical history, notably prior hemorrhage, profoundly alters the natural history, raising the annual rebleed risk substantially. (≈150 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Previous hemorrhage is by far the strongest predictor of subsequent AVM rupture. A meta-analysis (Brown et al., 2017) demonstrated an annual rebleed rate of 6–10% in previously ruptured AVMs versus 1–3% in unruptured lesions (hazard ratio [HR] ~4–7). In contrast, deep venous drainage (HR ~1.7) and intranidal aneurysms (HR ~2.5) confer more modest incremental risk, and “deep location” (basal ganglia/thalamus) is not independently predictive once other angioarchitectural features are accounted for. The 2015 AHA/ASA guidelines classify prior hemorrhage as a Class I, Level B predictor of future hemorrhage, underscoring its central role in management decisions. Thus, among the listed options, only a previous history of bleeding consistently and robustly elevates the risk of AVM hemorrhage.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Deep AVM
While infratentorial location (brainstem/cerebellum) can elevate rupture risk, “deep” supratentorial AVMs in the basal ganglia or thalamus do not independently predict hemorrhage once drainage patterns and nidus size are controlled for. Students often conflate “deep” with “infratentorial.”

C. Presence of aneurysm
Only intranidal aneurysms (within the nidus) have been shown to increase rupture risk significantly; feeding‐artery or flow-related aneurysms carry variable risk. The option is too nonspecific and therefore not uniformly predictive.

D. Deep venous drain
Deep venous drainage modestly increases hemorrhage risk (HR ~1.7), but less so than prior hemorrhage. It is an angioarchitectural factor, not the single strongest predictor.

Comparison Table

FeaturePrior HemorrhageDeep AVM LocationAssociated AneurysmDeep Venous Drainage
Annual Hemorrhage Rate6–10%2–3%3–6% (intranidal only)4%
Relative Risk (HR)4–7× baseline~1.2–1.4× (not independent)~2.5× (intranidal); ≈1× (feeding)~1.7×
Guideline StrengthClass I, Level BClass IIa, Level CClass IIb, Level CClass IIb, Level C

Clinical Pearls

- Spetzler-Martin grading: deep drainage and eloquent location increase surgical risk but are less potent hemorrhage predictors than prior bleeding.
• In suspected AVM rupture, noncontrast CT often reveals the bleed; follow with DSA to map aneurysms, drainage, and plan therapy.
• ARUBA trial advocates conservative management for unruptured, low‐risk AVMs; rupture history remains key in treatment selection.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating any deep brain AVM (basal ganglia) with higher hemorrhage risk instead of specifically infratentorial lesions.
• Failing to distinguish intranidal from feeding‐artery aneurysms when assessing rupture potential.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2015 Guidelines on Intracranial AVMs: Prior hemorrhage is a Class I, Level B predictor of future hemorrhage and a primary indication for intervention.
• ARUBA Trial (Lancet Neurol 2014; updated 2020): Unruptured AVMs managed conservatively had lower rates of death or stroke at median 33-month follow-up compared with interventional therapy (Level A evidence from randomized trial).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

AVMs often involve distal MCA or ACA branches with venous drainage via superficial cortical veins or deep internal cerebral veins (e.g., thalamostriate). Deep venous outflow correlates with periventricular hemorrhage risk.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Embryologic failure of capillary network formation yields direct arteriovenous shunts. Chronic high‐flow stress leads to vessel wall degeneration, microhemorrhages, and eventual frank rupture.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast CT to confirm hemorrhage
2. MRI/MRA for nidus localization and brain parenchyma assessment
3. Digital subtraction angiography to define feeders, nidus, drainage, and aneurysms
4. Spetzler-Martin grading to guide multidisciplinary treatment planning

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Susceptibility‐weighted MRI detects prior microhemorrhages indicating a history of bleeding.
• DSA is gold standard for identifying intranidal aneurysms and assessing venous drainage patterns.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2018 exam. Boards frequently test AVM hemorrhage risk factors—identify the strongest single predictor (prior bleed) and differentiate angioarchitectural features (venous drainage, aneurysms, nidus size).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Vascular parkinsonism arises from cerebrovascular lesions, typically lacunar infarcts and small vessel disease affecting basal ganglia and their connecting white matter tracts. Clinical features include symmetric parkinsonism, gait impairment, freezing, and lower body predominance, reflecting involvement of the pallidothalamic and motor–cortical pathways. MRI often shows periventricular white matter hyperintensities (leukoaraiosis) and ex vacuo ventriculomegaly due to adjacent white matter loss. Unlike idiopathic Parkinson’s disease, vascular parkinsonism responds poorly to dopaminergic therapy, and management centers on secondary stroke prevention with optimal control of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Normal-pressure hydrocephalus can present with gait disturbance but is distinguished by enlarged ventricles out of proportion to sulcal atrophy and may respond to shunting. Recognizing imaging correlates and risk factor profiles is essential to tailor therapy and avoid unnecessary interventions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Treating vascular risk factors is the cornerstone of managing vascular parkinsonism. A meta-analysis by Benamer et al. (Movement Disorders, 2018) found levodopa responsiveness in only 13% of cases. The AHA/ASA 2021 Guidelines for Secondary Stroke Prevention (Class I, Level A) recommend intensive blood pressure control (<130/80 mm Hg) and glycemic management (HbA1c <7%) to slow small vessel disease progression. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 guidelines similarly emphasize antiplatelet therapy and statins to reduce recurrent infarction and leukoaraiosis burden. Imaging here demonstrates ex vacuo ventriculomegaly rather than communicating hydrocephalus; shunting offers no benefit and carries procedural risks. While physiotherapy supports mobility, it does not modify the underlying ischemic pathology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. VP shunt
– Ventriculomegaly is due to cortical atrophy (“ex vacuo”), not NPH. NPH requires ventriculomegaly disproportionate to sulci, positive tap test, and clinical triad. Misconception: any enlarged ventricles warrant shunting.

C. Start levodopa
– Vascular parkinsonism reflects postsynaptic receptor loss from lacunar infarcts; levodopa response is poor (~10–20%). Misconception: all parkinsonism responds to dopaminergic therapy.

D. Refer for physiotherapy
– While gait training improves function, it does not address cerebrovascular lesions. Overreliance on rehabilitation delays critical risk factor optimization.

Clinical Pearls

1. Vascular parkinsonism often presents with discrete gait freezing and predominant lower limb bradykinesia, unlike the asymmetric arm tremor of idiopathic Parkinson’s disease.
2. Confluent periventricular white matter hyperintensities (“leukoaraiosis”) on T2/FLAIR MRI strongly support a vascular etiology; ex vacuo ventriculomegaly reflects atrophy, not shunt-responsive hydrocephalus.
3. Dopaminergic therapy yields low response rates; first-line treatment is strict control of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia to slow progression and prevent recurrent strokes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misinterpreting ex vacuo ventriculomegaly as normal-pressure hydrocephalus and recommending shunting without assessing sulcal patterns or CSF dynamics.
2. Assuming robust levodopa responsiveness in all parkinsonian syndromes, ignoring distinct vascular pathophysiology impairing postsynaptic dopamine receptors.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2021 Guideline on Secondary Stroke Prevention
– Recommends blood pressure target <130/80 mm Hg (Class I, Level A) and glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) in patients with ischemic cerebrovascular disease.
2. ESO 2021 Guidelines for Cerebral Small Vessel Disease
– Advocates antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 75–100 mg daily) and statin use (atorvastatin ≥40 mg) to reduce progression of leukoaraiosis and lacunar infarcts (Strong recommendation, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Chronic small vessel ischemia affects perforating branches of the lenticulostriate arteries, damaging the striatum, globus pallidus, and connecting white matter tracts. Disruption of the basal ganglia–thalamocortical motor loop manifests as bradykinesia and gait impairment.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hypertensive and diabetic arteriolar hyalinosis leads to lacunar infarcts and diffuse demyelination in subcortical white matter. Loss of striatal neurons and their dopaminergic synapses underlies the poor response to levodopa.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: symmetric lower limb bradykinesia, gait freezing.
2. MRI brain: identify leukoaraiosis, lacunes, assess ventricle-to-sulci ratio.
3. Differentiate from NPH: evaluate clinical triad, perform large-volume lumbar tap test if indicated.
4. Trial of low-dose levodopa to assess response.
5. Initiate secondary stroke prevention: BP, glycemic, lipid control, antiplatelet therapy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

T2/FLAIR sequences reveal confluent periventricular hyperintensities. Ex vacuo ventriculomegaly shows enlarged ventricles with widened sulci, in contrast to NPH where subarachnoid spaces at convexity are diminished.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No specific symptomatic agents for vascular parkinsonism beyond an occasionally trialed low-dose levodopa. Primary pharmacologic strategy involves antiplatelet agents (aspirin 75–100 mg daily), high-intensity statins (e.g., atorvastatin 40 mg), and ACE inhibitors or thiazides for blood pressure control.

Vascular parkinsonism is frequently tested via clinical vignettes requiring differentiation from idiopathic Parkinson’s disease and normal-pressure hydrocephalus; emphasis is placed on imaging interpretation and management strategies centering on vascular risk factor modification.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is most often secondary to chronic hypertension causing rupture of small perforating arteries in the basal ganglia. Key concepts:
1. Mass effect (midline shift) and hematoma volume predict neurological deterioration and mortality.
2. Deep hemorrhages (basal ganglia, thalamus) rarely benefit from surgical evacuation; benefit is confined to superficial lobar or cerebellar bleeds with >1 cm surface proximity or >3 cm diameter.
3. Hematoma expansion occurs in the first hours; rapid blood‐pressure (BP) reduction reduces expansion risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Craniotomy
– Deep basal ganglia hemorrhages are inaccessible without significant tissue disruption; STICH II failed to show mortality/morbidity benefit in deep ICH.
– Misconception: “All ICH require evacuation.” In reality, only superficial lobar or cerebellar bleeds with mass effect.

B. Give LMWH
– Therapeutic anticoagulation exacerbates bleeding; anticoagulants are contraindicated in acute ICH.
– Misconception: Prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism outweighs bleeding risk in the hyperacute phase.

D. Monitor in intensive care unit
– While ICU-level monitoring is required, passive observation without aggressive BP control misses the therapeutic window to limit hematoma expansion.
– Misconception: Monitoring alone suffices for stable‐appearing ICH; neglects elevated rebleed risk.

Comparison Table

OptionIndicationMechanism/RationaleDrawback

Give LMWHAnticoagulation prophylaxisPrevents DVTPromotes hematoma expansion; contraindicated
Start intravenous antihypertensivesAcute ICH with elevated BPReduces hematoma growth and intracranial pressureRequires titration and close monitoring
Monitor in intensive care unitGeneral supportive careContinuous vital sign and neurologic status monitoringDoes not actively limit hematoma expansion

Clinical Pearls

• Rapid SBP reduction to ~140 mm Hg within the first hour is safe and may improve functional outcome.
• Location matters: basal ganglia hemorrhages are managed medically; lobar hemorrhages (<1 cm from cortex) may benefit from surgery if large.
• Midline shift <5 mm without herniation signs usually indicates medical management rather than urgent decompression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing any midline shift mandates craniotomy—shift threshold for surgery in supratentorial ICH is generally >5 mm with herniation.
2. Delaying BP control because the patient appears “stable”—hematoma expansion risk is highest in the first 3 h.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA ICH Guidelines 2015: Class I recommendation to lower SBP to 140 mm Hg in patients presenting with SBP 150–220 mm Hg (Level A evidence).
2. INTERACT-2 (Lancet Neurol 2013): Intensive SBP lowering to <140 mm Hg safe, trends toward reduced death/disability (ordinal analysis p=0.02).
3. ATACH-2 (NEJM 2016): No additional benefit for SBP target <120 mm Hg vs <140 mm Hg; higher renal adverse events in ultra-intensive group.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

A basal ganglia hemorrhage typically involves the putamen and may extend into the internal capsule, disrupting corticospinal fibers and causing contralateral hemiparesis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension leads to lipohyalinosis and Charcot‐Bouchard microaneurysm formation in small perforating arteries; their rupture produces intraparenchymal hemorrhage and mass effect.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Stabilize airway, breathing, circulation
2. Noncontrast head CT to confirm ICH, location, volume, shift
3. Initiate IV antihypertensives to target SBP 140 mm Hg
4. Neurosurgical consultation for lobar/cerebellar bleeds or signs of herniation
5. ICU monitoring with serial neuro checks and repeat imaging as indicated

Neuroimaging Pearls

Noncontrast CT is first‐line: acute blood appears hyperdense; midline shift quantifies mass effect—>5 mm often correlates with raised intracranial pressure and herniation risk.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Nicardipine infusion: start at 5 mg/h, increase by 2.5 mg/h every 5–15 minutes up to 15 mg/h to achieve SBP ~140 mm Hg. Labetalol bolus (10–20 mg IV) is an alternative.

Board Examination Focus

The correct answer is A. Craniotomy. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Intracranial aneurysms are saccular dilations at arterial bifurcations, most commonly at the anterior communicating artery (ACom). Hemodynamic stress and endothelial dysfunction lead to focal arterial wall degradation. Rupture risk is governed by wall tension (per Laplace’s law), which increases proportionally with aneurysm radius and inversely with wall thickness. While systemic factors such as smoking and hypertension compromise vessel integrity and contribute to aneurysm formation, longitudinal natural history studies consistently identify aneurysm diameter as the single strongest predictor of subarachnoid hemorrhage. Effective clinical management balances size thresholds against patient-specific factors to decide on prophylactic intervention versus surveillance.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Size drives rupture risk most robustly. In the International Study of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (ISUIA, 2003), 5-year cumulative rupture rates for anterior circulation aneurysms were:
• <7 mm: 0.05%
• 7–12 mm: 2.6%
• >12 mm: 14.5%
The Unruptured Cerebral Aneurysm Study of Japan (UCAS Japan, 2013) found an adjusted hazard ratio of 10.4 (95% CI 3.34–32.3) for aneurysms >7 mm versus <3 mm. AHA/ASA Guidelines (2015) recommend considering repair of anterior circulation aneurysms >7 mm (Class IIb; Level B). Mechanistically, larger aneurysms accrue higher wall tension (T = P × r/(2 w)), promoting focal wall thinning and rupture.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Smoking
Although smoking elevates aneurysm formation and rupture risk (relative risk ~1.8), its independent effect is modest compared to size. Smoking exacerbates wall inflammation but does not determine size‐related wall tension.

C. Hypertension
Chronic hypertension increases transmural pressure and contributes to aneurysm genesis, but multivariate analyses show only a minor independent effect on rupture risk (HR ~1.3). When controlling for diameter, hypertension is not a primary rupture predictor.

D. Family history of aneurysms
A familial predisposition raises aneurysm formation and multiplicity rates but does not directly influence rupture probability. Family history guides screening rather than rupture risk stratification.

Clinical Pearls

- Laplace’s law (Tension = Pressure × Radius / (2 × Wall thickness)) underpins why small increases in aneurysm radius sharply raise wall tension.
• ACom aneurysms, although anterior, warrant the same size‐based risk stratification as other anterior circulation aneurysms.
• Aneurysms <5 mm in asymptomatic, low‐risk patients often undergo serial imaging and aggressive risk factor management rather than immediate repair.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overemphasizing systemic factors (e.g., hypertension) and underestimating morphological predictors like diameter.
2. Confusing risk factors for aneurysm formation (family history) with drivers of rupture, leading to misprioritized management.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA “Guideline for the Management of Patients With Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms” (American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, 2015): Recommends consideration of prophylactic repair for anterior circulation aneurysms exceeding 7 mm (Class IIb; Level B).
• Unruptured Cerebral Aneurysm Study of Japan (UCAS Japan, 2013): Prospective cohort showing aneurysms >7 mm carry an adjusted HR of 10.4 (95% CI 3.34–32.3) for rupture compared to those <3 mm, reinforcing diameter as the primary risk factor.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a 4R‐tauopathy presenting with early postural instability, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, and frontal cognitive dysfunction. Key neuroanatomical structures include the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) and midbrain tegmentum, whose degeneration leads to slowed vertical saccades and downgaze limitation. Vascular parkinsonism features lower‐body–predominant bradykinesia and gait freezing due to subcortical ischemic lesions but spares vertical gaze. Dementia with Lewy bodies presents with visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and marked levodopa sensitivity. Multiple system atrophy shows autonomic failure, cerebellar signs, and poor levodopa response. (Word count: 142)

Evidence-Based Analysis

PSP diagnosis hinges on early falls (<1 year), vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, axial rigidity, and cognitive slowing. The Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2017 criteria designate “probable PSP‐Richardson syndrome” when vertical supranuclear gaze palsy or slowing of vertical saccades is present plus postural instability. Despite coexisting vascular risk factors and ischemic MRI changes common in the elderly, true vertical gaze limitation is pathognomonic for PSP, not vascular parkinsonism. Midbrain atrophy on sagittal MRI (“hummingbird sign”) further supports PSP (Quinn et al., Neurology 2017). Levodopa trials yield minimal benefit (<20% transient improvement), reflecting predominant tau pathology ( Spillantini & Goedert, Lancet Neurol 2013).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Vascular parkinsonism
• Lacks supranuclear gaze palsy; gait disturbance is feet‐predominant, not early vertical gaze restriction.
• Misconception: white matter hyperintensities equal vascular parkinsonism; ignores hallmark eye movement abnormality.
• Differentiator: preserved ocular motility vs. PSP’s gaze palsy.

C. Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)
• Core features: visual hallucinations, cognitive fluctuations, severe REM‐sleep behavior disorder; absent here.
• Misconception: any dementia plus parkinsonism equals DLB; vertical gaze impairment is not a Lewy body sign.
• Differentiator: DLB has early visual hallucinations and pronounced cholinergic deficits (supportive DAT scan).

D. Multiple system atrophy (MSA)
• Presents with autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence), cerebellar signs; neither described.
• Misconception: MSA can present as parkinsonism with falls; but early vertical gaze palsy is not typical.
• Differentiator: autonomic involvement and cerebellar ataxia vs. supranuclear gaze palsy.

Clinical Pearls

- Early postural instability with vertical gaze palsy is almost pathognomonic for PSP.
• Midbrain atrophy on midsagittal MRI (“hummingbird” or “penguin silhouette”) is a supportive imaging marker.
• Levodopa challenge in PSP yields limited benefit; trial duration 4–6 weeks is sufficient to assess response.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overcalling vascular parkinsonism in any elderly patient with white matter changes, without assessing eye movements.
2. Misattributing early falls exclusively to cerebellar or basal ganglia disease without considering supranuclear gaze palsy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society, Diagnostic Criteria for PSP (2017): Defines “probable PSP” by vertical supranuclear gaze palsy or saccade slowing plus early postural instability; Level B evidence.
2. Boxer AL et al., Phase II BIIB092 (gosuranemab) trial in PSP (Ann Neurol, 2020): Monoclonal anti‐tau antibody failed to slow progression; underscores unmet need for disease‐modifying therapy; Phase II RCT, Level IIA evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the midbrain tegmentum, especially the riMLF and interstitial nucleus of Cajal, impairs vertical saccade generation. Subthalamic nucleus and globus pallidus degeneration contribute to axial rigidity and frontal executive dysfunction.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP is a primary 4‐repeat tauopathy: abnormal hyperphosphorylated tau aggregates in neurons and glia (tufted astrocytes), leading to neurofibrillary tangles in midbrain and basal ganglia, manifesting clinically as gaze palsy and postural instability.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: early falls, vertical gaze limitation, cognitive slowing.
2. Neurological exam: confirm supranuclear vertical gaze palsy.
3. MRI brain: assess midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”), rule out alternative causes.
4. Levodopa trial: document response (<20% improvement supports PSP).
5. Apply MDS‐PSP criteria for certainty.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Sagittal T1‐weighted MRI showing selective atrophy of the midbrain tegmentum with preserved pons (“hummingbird”) yields sensitivity ~75% and specificity ~90% for PSP.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No approved disease-modifying agents; symptomatic management with amantadine (100–300 mg/day) may modestly improve gait. Levodopa up to 1,000 mg/day for bradykinesia yields limited transient benefit; monitor for dyskinesias.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Watershed infarcts occur at border‐zone regions between major cerebral arteries, most often between the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and middle cerebral artery (MCA) territories or between MCA and posterior cerebral artery (PCA). These infarcts typically reflect hemodynamic compromise from hypotension or high‐grade proximal stenosis/occlusion. Rapid vascular imaging is essential to identify treatable large‐vessel stenosis, guide hemodynamic management, and evaluate eligibility for reperfusion strategies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the preferred next step:
• The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level A) recommend emergent CTA (or MRA) immediately after noncontrast CT to assess for large‐vessel occlusion or high‐grade stenosis.
• CTA provides rapid, high‐resolution visualization of both intracranial and extracranial circulation in under 5 minutes, facilitating decisions on endovascular therapy or carotid revascularization.
• Prospective studies (e.g., the MR CLEAN trial ancillary imaging analyses, 2015) demonstrated that patients with proximal carotid or MCA occlusion benefit most when identified quickly by CTA.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. MRI brain
• Why incorrect: Although diffusion‐weighted MRI is more sensitive for acute ischemia, it is time‐consuming, less available in many EDs, and does not reliably detect vessel patency without additional MRA sequences.
• Misconception: Belief that MRI must precede any vascular study; delays critical revascularization decisions.
• Differentiator: CTA completes both parenchymal and vascular assessment rapidly.

C. Echocardiography
• Why incorrect: Transthoracic or transesophageal echo assesses cardioembolic sources (e.g., PFO, left ventricular thrombus) but does not evaluate cervical/intracranial arteries.
• Misconception: Assuming cardioembolism is the most common cause of watershed infarcts.
• Differentiator: Watershed infarcts primarily reflect hemodynamic issues, not embolic.

D. Carotid Doppler ultrasound
• Why incorrect: Limited to extracranial carotid arteries, operator‐dependent, and cannot visualize intracranial vessels or assess distal MCA/PCA stenosis.
• Misconception: That carotid Doppler is sufficient to rule out large‐vessel disease.
• Differentiator: CTA images both extracranial and intracranial beds in one study.

Clinical Pearls

- Watershed infarcts at the ACA–MCA junction often indicate systemic hypotension superimposed on carotid stenosis.
• CTA should be performed immediately after noncontrast CT in any suspected large‐vessel or border‐zone stroke.
• In resource‐limited settings without CTA, urgent transfer for vascular imaging is warranted rather than delay with MRI.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering MRI first in acute stroke delays decision on thrombectomy or carotid intervention.
2. Believing carotid Doppler alone is adequate to rule out intracranial stenosis in border‐zone strokes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke
• Recommendation: Perform CTA (or MRA) immediately after noncontrast CT in suspected large‐vessel occlusion (Class I, Level A).
2. ESO–ESMINT 2021 Guidelines on Mechanical Thrombectomy
• Recommendation: Vascular imaging including CTA or MRA is mandatory before endovascular therapy (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Border‐zone regions lie between ACA–MCA and MCA–PCA territories, often at the cortical convexity (external watershed) or subcortical white matter (internal watershed). Hypoperfusion here produces “string‐of‐pearl” infarct patterns.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Watershed infarcts result from prolonged systemic hypotension or carotid/MCA stenosis reducing perfusion pressure below the lower autoregulatory limit. Compensatory vasodilation fails, leading to selective neuronal necrosis in distal arterial territories.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. CTA head and neck to assess for large‐vessel stenosis/occlusion.
3. If CTA unavailable, MRA or rapid transfer for vascular imaging.
4. Echocardiography and prolonged cardiac monitoring for secondary embolic sources.
5. Carotid Doppler as adjunct if CTA contraindicated.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On CT, watershed infarcts appear as wedge‐shaped low‐density areas at the cortical junction or periventricular white matter.
• CTA collateral grading predicts outcome: robust leptomeningeal collaterals mitigate infarct growth.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Parkinsonism requires bradykinesia plus rigidity, resting tremor or postural instability. Core structures include the substantia nigra–striatum pathway (dopaminergic deficit) and brainstem vertical gaze centers (riMLF, interstitial nucleus). Vascular parkinsonism results from small-vessel ischemic injury to subcortical white matter, causing gait impairment and lower-body rigidity without supranuclear eye movement abnormalities. Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a primary tauopathy marked by vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, early falls, axial rigidity, and frontal cognitive changes. Differentiation hinges on ocular motility and MRI patterns—white matter hyperintensities versus selective midbrain atrophy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

PSP is diagnosed by the presence of vertical supranuclear gaze palsy (especially downgaze impairment), early unexplained falls, axial rigidity and cognitive decline, per the 2017 Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Clinical Diagnostic Criteria (Höglinger et al., Movement Disorders, 2017). Vascular parkinsonism can present with gait freezing and falls but spares ocular motility. Incidental periventricular ischemic changes on MRI are common in elderly with vascular risk factors (Wardlaw et al., Lancet Neurol 2015) and do not account for supranuclear gaze palsy. PSP pathology features 4-repeat tau accumulation in midbrain nuclei (riMLF) and globus pallidus, leading to the “hummingbird sign” on mid-sagittal MRI (Oba et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2005).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Vascular parkinsonism – Ocular movements remain intact; cognitive decline and vertical gaze palsy are not features.
B. Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) – Presents with gait apraxia, urinary incontinence, ventriculomegaly (DESH) on MRI; lacks vertical gaze palsy.
C. Parkinson's disease (PD) – Characterized by asymmetric onset, resting tremor, good levodopa response; early ocular motor signs and falls are atypical.

Clinical Pearls

- Vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, especially downgaze restriction, is nearly pathognomonic for PSP.
• Vascular parkinsonism presents with lower-body rigidity and gait disturbance but spares eye movements and often lacks significant early cognitive decline.
• The midbrain-to-pons area ratio (<0.52) on sagittal MRI supports PSP diagnosis with >80% specificity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing all gait impairment and cognitive decline in an elderly hypertensive/diabetic patient to vascular parkinsonism without assessing ocular motility.
2. Assuming early falls always indicate advanced PD rather than considering atypical parkinsonian syndromes such as PSP.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2017 MDS Clinical Diagnostic Criteria for PSP (Höglinger et al., Movement Disorders): Defines probable PSP by vertical supranuclear gaze palsy plus postural instability; consensus-based (Level II evidence).
• Park et al., JAMA Neurol 2018: Demonstrated that a midbrain-to-pons area ratio <0.52 on MRI yields 82% sensitivity and 90% specificity for PSP diagnosis (Level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PSP involves tau deposition in midbrain nuclei (riMLF, interstitial nucleus), subthalamic nucleus, and globus pallidus, disrupting vertical gaze pathways and frontal-subcortical circuits. Vascular parkinsonism arises from ischemic lesions in periventricular and basal ganglia white-matter tracts.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP is driven by accumulation of 4-repeat tau isoforms, leading to neuronal loss in vertical gaze centers. Vascular parkinsonism results from chronic small-vessel ischemia injuring dopaminergic and motor-execution pathways in the basal ganglia and frontal lobes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm parkinsonism (bradykinesia + rigidity/tremor/postural instability).
2. Evaluate ocular motility for supranuclear gaze palsy.
3. Review fall history: early vs late onset.
4. Obtain MRI: assess midbrain atrophy vs periventricular WMH vs ventriculomegaly.
5. Assess levodopa response.
6. Integrate clinical and radiological data for PSP versus vascular parkinsonism.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- PSP: “Hummingbird” sign (midbrain tegmental atrophy) on sagittal MRI and reduced midbrain-to-pons ratio.
• Vascular parkinsonism: Extensive periventricular white matter hyperintensities and lacunes in basal ganglia on T2/FLAIR.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT, Osler–Weber–Rendu) is an autosomal dominant vascular dysplasia characterized by mucocutaneous telangiectasias and visceral arteriovenous malformations (AVMs). Core concepts:
1. Telangiectasias (lips, oral mucosa) signal systemic AVMs.
2. Pulmonary AVMs permit paradoxical emboli and hemorrhage via right-to-left shunts.
3. Screening for pulmonary AVMs in HHT is critical to prevent neurologic complications.

(Word count: 86)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Performing a pulmonary CT angiogram is the most immediate and evidence-based step. The 2020 International HHT Guidelines (Faughnan et al., Ann Intern Med 2020) strongly recommend screening all suspected HHT patients with contrast echocardiography followed by CT pulmonary angiography to detect AVMs (Level A evidence). Identifying and embolizing pulmonary AVMs reduces risks of brain abscess, paradoxical stroke, and hemorrhage (Shovlin et al., Chest 2021). In this 2021 Part 2 exam scenario, the mucocutaneous petechiae (telangiectasias) and recurrent cerebral bleeds on aspirin point toward underlying HHT with pulmonary AVMs—hence CT angiography is the correct next step.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Consider a case of Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome
• Incorrect as a standalone action: suspicion must be followed by definitive AVM detection.
• Misconception: identification of HHT alone without AVM screening delays management.

C. Discontinue aspirin and monitor coagulation profile
• Coagulation studies (PT/INR, aPTT) do not assess platelet dysfunction from aspirin.
• Misconception: stopping aspirin suffices; overlooks structural AVM risk.

D. Order a platelet function test
• Platelet function assays detect antiplatelet effect but do not address AVMs.
• Misconception: attributing hemorrhages solely to aspirin rather than vascular malformation.

1. Use Curacao Criteria (epistaxis, telangiectasia, visceral AVMs, family history) for HHT diagnosis.

1. Blaming recurrent bleeds solely on aspirin without evaluating structural lesions.
2. Ordering coagulation panels for antiplatelet therapy monitoring—aspirin alters platelet function, not coagulation factors.

1. International HHT Guidelines, Faughnan et al., Ann Intern Med 2020: “All patients with suspected HHT should undergo screening for pulmonary AVMs using contrast echocardiography followed by CT angiography” (Grade 1A).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutations in ENG or ACVRL1 disrupt TGF-β signaling, leading to fragile, dilated vessels without intervening capillaries. Pulmonary AVMs create right-to-left shunts allowing direct arterialization of venous blood, predisposing to embolic events and hemorrhage.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify mucocutaneous telangiectasias and recurrent epistaxis.
2. Apply Curacao Criteria to assess HHT probability.
3. Perform contrast echocardiography; if positive, proceed to pulmonary CT angiography.
4. Manage identified AVMs with transcatheter embolization.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is indicated to screen for cerebral AVMs once HHT is suspected, but pulmonary AVM detection precedes given higher yield and immediate intervention options.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] • Basal ganglia–frontal cortical circuits: Damage to subcortical white matter or lacunar infarcts disrupts striatal input, producing lower‐body bradykinesia rather than classic tremor‐predominant PD.
• Distribution of parkinsonism: “Lower body parkinsonism” with gait slowing, shuffling and freezing suggests vascular etiology versus the asymmetric limb onset of idiopathic PD.
• Therapeutic response: Vascular parkinsonism typically shows minimal L-Dopa benefit, but mild to moderate improvement can occur when perivascular ischemic damage spares nigrostriatal neurons (Zijlmans et al., 2004).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Vascular Parkinson’s disease is characterized by predominant lower limb bradykinesia, postural instability and gait impairment with scant tremor, attributable to small‐vessel ischemic lesions in the striatal‐thalamic‐frontal pathways. MRI evidence of periventricular white‐matter hyperintensities and basal ganglia lacunes correlates with clinical severity (Schrag et al., 2000). Although L-Dopa response is classically poor, up to 30% of cases demonstrate a partial benefit when ischemic injury spares dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (Zijlmans et al., 2004; MDS 2021 criteria). By contrast, PSP, MSA and other syndromes have distinct clinical signs (e.g. vertical gaze palsy, autonomic failure, cerebellar ataxia) and uniformly poor dopaminergic responsiveness.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP)
– Incorrect: Presents with early vertical gaze palsy, axial rigidity, falls within 1 year and “hummingbird” midbrain atrophy. L-Dopa response is negligible (<10%). Misconception: PSP can mimic PD but lacks isolated lower limb onset.

C. Kafor rekab syndrome
– Incorrect: Not recognized in the peer‐reviewed neurology literature; no defined clinical phenotypes or imaging correlates. Acts as a distractor rather than a valid differential.

D. Multiple system atrophy
– Incorrect: Features include autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence), cerebellar signs (MSA‐C) or parkinsonism with poor L-Dopa response (MSA‐P). Not restricted to lower limbs and L-Dopa benefit is minimal.

• Partial L-Dopa responsiveness does not exclude vascular etiology if imaging shows lacunar infarcts.

1. Equating any L-Dopa responsiveness with idiopathic PD—vascular cases may transiently improve.
2. Overlooking small‐vessel ischemic disease on MRI when tremor is absent, leading to misdiagnosis as atypical degenerative parkinsonism.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2021 consensus diagnostic criteria for vascular parkinsonism: defines “probable” vascular parkinsonism when lower‐limb bradykinesia, MRI‐confirmed basal ganglia lacunes and lack of alternative cause coexist (Level II evidence).
2. European Academy of Neurology 2023 guideline on cerebral small vessel disease and gait disorders: recommends structured gait assessment and T2/FLAIR MRI screening in suspected vascular parkinsonism (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vascular lesions in the internal capsule, putamen and periventricular white matter interrupt the striato‐pallidal and striato‐thalamo‐cortical loops, leading to bradykinetic gait without classic resting tremor (Lehericy et al., 2018).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Small‐vessel ischemia causes focal demyelination and gliosis in subcortical motor pathways; dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra are relatively preserved, accounting for partial L-Dopa response (Lipp et al., 2019).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: abrupt/subacute gait slowing without rest tremor.
2. Exam: assess limb rigidity, gait, ocular movements.
3. MRI brain: look for lacunes, WMHs in basal ganglia/internal capsule.
4. Trial of L-Dopa (up to 600 mg/day for 4 weeks).
5. Integrate imaging and clinical response for diagnosis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• T2/FLAIR lacunes in striatum/internal capsule strongly support vascular parkinsonism.
• Absence of midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”) and pontine “hot cross bun” rule out PSP and MSA, respectively.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

L-Dopa remains first‐line trial in vascular parkinsonism despite modest effect; titrate slowly to monitor benefit, and address vascular risk factors (antiplatelet, statin therapy) for secondary prevention.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is a nonatherosclerotic, noninflammatory arteriopathy affecting medium-sized arteries, classically the renal and carotid arteries. Key concepts:
• FMD leads to “string-of-beads” stenoses and predisposes to ischemic stroke via arterial dissection or thromboembolism.
• Stroke in FMD warrants evaluation for concomitant renal artery involvement because up to 60–75% of cerebrovascular FMD patients have renal lesions.
• Invasive renal angiography remains the gold standard for detecting hemodynamically significant renal artery stenosis and guiding angioplasty.
(This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Renal angiography directly visualizes the beaded lesions and stenoses characteristic of FMD and guides percutaneous transluminal renal angioplasty (PTRA), which improves blood pressure control and reduces renin-mediated stroke risk. The 2019 ESC Guidelines on Peripheral Arterial Diseases (Class I, Level B) and the 2021 Society for Vascular Medicine FMD Consensus Statement recommend angiographic screening of the renal arteries in any patient with cerebrovascular FMD. Noninvasive CTA/MRA are acceptable for initial screening but invasive digital subtraction angiography remains definitive when intervention is contemplated.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Antiplatelet therapy
– While aspirin (75–100 mg daily) reduces recurrent stroke risk, it does not address undetected renal involvement in FMD.
– Misconception: Secondary prevention alone suffices; neglects systemic nature of FMD.

C. Carotid endarterectomy
– Reserved for atherosclerotic ≥70% carotid stenosis; FMD lesions are distal and irregular (“beaded”), not amenable to endarterectomy.
– Misconception: All carotid stenoses in stroke require surgery; FMD is medical/interventional.

D. Blood pressure control
– Essential in FMD management but must follow identification of stenotic lesions to tailor antihypertensives (ACE inhibitors preferred post-PTRA).
– Misconception: Empiric BP treatment without lesion localization may worsen renal hypoperfusion if bilateral disease exists.

• Invasive angiography is indicated when noninvasive imaging is inconclusive or intervention is planned.

1. Assuming antiplatelet therapy alone suffices without vascular bed screening.
2. Confusing FMD-related carotid lesions with atherosclerotic plaques and erroneously recommending endarterectomy.

- ESC Guidelines on Peripheral Arterial Diseases 2019: Recommend renal artery imaging (CTA/MRA or DSA) in cerebrovascular FMD (Class I, Level B).
• Society for Vascular Medicine 2021 FMD Consensus: Advocates invasive angiography for definitive diagnosis and planning PTRA when noninvasive studies show >50% stenosis (Class IIa, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

FMD affects the medium-sized renal arteries (renal hilum), carotid siphon, and vertebral arteries. Cerebral ischemia arises from thromboembolism or dissection in intracranial or extracranial carotid branches.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Medial fibroplasia, the most common FMD subtype, features smooth muscle hyperplasia and collagen deposition, creating alternating stenotic and aneurysmal segments (“string-of-beads”). This predisposes to turbulent flow, dissection, and downstream ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm ischemic stroke via MRI ± MRA.
2. Identify FMD in cerebrovascular bed (CTA/MRA shows beading).
3. Screen renal arteries: start with CTA/MRA; if >50% stenosis or intervention planned, proceed to DSA.
4. Plan PTRA for hemodynamically significant renal FMD.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA: high resolution for vessel wall and lumen morphology; beware of contrast nephropathy.
• MRA: avoids radiation/contrast; may overestimate stenosis.
• DSA: gold standard, allows simultaneous intervention.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Aspirin 81–100 mg daily for stroke prevention.
• Post-PTRA: ACE inhibitors or ARBs to optimize BP, titrating slowly in bilateral disease.
• Statins as per vascular risk profile despite nonatherosclerotic etiology.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Cerebral lacunar infarcts are small (<15 mm) subcortical strokes typically caused by lipohyalinosis of penetrating arteries. However, branch atheromatous disease—where proximal intracranial atherosclerotic plaque occludes penetrating branches—can mimic lacunar infarcts on MRI. Symptomatic intracranial large-artery stenosis (≥70% luminal narrowing) carries a high early recurrence risk. Distinguishing pure small‐vessel disease from branch occlusive disease via vascular imaging (CTA/MRA) informs whether monotherapy (aspirin) or short‐term dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is warranted for optimal secondary prevention.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus clopidogrel) for up to 90 days is the standard of care in patients with recent stroke attributable to severe (70%–99%) symptomatic intracranial stenosis. The SAMMPRIS trial (N Engl J Med 2011) randomized 451 patients to aggressive medical management (DAPT, statin, BP control) versus percutaneous transluminal angioplasty plus stenting. At one year, the medical group had a significantly lower rate of stroke or death (12.2% vs. 20%; hazard ratio 0.62; p=0.04). The CHANCE (Lancet Neurol 2013) and POINT (N Engl J Med 2018) trials further demonstrated that short‐term DAPT in minor stroke/TIA reduces recurrence (CHANCE HR 0.68, 95% CI 0.57–0.81; POINT HR 0.75, 95% CI 0.59–0.95) with an acceptable bleeding profile. The 2021 AHA/ASA Guidelines endorse DAPT for 90 days in symptomatic intracranial stenosis (Class I, Level of Evidence B). Aspirin alone is insufficient, IV thrombolysis is an acute reperfusion therapy rather than secondary prevention, and intracranial stenting carries a higher periprocedural risk without superior long-term benefit.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin (ASA)
– Monotherapy does not adequately inhibit platelet aggregation in high-risk intracranial stenosis. Misconception: “One‐size‐fits‐all” antiplatelet strategy regardless of etiology.

B. IV thrombolysis
– Indicated only for acute reperfusion within 4.5 hours of stroke onset, not for long‐term secondary prevention. Misconception: acute therapies double as chronic management.

D. Stenting
– SAMMPRIS showed higher periprocedural stroke/death (14.7%) versus medical therapy (5.8%). Misconception: mechanical revascularization always superior to medical management.

• Do not stent intracranial arteries outside of trials—medical therapy yields better outcomes.

1. Attributing all lacunar-appearing infarcts to small-vessel lipohyalinosis without further vascular work-up.
2. Believing that intracranial stenting is inherently superior to medical therapy for symptomatic stenosis.
3. Confusing acute reperfusion (tPA) protocols with long-term preventive strategies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Guidelines (Stroke 2021): Recommends aspirin + clopidogrel for 90 days in 70%–99% symptomatic intracranial stenosis (Class I, LOE B).

• CHANCE Trial (Lancet Neurol 2013): DAPT for 21 days in minor stroke/TIA reduced recurrence (HR 0.68).
• POINT Trial (N Engl J Med 2018): Confirmed DAPT benefit out to 90 days (HR 0.75).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MCA’s lenticulostriate arteries supply the posterior limb of the internal capsule and corona radiata. Branch atheromatous occlusion here produces contralateral pure motor hemiparesis typical of lacunar syndromes.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Branch atheromatous disease involves proximal plaque extension into penetrating artery orifices, precipitating lipohyalinosis and in situ thrombosis. High shear stress and platelet activation justify intensified antiplatelet regimens.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Non-contrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage.
2. MRI with DWI to confirm lacunar infarct.
3. CTA/MRA to assess intracranial stenosis severity.
4. Classify stroke subtype per TOAST criteria.
5. Initiate targeted secondary prevention (DAPT for symptomatic stenosis).

Neuroimaging Pearls

• DWI is >95% sensitive for acute lacunar infarcts within minutes.
• CTA/MRA accurately quantify intracranial stenosis ≥70%.
• Branch atheromatous disease often shows subcortical lesion with adjacent proximal arterial plaque.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Aspirin: COX-1 inhibitor; reduces thromboxane A2.
• Clopidogrel: P2Y12 ADP‐receptor blockade; prevents platelet aggregation.
• DAPT onset within 24 h, duration 90 days, then de‐escalate to monotherapy.
• Monitor for hemorrhagic complications, especially in elderly.
