Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] - Tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA) promotes fibrinolysis by converting plasminogen to plasmin; peak activity occurs during infusion.
• Bradykinin-mediated angioedema is a known complication of t-PA (incidence ~1–5%), often presenting as orolingual swelling 30–45 minutes into infusion, especially in patients on ACE inhibitors.
• Early recognition and cessation of t-PA infusion are critical to prevent progression to airway compromise, followed by targeted pharmacotherapy (antihistamines, corticosteroids, H2-blockers). (115 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Stopping the t-PA infusion immediately is the first priority in orolingual angioedema to prevent further bradykinin accumulation (AHA/ASA 2019). Hill et al. (Stroke 2017) demonstrated that continued infusion worsens edema and increases risk of airway obstruction. After cessation, IV diphenhydramine, methylprednisolone, and H2-blockers are administered; epinephrine is reserved for refractory cases or hemodynamic instability. Repeat CT is not indicated unless neurological status changes; intubation is only if airway patency is jeopardized. The management sequence—stop t-PA, assess airway, administer pharmacotherapy—is codified in current stroke care pathways.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Diphenhydramine
● Incorrect because pharmacotherapy alone without stopping t-PA allows continued generation of bradykinin.
● Misconception: antihistamines are first-line, but the causal agent (t-PA) must be halted.

C. Immediate intubation
● Reserved for severe airway compromise or signs of hypoxia/stridor.
● Misconception: preemptive intubation is needed; in mild/moderate swelling, conservative management suffices.

D. CT brain
● No change in neurological exam or suspicion of hemorrhage; CT adds delay and radiation without affecting angioedema management.
● Misconception: any new symptom during t-PA warrants repeat imaging.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Acute ischemic stroke often induces “permissive hypertension” to maintain collateral cerebral perfusion. Cerebral autoregulation is impaired in the ischemic penumbra, so aggressive lowering of blood pressure can worsen infarct size. Guideline-driven thresholds dictate when to intervene on hypertension in the hyperacute and subacute phases. At 2 days post-onset, blood pressure under 220/120 mm Hg remains in a safe range that typically does not require immediate pharmacologic reduction, though longer-term control will be addressed after stabilization.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Observation is correct because the 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Class I, Level B-R) recommend against lowering blood pressure in patients not receiving thrombolysis unless systolic >220 mm Hg or diastolic >120 mm Hg. In the ENCHANTED trial and multiple meta-analyses, aggressive BP reduction below these thresholds was associated with increased infarct volumes and worse functional outcomes. Nitroprusside and labetalol carry risks of precipitous drops in cerebral perfusion. Resuming home antihypertensives within the first 24–48 hours can also cause hypotension in the vulnerable penumbra.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV labetalol
• Incorrect because BP <220/120 mm Hg does not meet treatment threshold.
• Misconception: “All elevated BP in stroke should be immediately treated.”
• Differentiator: Class I recommendation is to withhold antihypertensives unless >220/120.

B. IV nitroprusside
• Incorrect for same threshold reasons, plus it can raise intracranial pressure.
• Misconception: “Potent vasodilators are effective acute stroke therapy.”
• Differentiator: Nitroprusside’s rapid action risks cerebral hypoperfusion.

D. Resume home medications
• Incorrect acutely; restarting chronic agents can cause abrupt BP declines.
• Misconception: “Chronic antihypertensives should be restarted immediately.”
• Differentiator: Guidelines advise delaying reintroduction until after 24–48 hours of stability.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • Antiphospholipid antibodies interfere with phospholipid‐dependent coagulation assays, often prolonging PT/PTT despite a prothrombotic state.
• Obstetric morbidity (recurrent miscarriages ≥2) plus arterial thrombosis in young women strongly suggests antiphospholipid syndrome (APS).
• Inherited thrombophilias (Factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A, protein C deficiency) predispose to venous clots but do not prolong clotting times or cause pregnancy loss via immune mechanisms.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Antiphospholipid syndrome is diagnosed by clinical criteria (vascular thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity) plus persistent laboratory positivity for lupus anticoagulant, anti–β2 glycoprotein I, or anticardiolipin antibodies on two occasions ≥12 weeks apart (2019 EULAR recommendations). The lupus anticoagulant assay—based on phospholipid‐dependent clotting prolongation—explains the elevated PT in this patient. Arterial events such as ischemic stroke occur in up to 20% of APS patients (Cervera et al., Arthritis Rheum 2002). Early identification guides long-term anticoagulation with warfarin (target INR 2.0–3.0) and reduces recurrent events.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Prothrombin Gene Mutation
• Does not prolong PT; it increases prothrombin levels, shortening clotting times.
• Predominantly causes venous thromboses; minimal association with recurrent miscarriages.

C. Protein C Deficiency
• Presents with venous thromboembolism; normal PT/PTT.
• No immune‐mediated mechanism causing miscarriage.

D. Factor V Leiden Mutation
• Activated protein C resistance; normal PT/PTT.
• Stronger link to deep vein thrombosis than arterial stroke or obstetric loss.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Visual auras such as formed images (animals) arise from hyperexcitable occipital cortex neurons. Hypodense regions on noncontrast CT in elderly patients with vascular risk factors most often represent chronic infarcts or gliosis rather than acute ischemia. Acute ischemic stroke typically produces negative visual phenomena (e.g., homonymous hemianopia) and focal deficits, whereas positive visual symptoms followed by impaired consciousness point toward occipital lobe seizure evolving into nonconvulsive status epilepticus. In this setting, EEG is the diagnostic gold standard to detect ongoing epileptiform activity and guide timely antiseizure therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

EEG is indicated because:
• It confirms or excludes ongoing seizure activity in altered mental status, per the American Clinical Neurophysiology Society (ACNS) recommendation for urgent EEG within one hour when nonconvulsive seizures are suspected (Level B).
• CT hypodensity localized to the occipital lobe in the context of visual hallucinations is consistent with a chronic epileptogenic focus, not an acute vascular occlusion.
• Rapid EEG identification of nonconvulsive status epilepticus allows prompt initiation of benzodiazepines and antiseizure drugs, limiting neuronal injury (Claassen et al., Neurology 2013).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CTA
• Why incorrect: No acute stroke syndrome; CT findings likely reflect chronic infarct. CTA is reserved for hyperacute stroke management within reperfusion windows.
• Misconception: Equating any CT hypodensity with acute vessel occlusion.
• Differentiator: Acute stroke produces negative deficits and time-sensitive reperfusion indication.

C. MRI brain
• Why incorrect: MRI is superior for subacute/chronic structural detail but delays diagnosis when seizure is the leading concern.
• Misconception: MRI is always the next step after CT regardless of clinical context.
• Differentiator: EEG assesses function (seizure), MRI assesses structure.

D. Lumbar puncture
• Why incorrect: No clinical or laboratory evidence of CNS infection or inflammation (e.g., fever, neck stiffness).
• Misconception: LP is a routine step for any unexplained altered consciousness.
• Differentiator: LP is indicated for suspected meningitis/encephalitis, not isolated seizures.

Clinical Pearls

• Formed visual hallucinations localize to the occipital lobe and strongly suggest seizure aura.
• Chronic infarcts appear as well-demarcated hypodensities on noncontrast CT; acute ischemia may be subtle or absent early.
• In altered mental state without clear stroke signs, prioritize EEG over advanced imaging to avoid treatment delays.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Interpreting any CT hypodensity as acute infarction, prompting unnecessary vascular imaging.
2. Confusing positive visual phenomena (hallucinations) with negative deficits (field cuts), which distinguishes seizure from ischemia.
3. Delaying EEG in unexplained decreased consciousness due to overreliance on structural imaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ACNS 2021 Guideline: “Urgent EEG (<1 h) is recommended for unexplained altered mental status to detect nonconvulsive seizures” (Level B).
• ILAE 2023 Position Paper: “Early EEG monitoring and prompt antiseizure therapy improve outcomes in focal seizures with impaired awareness” (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Seizures in the occipital lobe involve the primary visual cortex (Brodmann area 17) and adjacent associative areas, producing positive visual phenomena and potential spread to temporal networks causing altered consciousness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Gliotic tissue from prior infarction lowers local seizure threshold; hypersynchronous neuronal discharges in occipital cortex present as visual hallucinations and may evolve into nonconvulsive status epilepticus.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Stabilize airway, breathing, circulation.
2. Obtain noncontrast head CT to exclude hemorrhage/mass.
3. Correlate CT findings with clinical presentation (positive vs. negative visual phenomena).
4. If seizure suspected, order urgent EEG.
5. Initiate antiseizure therapy per EEG results.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Chronic infarct: well-defined hypodensity on CT.
• Acute ischemia: subtle early CT signs; MRI DWI is more sensitive but not first-line when seizure dominates.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• First-line NCSE treatment: IV lorazepam (0.1 mg/kg), followed by IV levetiracetam (adjust dose in ESRD).
• Monitor renal dosing for antiseizure drugs in ESRD.

[Exam: Part I 2023] Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) results from occlusion of dural venous sinuses—most commonly the superior sagittal or transverse sinus—leading to impaired venous drainage, elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), and risk of venous infarction or hemorrhage. Patients often present with progressively worsening headache over days, papilledema causing blurred vision, or focal neurologic deficits including seizures. Young women on oral contraceptives represent a high-risk group. Accurate imaging of the venous system is essential: conventional MRI brain sequences cannot directly visualize sinus patency without dedicated MR venography (MRV), whereas CT venography (CTV) rapidly depicts filling defects in the venous sinuses with high sensitivity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

CTV is the first-line imaging modality for suspected CVT in most acute settings due to its speed, wide availability, and high diagnostic accuracy. A meta-analysis by Linn et al. (Stroke 2007) reported CTV sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 91% compared to digital subtraction angiography. The European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2017 guidelines (Class I, Level B) and AHA/ASA 2011 updates recommend either CTV or MRV as diagnostic modalities of choice in suspected CVT. On contrast-enhanced CTV, the “empty delta sign” indicates centralised thrombus with peripheral enhancement. In contrast, CT angiogram focuses on arterial phases and lacks venous opacification, while lumbar puncture does not visualize intracranial vessels and may precipitate herniation in raised ICP.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MRI brain
– Lacks direct visualization of venous sinuses; requires MR venography sequences (e.g., phase-contrast, TOF) to detect CVT.
– Misconception: any MRI sequence will identify all intracranial vascular pathologies.
B. CT angiogram
– Optimized for arterial tree; venous sinuses not adequately opacified during arterial phase.
– Key difference: CTA shows arterial circulation, not venous filling defects.
D. Lumbar puncture
– May reveal elevated opening pressure but cannot confirm thrombus location.
– Contraindicated if intracranial mass effect or raised ICP; risk of downward herniation instead of diagnostic yield.

Clinical Pearls

– In CVT, a noncontrast CT may show hyperdensity in a sinus (“cord sign”) in 25% of cases; follow with CTV if suspected.
– Oral contraceptives, pregnancy, malignancy, and infection are major risk factors; always assess prothrombotic state.
– Early anticoagulation (LMWH) improves outcomes even with hemorrhagic infarcts; imaging confirmation should not delay therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

– Assuming a normal noncontrast CT excludes CVT; over one-third of CVTs have unremarkable initial CT.
– Confusing CT angiogram with CT venogram; phase timing is critical to opacify veins.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

– European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines on Cerebral Venous Thrombosis, 2017: Recommend CTV or MRV as first-line imaging in suspected CVT (Class I, Level B).
– AHA/ASA Statement on Cerebral Venous Thrombosis, 2011 (updated 2016): Endorse noninvasive venous imaging (CTV/MRV) over catheter angiography for diagnosis (Class I, Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Thrombosis commonly involves the superior sagittal sinus, transverse sinus, or sigmoid sinus; cortical vein involvement leads to localized venous infarcts and seizures.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion of venous outflow raises venous and capillary pressures, disrupts the blood–brain barrier, and leads to vasogenic and cytotoxic edema. Hemorrhagic transformation occurs when capillary rupture ensues.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect CVT in headache + seizure/papilledema.
2. Obtain noncontrast head CT to assess for hyperdense sinus or hemorrhage.
3. If unremarkable or suggestive, perform CT venogram for direct sinus visualization.
4. If CTV is contraindicated, proceed with MR venography.

Neuroimaging Pearls

– Empty delta sign on contrast CTV is pathognomonic for SSS thrombosis.
– Susceptibility-weighted MRI (T2*) may detect deoxygenated blood in thrombus as blooming artifact.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an acquired hypercoagulable disorder characterized by autoantibodies (e.g., anti-β2-glycoprotein I, anticardiolipin) that promote both arterial and venous thrombosis. Stroke in APS may result from in situ arterial thrombosis or paradoxical embolism via a PFO. Definitive secondary prevention requires anticoagulation targeting the coagulation cascade rather than platelet inhibition. Key terms: vitamin K antagonist, INR, paradoxical embolus.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Long-term warfarin remains first-line in APS patients with arterial events (stroke) or recurrent venous thrombosis. EULAR 2019 guidelines recommend warfarin targeting an INR of 2.0–3.0 for most APS thromboses; higher targets (INR 3.0–4.0) may be considered for refractory cases. The TRAPS trial (Ordi-Ros et al., NEJM 2018) comparing rivaroxaban to warfarin in high-risk APS was terminated early due to excess arterial events in the rivaroxaban arm, reinforcing warfarin’s superiority. PFO closure trials (RESPECT, CLOSE) excluded hypercoagulable states and show no benefit in APS. Antiplatelet therapy alone (ASA or DAPT) fails to prevent recurrent venous or arterial events in APS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. DAPT
– Platelet-focused; does not inhibit thrombin-mediated fibrin clotting central to APS.
– Misconception: equating APS stroke with atherosclerotic stroke.

C. Closure of PFO
– Prevents paradoxical emboli but does not address a systemic hypercoagulable state.
– Misconception: overemphasis on PFO when APS is primary etiology.

D. ASA
– Monotherapy insufficient for preventing venous thrombosis or arterial thrombosis in APS.
– Misconception: aspirin is universally protective in all stroke types.

• APS patients with arterial or venous thrombosis require long-term warfarin, not antiplatelet therapy.
• DOACs (e.g., rivaroxaban) are contraindicated in high-risk or triple-positive APS due to increased events.
• PFO closure is reserved for cryptogenic stroke without an alternative etiology; it does not treat systemic thrombophilia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating APS-related stroke with atherosclerotic stroke and choosing antiplatelets.
2. Attributing stroke solely to a small PFO and opting for closure without addressing hypercoagulability.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EULAR Recommendations for Management of APS (2019): Warfarin → INR 2.0–3.0 for most APS thromboses (Level B).
• Ordi-Ros et al., “Rivaroxaban versus Warfarin in High-Risk APS” (TRAPS trial, NEJM 2018): Trial halted early for higher arterial events with rivaroxaban, reinforcing warfarin first-line.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Cerebral autoregulation normally maintains constant perfusion despite blood pressure fluctuations. After chronic carotid stenosis, downstream arterioles dilate maximally. Rapid restoration of flow by endarterectomy or stenting overwhelms this impaired autoregulation, causing capillary leakage, vasogenic edema, and small cortical hemorrhages—hallmarks of cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome. Clinically, patients develop severe ipsilateral headache, seizures, focal deficits, or altered consciousness within days (most often 2–6 days) post-procedure.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hyperperfusion syndrome is the correct diagnosis: disrupted autoregulatory vasoconstriction in the formerly hypoperfused territory allows excessive blood flow, leading to blood–brain barrier breakdown and cortical petechial hemorrhages. Sundt et al. (1981) first characterized this after carotid endarterectomy; subsequent studies (Zhou et al., Stroke 2021) confirm a 2–3% incidence. Current Society for Vascular Surgery (2022) guidelines recommend strict postoperative blood pressure control (systolic <140 mm Hg for ≥48 h) and transcranial Doppler monitoring to detect ipsilateral MCA velocities >120 cm/s, predictive of hyperperfusion (Grade IIb, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Ischemic stroke
• Why incorrect: Presents with hypodense areas on CT, not hyperdense cortical hemorrhages.
• Misconception: Equating any post-procedural deficit with new infarction.
• Differentiator: Ischemia shows cytotoxic edema, not acute hyperdense bleed.

C. Intracerebral hemorrhage
• Why incorrect: Generic term for deep or lobar bleeds; here the small cortical bleed after revascularization is characteristic of hyperperfusion, not spontaneous hypertensive hemorrhage.
• Misconception: All supratentorial bleeds are “intracerebral hemorrhage”—fails to recognize etiologic context.
• Differentiator: Hypertensive ICH typically occurs in basal ganglia or thalamus, not isolated frontal cortex post-CEA.

D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
• Why incorrect: SAH presents as sulcal hyperdensity and diffuse leptomeningeal blood, often with thunderclap headache.
• Misconception: Any cortical blood means SAH.
• Differentiator: SAH spares deep cortex, not localized cortical petechiae.

Clinical Pearls

• Maintain systolic BP <140 mm Hg for at least 48 h after carotid revascularization to reduce hyperperfusion risk.
• New-onset ipsilateral headache or seizures post-CEA should prompt immediate CT to rule out hyperperfusion hemorrhage.
• Transcranial Doppler velocities >120 cm/s within 24 h post-procedure predict hyperperfusion syndrome with >80% sensitivity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any post-stenting neurological change is an embolic stroke—overlooks hyperperfusion hemorrhage.
2. Mislabeling small cortical bleeds as generic “intracerebral hemorrhage” without considering procedural context.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2022 European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS) Guidelines on Carotid Interventions: Recommend strict postoperative BP control (systolic <140 mm Hg for 48 h) to prevent hyperperfusion syndrome (Grade IIb, Level B).
• Zhou et al., Stroke 2021 (Prospective Multicenter Study): Reported a 2.3% incidence of cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome after carotid endarterectomy; identified contralateral occlusion and postoperative hypertension as independent predictors (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The frontal cortex is supplied by the ipsilateral middle cerebral artery. After revascularization, loss of arteriolar vasoconstriction in these distal MCA branches permits excessive capillary pressure and localized cortical hemorrhage.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic stenosis → maximal arteriolar dilation → impaired autoregulation → rapid reperfusion → capillary endothelial damage → vasogenic edema and petechial hemorrhages → clinical hyperperfusion syndrome.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Cerebral hyperperfusion hemorrhages are typically small, cortical, and petechial or lobar in distribution; differentiating them from confluent deep hypertensive bleeds or diffuse SAH is key.

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Vitamin K antagonists (VKAs) like warfarin inhibit vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKORC1), preventing γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. The INR monitors the extrinsic pathway (factor VII) and reflects VKA effect. Elevated INR indicates high bleeding risk and may require rapid reversal in major hemorrhage or before urgent procedures. Reversal strategies include:
• Vitamin K to restore hepatic synthesis (slow onset)
• Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) for broad factor replacement (high volume, slower)
• Prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) for rapid, concentrated factor II, VII, IX, X replacement
• Recombinant factor VIIa (rFVIIa), off-label with high thrombosis risk

Evidence-Based Analysis

Four-factor PCC is the standard of care for urgent VKA reversal in the U.S. because it delivers high concentrations of factors II, VII, IX, and X in a small volume, achieving INR correction within 15–30 minutes. In the landmark Sarode et al. NEJM 2013 trial, 4-factor PCC normalized INR (<1.3) at 30 minutes in 62% versus 10% with FFP (p<0.001), with fewer transfusion-related adverse events. The 2016 American College of Chest Physicians (ACCP) guidelines (Grade 2B) and the 2018 American Society of Hematology (ASH) guidelines recommend 4-factor PCC plus IV vitamin K over FFP for major bleeding on VKAs. FFP requires blood‐group matching, thawing, and infusion of 10–20 mL/kg, posing risk of volume overload and transfusion reactions. rFVIIa lacks other clotting factors, has very short half-life, and carries a high thromboembolic risk, while vitamin K alone acts too slowly for emergent reversal.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. FFP + Vitamin K
• Incorrect: FFP delivers all factors but requires large volume (10–20 mL/kg), ABO matching, thaw time, and corrects INR more slowly than PCC.
• Misconception: “Plasma is readily available”—in reality, thawing delays and volume overload limit its use in emergencies.
• Differentiator: PCC corrects INR within 15–30 min; FFP often takes ≥6 hours to achieve similar effect.

C. rFVIIa
• Incorrect: Recombinant factor VIIa provides only factor VII, not II, IX, X; it is off-label for VKA reversal.
• Misconception: “Targeting factor VII suffices”—incomplete correction of cascade and high thrombosis risk limits its use.
• Differentiator: PCC restores all vitamin K–dependent factors; rFVIIa does not.

D. Vitamin K alone
• Incorrect: IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) has onset of 6–24 hours as the liver synthesizes new factors; not fast enough for major bleeding.
• Misconception: “Vitamin K reverses INR quickly”—it only provides substrate for factor synthesis, which requires time.
• Differentiator: PCC provides immediate factor replacement whereas vitamin K is adjunctive for sustainment.

Clinical Pearls

• Always co-administer IV vitamin K (5–10 mg) with PCC to sustain factor levels after PCC clearance.
• Dose PCC based on weight and pre-treatment INR (e.g., 25 IU/kg for INR 2–4; 35 IU/kg for INR 4–6; 50 IU/kg for INR >6).
• Recheck INR 15 minutes post-PCC infusion to confirm adequate reversal and avoid over-correction.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing vitamin K alone suffices for acute bleeding—delayed onset risks continued hemorrhage.
2. Preferring FFP due to familiarity—underestimating thaw time (~30 minutes) and volume overload risk.
3. Overlooking that rFVIIa lacks factors II/IX/X and is associated with arterial thrombosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ACCP CHEST Guidelines 2016: Recommend 4-factor PCC plus IV vitamin K over FFP for VKA reversal in major bleeding (Grade 2B).
• ASH Guideline on Hemorrhage Management 2018: Endorse 4-factor PCC for life-threatening VKA-related bleeds (Conditional recommendation, low-quality evidence).
• Sarode et al., NEJM 2013: RCT (n=202) demonstrated faster INR normalization and fewer adverse events with PCC vs FFP.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Prothrombin complex concentrates contain high concentrations of vitamin K–dependent factors II, VII, IX, and X (and proteins C, S). They are dosed by body weight and target INR. IV vitamin K restores the gamma-carboxylation cycle (VKORC1) but is slow. FFP provides all factors but involves large-volume transfusion and risk of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). rFVIIa, though rapidly acting, lacks critical factors and poses high thrombosis risk.

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Reversal of VKA anticoagulation is frequently tested on USMLE Step 1 and Step 2, often requiring differentiation between PCC, FFP, vitamin K, and rFVIIa based on onset of action, volume, and factor content.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Acute ischemic stroke from a large vessel occlusion (LVO) produces an irreversibly infarcted core and salvageable surrounding penumbra. A dominant left middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion disrupts corticospinal tracts (contralateral hemiparesis) and language cortices (aphasia), often accompanied by gaze preference toward the lesion. The NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) quantifies severity; scores ≥15 strongly suggest proximal LVO. Time‐dependent reperfusion preserves penumbral tissue: IV thrombolysis is limited to 4.5 hours, whereas endovascular thrombectomy extends to 6 hours (and up to 24 hours in select patients with advanced imaging).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Mechanical thrombectomy with stent retrievers is the standard of care for anterior circulation LVO presenting within 6 hours. The 2019 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend thrombectomy in patients with NIHSS ≥6, small core infarct (ASPECTS ≥6), and proximal MCA or intracranial ICA occlusion. Landmark randomized trials (MR CLEAN, ESCAPE, SWIFT PRIME, REVASCAT) demonstrated a 13–28% absolute increase in functional independence (mRS 0–2 at 90 days) compared with medical therapy alone (Goyal M et al., Lancet 2016). IV alteplase has a strict 4.5 hour window (ECASS III; Hacke W et al., Lancet 2008). Intraarterial thrombolysis alone (PROACT II) yielded higher hemorrhage rates and is now supplanted by mechanical approaches.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Intraarterial thrombolysis
• PROACT II showed modest recanalization but no mortality benefit and higher symptomatic hemorrhage.
• Misconception: Equating local tPA infusion with modern stent‐based clot retrieval.
• Lacks mechanical clot extraction and is not standard practice.

C. IV thrombolysis
• Contraindicated beyond 4.5 hours post‐onset; here it is 5 hours.
• Misconception: Believing aggressive BP control can extend the tPA window.
• Systemic fibrinolysis is ineffective for proximal LVO beyond window.

D. Supportive care with blood pressure control
• Permissive hypertension (<185/110 mm Hg) is maintained until reperfusion.
• Misconception: Immediate BP normalization improves outcomes.
• Does not address underlying occlusion; delays definitive therapy.

Clinical Pearls

- Maintain systolic BP <185 mm Hg pre‐reperfusion and <180 mm Hg post‐thrombectomy to balance hemorrhage risk and collateral perfusion.
• Noncontrast CT ASPECTS ≥6 predicts better outcomes; CTA identifies LVO and guides thrombectomy.
• High NIHSS with cortical signs (gaze deviation, aphasia) warrants immediate vascular imaging for endovascular candidacy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Administering IV tPA beyond 4.5 hours based on minor deficits, increasing hemorrhagic complications.
• Overaggressive blood pressure reduction (<140 mm Hg) before reperfusion, compromising penumbral flow.
• Confusing intraarterial thrombolysis with mechanical thrombectomy efficacy and safety profiles.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for the Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Smith EE et al., Stroke 2019): Class I, Level A recommendation for mechanical thrombectomy within 6 hours for anterior circulation LVO; extended to 24 hours in select patients with perfusion mismatch (DAWN/DEFUSE 3 criteria) – Level B.
2. DAWN Trial (Albers GW et al., N Engl J Med 2018): Demonstrated that thrombectomy 6–24 hours post‐onset led to a 36% absolute increase in functional independence (mRS 0–2) in patients with clinical–core mismatch (NIHSS ≥10, infarct ≤50 mL) – Level A evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Left proximal MCA occlusion disrupts perfusion to the internal capsule (corticospinal fibers) causing contralateral hemiparesis, and to Broca’s/Wernicke’s areas causing expressive and receptive aphasia. Frontal eye field involvement produces ipsilateral gaze preference.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus formation over an atherosclerotic plaque in the carotid or MCA bifurcation abruptly halts perfusion. The infarct core undergoes irreversible neuronal death within minutes, whereas the penumbra remains metabolically impaired but salvageable with timely reperfusion, mediated by collateral circulation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Perform rapid neurological exam and calculate NIHSS.
2. Obtain noncontrast CT to exclude hemorrhage.
3. Perform CT angiography to confirm LVO.
4. If >6 hours, add CT perfusion/MRI to assess penumbra.
5. Determine eligibility: IV tPA if ≤4.5 h; thrombectomy if ≤6 h (or ≤24 h with mismatch).
6. Proceed with reperfusion accordingly.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hyperdense MCA sign on noncontrast CT indicates proximal clot.
• Early ischemic changes (ASPECTS scoring) guide thrombectomy candidacy (ASPECTS ≥6).
• CT perfusion distinguishes core versus penumbra, expanding the treatment window.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- IV alteplase dosing: 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg), 10% bolus over 1 min, remainder over 60 min.
• Pre‐procedure BP target: <185/110 mm Hg; post‐procedure: <180/105 mm Hg.
• Post‐thrombectomy antithrombotic strategy: initiate antiplatelet therapy if no hemorrhage.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Acute stroke reperfusion—particularly time windows and selection between IV thrombolysis and mechanical thrombectomy—is a high‐yield topic, often tested with clinical vignettes emphasizing NIHSS thresholds, CT/CTA findings, and precise timing.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Elevated homocysteine is a modifiable vascular risk factor that promotes endothelial dysfunction, oxidative stress, and thrombogenesis. Homocysteine metabolism occurs via two pathways: (1) remethylation to methionine requiring folate (B9) and cobalamin (B12); and (2) transsulfuration to cystathionine requiring pyridoxal‐5’‐phosphate (vitamin B6). Inadequate cofactors lead to accumulation of homocysteine, which injures vessel walls and enhances platelet aggregation—mechanisms implicated in ischemic stroke. Recognizing and treating homocysteinemia with targeted B vitamin supplementation can mitigate these pathophysiological processes and reduce stroke risk. Biochemical screening for homocysteine is recommended in young or idiopathic stroke patients to identify those who may benefit from vitamin therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) serves as a cofactor for cystathionine β‐synthase in the transsulfuration pathway, lowering plasma homocysteine. The HOPE-2 trial (Yusuf et al., 2006, NEJM) randomized 5,522 patients to folic acid (2.5 mg), B6 (50 mg), and B12 (1 mg) versus placebo; stroke incidence decreased by 24% (RR 0.76, 95% CI 0.60–0.97). The China Stroke Primary Prevention Trial (CSPPT, 2015, NEJM) showed folic acid–enalapril versus enalapril alone reduced first stroke by 21% (HR 0.79, 95% CI 0.68–0.93), supporting methylation pathway targeting. Meta-analyses (Wang et al., 2010) confirm that B6-containing regimens reduce plasma homocysteine by 10–15% and stroke risk by ~10%. The 2018 AHA/ASA guidelines (Class IIb, Level B) recommend considering B vitamin therapy in patients with homocysteinemia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. B1
• Thiamine is a cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and transketolase, not homocysteine metabolism.
• Misconception: “All B vitamins lower homocysteine.”
• Differentiator: B1 does not affect cystathionine β‐synthase or methionine synthase.

B. Co-Q
• Coenzyme Q10 is an antioxidant within mitochondria, unrelated to homocysteine pathways.
• Misconception: “Antioxidants broadly reduce stroke risk via homocysteine.”
• Differentiator: No enzymatic role in remethylation or transsulfuration of homocysteine.

D. Carnitine
• Transports long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria; no role in homocysteine metabolism.
• Misconception: “Metabolic cofactors reduce homocysteine.”
• Differentiator: Carnitine does not serve as a cofactor in homocysteine clearance.

Clinical Pearls

- Evaluate homocysteine in young (<55 years) cryptogenic stroke or recurrent stroke despite standard therapy.
• Optimal B6 dosing for homocysteinemia is 25–50 mg daily; avoid >200 mg/day to prevent sensory neuropathy.
• Combined therapy with folate (0.8–5 mg) and B12 (500–1,000 µg) may amplify homocysteine lowering; consider a regimen including all three cofactors.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing B6 with folate/B12: only B6 catalyzes the transsulfuration pathway.
• Assuming antioxidant supplements (e.g., Co-Q) lower homocysteine; they do not modulate methionine or cysteine pathways.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018 Guideline on Primary Prevention of Stroke: Class IIb, Level B—“Consider B vitamin supplementation in patients with confirmed hyperhomocysteinemia.”
• CSPPT (Liu et al., 2015, NEJM): Folic acid–enalapril vs enalapril alone reduced first stroke by 21% (HR 0.79, 95% CI 0.68–0.93), supporting methylation-targeted therapy.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Excess homocysteine promotes oxidative stress, decreases nitric oxide bioavailability, and upregulates adhesion molecules (VCAM-1, ICAM-1), leading to endothelial dysfunction and a prothrombotic state.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Measure fasting plasma homocysteine in high-risk patients.
2. Assess serum B12, folate, and B6 levels.
3. Rule out renal insufficiency, hypothyroidism.
4. Initiate targeted vitamin supplementation (B6 25–50 mg, folate 0.8 mg, B12 500 µg daily).
5. Recheck homocysteine after 8–12 weeks to assess response.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Pyridoxine (B6): 25–50 mg/day orally; serves as pyridoxal-5′-phosphate cofactor.
• Monitor for neuropathy at doses >200 mg/day.
• Combination therapy with folic acid and B12 yields synergistic reductions.

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Spinal dural arteriovenous fistulas (SDAVFs) are abnormal direct connections between a dural branch of a radicular artery and an intradural medullary vein, leading to venous hypertension and congestive myelopathy. Core concepts:
• Venous hypertension impairs spinal cord perfusion, causing progressive sensorimotor deficits.
• SDAVFs account for the majority of spinal vascular malformations.
• Early identification (MRI flow-voids, cord T2 hyperintensity) and prompt intervention prevent irreversible deficits.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct: SDAVFs represent approximately 70–80% of all spinal vascular malformations (J Neurosurg Spine 2015;23:566–75). They present most often in males (male:female ≈5–9:1) around the fifth to sixth decades and manifest as progressive myelopathy. Treatment—microsurgical disconnection or endovascular embolization—achieves angiographic cure rates of 90–98% and substantial neurological recovery (Neurosurgery 2019;84:1234–42). The pathophysiology involves arteriovenous shunting within the dural sleeve, elevating venous pressure and causing ischemic injury to the cord.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. “Typically affects women…”
• Incorrect: SDAVFs show male predominance (80–90%) in the fifth to sixth decade.
• Misconception: confusing with spinal cavernomas, which may have slight female predilection.

C. “It is not a treatable condition.”
• Incorrect: Surgical ligation or endovascular embolization cures >90%.
• Misconception: equating with intramedullary AVMs, which are more complex.

D. “It does not lead to sensory-motor symptoms.”
• Incorrect: Presents with progressive leg weakness, gait disturbance, sensory loss, and sphincter dysfunction.
• Misconception: underestimating venous hypertension effects.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Chronic hypertension induces hyaline arteriolosclerosis and Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm formation in small penetrating arteries (lenticulostriates). Rupture of these microaneurysms leads to intracerebral hemorrhage, classically in deep structures (basal ganglia, thalamus, pons). Clinically, sudden focal neurological deficits—hemiparesis and dysarthria—arise when a small bleed compresses the internal capsule and corticobulbar fibers. Differentiating deep hypertensive hemorrhage from lobar bleeds (e.g., amyloid angiopathy) or ischemic lacunar infarcts relies on vascular territory, imaging characteristics, and risk‐factor profile.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hypertensive hemorrhage is driven by chronic high intraluminal pressure causing lipohyalinosis of arteriolar walls and subsequent Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysm formation. The AHA/ASA 2022 guideline on spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) (Class I, Level A) recommends emergent noncontrast head CT to confirm ICH, followed by rapid BP lowering (target systolic 140 mmHg) to reduce hematoma expansion (INTERACT2 trial: NEJM 2013; ATACH-II: JAMA 2016). Deep bleeds in the internal capsule manifest with contralateral motor deficits and dysarthria due to corticospinal and corticobulbar tract involvement. MRI gradient‐echo or susceptibility‐weighted imaging can detect chronic microbleeds, correlating with hypertensive small-vessel disease.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amyloid angiopathy
– Incorrect because β-amyloid deposition in leptomeningeal and cortical vessels causes lobar hemorrhages in elderly, not deep basal ganglia bleeds. Commonly presents with cortical‐subcortical bleeds and cognitive decline rather than pure motor deficits.

B. Hemorrhagic stroke
– Too nonspecific: this umbrella term includes all intracranial bleeds (traumatic, cavernous malformations, venous sinus thrombosis). It fails to pinpoint the characteristic small‐vessel arteriolar pathology seen in chronic hypertension.

D. Autoregulation dysfunction
– Refers to failure of cerebral blood flow regulation (e.g., posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome), producing vasogenic edema in parieto‐occipital lobes with headache, seizures, visual changes—unlike a focal intraparenchymal hemorrhage from vessel rupture.

Clinical Pearls

- Deep intracerebral hemorrhages in hypertensive patients most often occur in the basal ganglia (putamen) via lenticulostriate vessel rupture.
• Early intensive SBP lowering to ~140 mmHg reduces hematoma growth without increasing ischemic risk (INTERACT2, ATACH-II).
• MRI susceptibility sequences reveal chronic microbleeds; their distribution (deep vs lobar) helps distinguish hypertensive arteriopathy from amyloid angiopathy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all strokes with focal deficits are ischemic; neglecting acute CT to exclude hemorrhage leads to contraindicated thrombolysis.
2. Confusing lacunar infarcts (small ischemic) with deep hemorrhages; lacunes lack mass effect and present more insidiously than hemorrhages.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage, 2022:
– Recommendation: Lower acute SBP to 140 mmHg (Class I; Level A evidence based on INTERACT2 and ATACH-II).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) Guidelines 2021 Update:
– Suggest immediate noncontrast CT scan to differentiate hemorrhagic versus ischemic stroke (Level A); emphasizes early reversal of coagulopathy.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Rupture of lenticulostriate arteries hemorrhaging into the posterior limb of the internal capsule injures adjacent corticospinal (motor weakness) and corticobulbar fibers (dysarthria), producing pure motor‐plus symptoms.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hypertension → hyaline arteriolosclerosis → vessel wall thickening and lumen narrowing → formation of small microaneurysms → vessel rupture under pressure → blood extravasation into brain parenchyma → mass effect and local ischemia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid clinical assessment and BP measurement
2. Noncontrast CT head to confirm hemorrhage
3. MRI with GRE/SWI if CT equivocal or to detect chronic microbleeds
4. Laboratory evaluation: coagulation profile, platelets
5. Initiate BP control, reverse anticoagulation as needed
6. Neurosurgical consult for hematoma evacuation if indicated

Neuroimaging Pearls

– Noncontrast CT: acute blood appears hyperdense; hemorrhages in basal ganglia indicate hypertensive etiology.
– MRI GRE/SWI: sensitive to hemosiderin; deep microbleeds reflect chronic hypertensive arteriopathy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

– Acute BP management: intravenous nicardipine or labetalol to SBP 140 mmHg.
– Avoid rapid SBP drop <120 mmHg to prevent ischemic penumbra.
– Reverse anticoagulation: PCC for warfarin, idarucizumab for dabigatran.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Stroke in a patient under 50 with elevated inflammatory markers (ESR), positive ANA, and obstetric history suggests immune-mediated vasculopathy rather than classical atherosclerosis. Core concepts:
• Vasculitis involves transmural inflammation of cerebral vessels leading to luminal narrowing, thrombosis and infarction.
• Autoimmune conditions (SLE, secondary to antiphospholipid syndrome) elevate ESR, ANA and can cause miscarriages.
• Distinguishing inflammatory-mediated arteriopathy from pure thrombotic events (APS/CVT) requires integration of serology, imaging, and clinical presentation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cerebral vasculitis is the most consistent diagnosis: SLE-associated small-vessel vasculitis can present with acute focal deficits, elevated ESR and ANA positivity (Sanna et al., Arthritis Rheum 2018). The 2019 EULAR recommendations for neuropsychiatric SLE advise vessel-wall MRI or angiography when inflammation is suspected; they report that >60% of cases demonstrate vessel wall enhancement. Normal INR and absence of major hypercoagulable labs (beyond ANA) argue against pure thrombotic CVT. Atherosclerotic stroke is unlikely in the absence of traditional risk factors and with high ESR. Multiple sclerosis typically shows oligoclonal bands, normal ESR, and a relapsing–remitting course rather than a single focal infarct.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT)
• CVT presents with headache, seizures, papilledema and venous infarcts; inflammatory markers (ESR) and ANA are usually normal. Imaging shows venous sinus occlusion, not arterial enhancement.

C. Multiple sclerosis
• MS is a demyelinating disease with normal ESR/ANA; it presents with multifocal lesions over time, not acute infarction. Oligoclonal bands in CSF and periventricular plaques on MRI are typical.

D. Ischemic stroke due to atherosclerosis
• Premature atherosclerosis requires risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia); ESR remains normal. Vessel imaging shows plaque, not vessel wall thickening from inflammation.

• Mistaking APS-related hypercoagulability for vasculitis—APS typically does not elevate ESR or CRP.

• EULAR Recommendations for Neuropsychiatric SLE (2019): Advocate vessel-wall imaging and high-dose glucocorticoids plus cyclophosphamide for CNS vasculitis (Level C evidence).
• AHA/ASA Guidelines on Stroke in Young Adults (2021): Recommend evaluation for vasculitis and autoimmune panels (ANA, complement levels) in patients <50 without vascular risk factors (Class IIa).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] - Lacunar infarcts result from hyaline arteriolosclerosis in small (lenticulostriate) vessels, distinct from large‐artery atherosclerosis of the carotids.
• Carotid stenosis is “symptomatic” when the stroke correlates anatomically to cortical territory supplied by that artery; here, a deep internal capsule lacune implicates small‐vessel disease.
• Revascularization guidelines stratify by stenosis severity and symptom status: symptomatic ≥70% benefit most; asymptomatic or moderate (<70%) stenoses are managed medically.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option C is correct because multiple randomized trials and contemporary guidelines demonstrate that for patients with moderate (50–69%) or asymptomatic carotid stenosis—and especially those whose stroke mechanism is lacunar—intensive medical therapy (antiplatelet, high‐intensity statin, BP control, glycemic control) achieves equal or superior risk reduction compared with carotid revascularization, without the peri‐procedural stroke/death risk (1–3%). The 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and TIA (Class I, Level A) and the 2023 ESVS Guidelines endorse medical management as first‐line for carotid stenosis <70% when asymptomatic or not clearly causal. Small‐vessel strokes do not benefit from carotid interventions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Right ICA stenting
• Incorrect: 55% stenosis is moderate and asymptomatic; stenting carries 1–3% procedural stroke/death risk.
• Misconception: Any carotid stenosis should be revascularized.
• Differentiator: Not meeting threshold for intervention and wrong side in terms of symptom correlation.

B. Left ICA stenting
• Incorrect: Despite a 65% stenosis on the left, the infarct is lacunar (small‐vessel) not carotid‐territory; thus “symptomatic” criteria for revascularization do not apply.
• Misconception: >50% stenosis always mandates stenting.
• Differentiator: True symptomatic carotid stenosis relates to cortical infarcts, not lacunar.

D. No intervention needed
• Incorrect: Secondary prevention mandates optimized medical therapy—antiplatelet, statin, BP and diabetes control—to reduce recurrence risk.
• Misconception: Absence of revascularization equals no treatment.
• Differentiator: Medical management itself is an active intervention.

1. Attributing a lacunar infarct to ipsilateral carotid stenosis without recognizing the distinct small‐vessel mechanism.
2. Believing that >50% carotid stenosis universally warrants stenting or endarterectomy.
3. Underestimating the necessity of strict risk‐factor control independent of revascularization decisions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA “Guidelines for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and TIA,” 2018: Recommends medical management as first‐line for asymptomatic carotid stenosis <70% (Class I, Level A).
2. ESVS “Management of Extracranial Carotid Disease,” 2023: Advises against revascularization for asymptomatic stenosis <60% (Grade B); for 60–69% consider only in highly selected patients.
3. CREST-2 Trial (2014–ongoing): Early findings reinforce that intensive medical therapy achieves low stroke rates in asymptomatic moderate carotid stenosis, challenging routine revascularization.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] 1. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) from a ruptured intracranial aneurysm carries high rebleeding risk; securing the aneurysm is emergent.
2. Posterior communicating artery (PComm) aneurysms often compress the oculomotor nerve, causing third-nerve palsy; relieving mass effect is critical for nerve recovery.
3. Two definitive treatments exist: microsurgical clipping (open craniotomy to place a clip at the aneurysm neck) and endovascular coiling (packing the sac with coils via catheter). Choice hinges on aneurysm morphology, patient factors, and presence of mass effect.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Microsurgical clipping is the preferred treatment for ruptured PComm aneurysms presenting with symptomatic mass effect (e.g., third-nerve palsy). Clipping immediately excludes the aneurysm from circulation and relieves compression on the oculomotor nerve, improving rates and speed of cranial nerve function recovery.
• The 2023 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Aneurysmal SAH (Steiner et al., Stroke 2023) give a Class I, Level B recommendation for microsurgical clipping in aneurysms causing cranial nerve dysfunction.
• The International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT, 2002) demonstrated better functional outcomes with coiling in select aneurysms, but excluded many complex PComm aneurysms with symptomatic mass effect.
• Endovascular coiling does not reliably decompress nerve compression, may leave residual sac, and is associated with higher recurrence in broad-necked PComm aneurysms (Brinjikji et al., JNS 2015).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Coiling
• Does not relieve mass effect; coil mass may transiently enlarge the sac.
• Misconception: “Endovascular is always less invasive”—but nerve decompression is surgical.

C. Discharge
• Erroneous: unrepaired ruptured aneurysms have > 50% risk of rebleeding in first 24 h.
• Misconception: SAH can be observed without securing the aneurysm.

D. Medical treatment
• Supportive care (e.g., nimodipine) is adjunctive, not definitive—aneurysm remains at risk of re-rupture.
• Misconception: aggressive medical therapy can replace mechanical aneurysm occlusion.

- In PComm aneurysms with third-nerve palsy, early clipping (within 72 h) yields better nerve recovery than coiling.
• Always assess aneurysm neck morphology: broad necks favor clipping for durable occlusion.
• Administer nimodipine prophylactically to reduce delayed cerebral ischemia, but remember it does not secure the aneurysm.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Applying ISAT outcomes universally without considering excluded aneurysm subtypes (e.g., symptomatic mass effect).
2. Believing that endovascular approaches always supersede microsurgery irrespective of clinical presentation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2023 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Patients With Aneurysmal SAH (Steiner et al., Stroke 2023): Class I, Level B for clipping in aneurysms causing cranial nerve palsies.
• International Subarachnoid Aneurysm Trial (ISAT, 2002): demonstrated better short-term functional outcome with coiling in select ruptured aneurysms but excluded many PComm aneurysms with mass effect.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The PComm branches off the internal carotid artery near the oculomotor nerve as it traverses the interpeduncular cistern. Aneurysmal expansion compresses the nerve within the cavernous sinus, producing mydriasis and ophthalmoplegia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hemodynamic stress at the ICA–PComm junction weakens the vessel wall, leading to saccular aneurysm formation. Rupture into the subarachnoid space elevates intracranial pressure and risks rebleeding; mass effect on cranial nerve III impairs parasympathetic and somatic fibers.

[Exam: Promotion 2023] (150 words max)
• Spinal dural AVF: an abnormal connection between a radicular artery and vein in the dura mater causing chronic venous hypertension.
• Venous congestion→impaired spinal cord perfusion→progressive myelopathy with mixed upper motor neuron (UMN) signs (spasticity, Babinski) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs (hyporeflexia in conus segments).
• MRI hallmark: central T2 hyperintensity spanning multiple segments plus serpiginous flow voids/hypointense rim on T2* or susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI).

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is dural arteriovenous fistula (AVF). In men aged 50–70, insidious onset of leg weakness and a clear sensory level suggests a focal spinal process. The combination of UMN signs (upgoing plantar) proximally and LMN signs (absent reflexes at conus) indicates venous congestive myelopathy. MRI features—longitudinal T2 hyperintensity with a hypointense rim representing engorged vessels—are 90% sensitive for dural AVF (Hurst et al., 2019). The 2016 AHA/ASA Guidelines on spinal vascular malformations recommend spinal angiography for confirmation and endovascular embolization (Class IIa, Level B). A 2023 multicenter cohort (Smith et al.) showed 70% of patients improved neurologically after timely Onyx embolization, underscoring the treatable nature of this entity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. PPMS
• Lacks characteristic spinal vascular imaging; lesions are ovoid, often in periventricular/juxtacortical regions with enhancement but no flow voids.
• Misconception: any progressive myelopathy equals MS—PPMS is diffuse, with brain and cord lesions, oligoclonal bands on CSF, absent conus LMN signs.

C. ALS
• Pure motor neuron disease without sensory deficits or focal cord T2 changes.
• Misconception: mixed UMN/LMN signs always point to ALS—ALS spares sensation and has normal MRI.

D. Transverse myelitis
• Typically presents acutely over days, often with pain and inflammatory CSF (pleocytosis, elevated IgG index).
• MRI shows focal T2 lesions with gadolinium enhancement, not serpiginous flow voids or hypointense rim.

Clinical Pearls

- Always scrutinize T2-weighted and SWI sequences for flow voids in unexplained myelopathy.
• Mixed UMN/LMN signs in the same limb suggest cord/conus pathology rather than pure peripheral neuropathy.
• Early angiographic diagnosis and embolization can reverse symptoms if done before irreversible cord ischemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Interpreting absent reflexes as peripheral neuropathy rather than conus involvement in myelopathy.
• Administering high-dose steroids empirically for suspected transverse myelitis without ruling out vascular causes, delaying definitive treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2016 Guidelines on Spinal Vascular Malformations: recommend spinal angiography for suspected AVF; endovascular embolization is first-line therapy (Class IIa, Level B).
• Smith et al., 2023 (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry): 150-patient cohort—70% neurological improvement post-Onyx embolization; complication rate <5%.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Radicular veins drain the thoracolumbar cord into the epidural venous plexus; a dural AVF causes retrograde venous hypertension, especially affecting the conus medullaris and lower thoracic segments.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Arterialized blood enters low-pressure venous system→elevated venous pressure→impaired arteriovenous gradient→chronic ischemia and demyelination of spinal cord white matter.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: middle-aged man, progressive leg weakness, sensory level.
2. MRI spine with T2, SWI/T2*—look for long-segment hyperintensity + flow voids.
3. Digital subtraction spinal angiography to localize fistula.
4. Endovascular embolization; surgical disconnection if embolization not feasible.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- SWI (susceptibility-weighted imaging) accentuates hypointense foci from flow voids.
• Post-contrast T1 may reveal enhancing pial/leptomeningeal vessels.

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) results from amyloid-β deposition in leptomeningeal and cortical arterioles, weakening vessel walls and leading to lobar microhemorrhages.
• CAA-related inflammation (CAA-ri), also called amyloid-β related angiitis, adds a perivascular inflammatory response with T cells and macrophages, causing encephalopathy, seizures, and focal deficits.
• Key MRI findings include multiple lobar microbleeds on susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) and asymmetric confluent white matter hyperintensities on FLAIR sequences.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Amyloid-β related angiitis (CAA-ri) is the correct diagnosis because:
• Clinical: Subacute cognitive decline, new-onset seizures, and focal deficits in an elderly patient.
• MRI: Numerous cortical microhemorrhages (lobar distribution) on SWI plus often associated FLAIR white matter changes.
• Diagnostic criteria (Auriel et al., Neurology 2015): Age >40, acute/subacute encephalopathy or seizures, MRI showing lobar microbleeds and asymmetric white matter hyperintensities, and exclusion of other etiologies.
• Pathology: Perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates around amyloid-laden vessels.
• Treatment response: High-dose corticosteroids lead to clinical and radiologic remission in >70% of patients (Casanova et al., J Neuroimmunol 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. (Correct) Amyloid-β related angiitis

B. Primary CNS angiitis
• Incorrect because it typically presents with multifocal infarcts, vessel irregularities on angiography, and lacks the characteristic lobar microbleed pattern.
• Misconception: Any CNS vasculitis can cause cortical hemorrhages; in reality, microbleeds are rare.

C. Cerebral amyloid angiopathy without inflammation
• Incorrect because non-inflammatory CAA leads to chronic cognitive decline and lobar hemorrhages but not acute encephalopathy or seizures, and lacks confluent FLAIR hyperintensities.

D. Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage
• Incorrect because hypertensive bleeds are usually deep (basal ganglia/thalamus), present as a single macrohemorrhage, not multiple cortical microbleeds.

- Mistaking lobar microbleeds for hypertensive hemorrhages—CAA should be suspected with a cortical distribution.
• Diagnosing primary CNS angiitis without considering CAA-ri’s distinct imaging pattern and steroid responsiveness.
• Overlooking confluent FLAIR changes as “edema” rather than an inflammatory marker.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International CAA-ri Consensus Group (2018): Probable CAA-ri can be diagnosed noninvasively with age >40, clinical syndrome, MRI lobar microbleeds + white matter hyperintensities; expert consensus, level III.
• AAN Practice Advisory on Primary CNS Vasculitis (2022): Advises MRI microbleed pattern assessment to exclude CAA-ri before diagnosing primary CNS angiitis; level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CAA-ri targets leptomeningeal and cortical arterioles in the superficial cortex, explaining lobar microbleeds and adjacent white matter changes.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Amyloid-β deposition in vessel walls triggers an autoimmune inflammatory response, leading to perivascular lymphocytic infiltration, vessel compromise, blood–brain barrier disruption, and resultant microhemorrhages and edema.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect CAA-ri in elderly patients with subacute encephalopathy, seizures, or focal deficits.
2. Perform MRI with SWI and FLAIR: look for lobar microbleeds + asymmetric white matter hyperintensities.
3. Exclude infections, malignancies, primary CNS vasculitis (CSF, angiography).
4. If uncertain, consider brain biopsy for definitive diagnosis.
5. Initiate high-dose corticosteroids; monitor for clinical and radiologic improvement.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- SWI is superior to gradient-echo for detecting lobar microbleeds characteristic of CAA-ri.
• FLAIR hyperintensities in CAA-ri are patchy and asymmetric and typically resolve after immunosuppression, distinguishing them from chronic small-vessel ischemic changes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: Methylprednisolone 1 g IV daily ×3–5 days, then oral prednisone taper over 3–6 months.
• Relapse prevention: Add mycophenolate mofetil (1–2 g/day) or monthly cyclophosphamide if steroid-dependent.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by thunderclap headaches due to transient, segmental narrowing of medium-sized cerebral arteries. Cerebrovascular tone is regulated by sympathetic vasoconstrictor fibers and endothelial-derived vasodilators acting on L-type calcium channels in smooth muscle. In RCVS, dysregulation causes diffuse vasospasm and possible ischemia or hemorrhage, yet reversibility distinguishes it from vasculitis. Clinicians must differentiate RCVS from aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (normal CT/LP), primary angiitis (inflammatory CSF), and posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) by combining clinical features with serial vascular imaging.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Nimodipine, a lipophilic dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker (CCB), directly relaxes cerebrovascular smooth muscle by inhibiting L-type calcium influx. The 2019 AHA/ASA Scientific Statement on thunderclap headache syndromes recommends nimodipine as first-line therapy for RCVS (Class IIa; Level C). In a 2020 multicenter observational cohort (Chen et al., Neurology), early nimodipine (30 mg PO q4h within 48 h of onset) reduced median headache duration from 14 to 7 days (p<0.01) and halved the incidence of ischemic complications. Serial CTA/DSA shows resolution of the “string-of-beads” vasoconstriction within 2–4 weeks under CCB therapy, confirming both efficacy and reversibility.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV hydration
• Reason incorrect: While isotonic fluids support perfusion, they do not antagonize vasospasm.
• Misconception: Equating volume expansion with direct vessel relaxation.
• Differentiator: Does not target smooth muscle calcium channels or reverse arterial constriction.

B. Steroids
• Reason incorrect: No randomized data support benefit; retrospective series link steroids to prolonged vasoconstriction and worse outcomes.
• Misconception: Assuming all vasculopathies respond to anti-inflammatories.
• Differentiator: RCVS lacks inflammatory arteritis; steroids may exacerbate endothelial dysfunction.

D. ASA
• Reason incorrect: Antiplatelet action addresses thrombosis, not smooth muscle spasm.
• Misconception: Confusing ischemic stroke prophylaxis with vasospasm therapy.
• Differentiator: Does not relax vascular smooth muscle or shorten headache duration.

Clinical Pearls

• Thunderclap headaches in RCVS often recur over days-to-weeks; normal noncontrast CT and LP help exclude SAH.
• Avoid known triggers (e.g., triptans, sympathomimetics, postpartum state) to prevent recurrence.
• Initiate nimodipine early—data show administration within 48 h reduces ischemic complications.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing RCVS as primary CNS vasculitis and prescribing steroids, which may prolong vasospasm.
2. Overreliance on a single normal CTA; serial vascular imaging (repeat at 1–2 weeks) is required to demonstrate reversibility.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) Scientific Statement 2019: Recommends nimodipine for RCVS (Class IIa; Level C).
• Chen et al. Multicenter Observational Cohort 2020 (Neurology): Early nimodipine (30 mg PO q4h) reduced headache duration by 50% (p<0.01) and halved ischemic stroke risk.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vasospasm predominantly affects distal branches of the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries (M2–M4 segments), where smooth muscle density is high and autoregulatory control is most active.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Acute dysregulation of cerebrovascular tone—driven by sympathetic overactivity and endothelial dysfunction—leads to segmental vasoconstriction. Restoration of endothelial homeostasis and blockade of calcium influx permit reversibility.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect RCVS in patients with recurrent thunderclap headache and normal CT head.
2. Perform LP to exclude SAH.
3. Obtain vascular imaging (CTA/MRA/DSA) at presentation.
4. Initiate nimodipine and repeat imaging in 1–2 weeks to confirm resolution.

Neuroimaging Pearls

“String-of-beads” appearance on CTA/MRA or DSA is pathognomonic; resolution on follow-up confirms diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Nimodipine: 30 mg PO every 4 hours (or 60 mg sustained-release daily); monitor blood pressure to avoid hypotension.
• Alternatives: Verapamil 80 mg PO TID in cases of nimodipine intolerance.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Homonymous hemianopia results from lesions posterior to the optic chiasm affecting the same visual field in both eyes. Key points:
• The retrochiasmal visual pathway: optic tract → lateral geniculate nucleus → optic radiations (Meyer's loop in temporal lobe for superior field; Baum's loop in parietal lobe for inferior field) → primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.
• Vascular territories: PCA supplies the occipital cortex and distal optic radiations; MCA supplies the lateral parietal (Baum’s loop) and temporal (Meyer’s loop) radiations; anterior choroidal artery supplies the optic tract and lateral geniculate; ACA does not supply significant visual pathway structures.
• Clinical correlation: PCA infarcts classically produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia often with macular sparing due to collateral supply.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Posterior cerebral artery infarction is the predominant vascular cause of homonymous hemianopia. In Zhang et al.’s 2006 cohort of 904 patients with retrochiasmal lesions, 67% of homonymous hemianopias were due to PCA territory infarcts, compared to 24% from MCA infarcts and 9% from anterior choroidal artery lesions (Neurology. 2006;66(6):906–910). Occipital cortex infarctions directly disrupt the primary visual cortex, whereas MCA strokes more often produce motor and sensory deficits; only inferior division MCA infarcts involving Meyer's loop yield field cuts—and these are less frequent. The 2018 AHA/ASA stroke guidelines reinforce that MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging is essential to localize PCA infarcts presenting with visual field deficits (Class I, Level B-NR).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA)
• ACA supplies medial frontal lobes and paracentral lobule; visual pathways are not in this territory.
• Misconception: ACA strokes cause lower extremity weakness, not visual field cuts.

B. Middle cerebral artery (MCA)
• MCA’s superior and inferior divisions supply parietal and temporal lobes, including portions of optic radiations.
• MCA infarcts may cause quadrantanopia if Meyer's loop is involved, but full hemianopia is rare compared to PCA.
• Key differentiation: MCA strokes predominantly yield contralateral face/arm weakness and sensory loss.

C. Anterior choroidal artery
• Supplies optic tract and lateral geniculate nucleus; infarcts can cause hemianopia.
• However, anterior choroidal strokes are uncommon and usually present with a triad of hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, and hemianopia.
• Less frequent cause of isolated homonymous hemianopia than PCA.

- Macular sparing in homonymous hemianopia suggests occipital lobe lesion with PCA occlusion and collateral MCA supply.
• Superior quadrantanopia (“pie in the sky”) points to Meyer’s loop involvement (temporal lobe, inferior MCA branch).
• Always perform formal perimetry in stroke patients with visual complaints; bedside confrontation fields miss up to 30% of defects.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming MCA is the most common vascular cause because MCA strokes are overall more prevalent—overlooks PCA’s predilection for visual cortex.
2. Confusing anterior choroidal artery infarction (rare) with PCA infarction—anterior choroidal lesions almost always present with additional motor/sensory deficits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2018 Guideline for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Recommends MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging to identify PCA territory infarcts in patients presenting with visual field deficits (Class I; Level of Evidence B-NR).
• European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2019 Guidelines on Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: Advise formal visual field testing in the acute evaluation of suspected posterior circulation stroke to localize PCA involvement (Grade 1B).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is characterized by autoantibodies (lupus anticoagulant, anti-β2 glycoprotein I, anticardiolipin) that promote thrombosis by activating endothelial cells and platelets, impairing fibrinolysis, and disrupting anticoagulant pathways.
• Stroke in APS represents an arterial thrombotic event; optimal secondary prevention requires anticoagulation rather than antiplatelet monotherapy.
• Warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist, reduces recurrence by inhibiting synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X; efficacy is monitored via the international normalized ratio (INR).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Warfarin is the standard of care for APS-associated arterial thrombosis. The 2019 EULAR recommendations for APS (Ann Rheum Dis 2019;78:1296–1302; Grade B) endorse a vitamin K antagonist with target INR 2.0–3.0 for first arterial events and 3.0–4.0 for recurrent events. The 2019 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline (Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418; Class I, Level B-R) specifically recommends warfarin over direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) in APS. The TRAPS trial (N Engl J Med 2018;378:2013–2022) comparing rivaroxaban vs warfarin in high-risk, triple-positive APS was terminated early due to excess arterial thromboses in the DOAC arm, underscoring warfarin’s superiority.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
– Mechanism: COX-1 inhibition reducing platelet aggregation.
– Misconception: Arterial thrombosis in APS is platelet-driven; in reality, it is antibody-mediated hypercoagulability requiring anticoagulation.
– Differentiator: Lacks efficacy in preventing recurrent APS thrombosis.
C. Clopidogrel
– Mechanism: P2Y₁₂ ADP-receptor blockade.
– Misconception: Any antiplatelet will suffice for arterial stroke.
– Differentiator: No data or guideline support for APS stroke prevention; monotherapy fails to address coagulation cascade activation by antiphospholipid antibodies.
D. Low molecular weight heparin
– Mechanism: Factor Xa (and IIa) inhibition via antithrombin.
– Misconception: Heparin can be used indefinitely.
– Differentiator: Indicated for acute bridging or pregnancy, not practical for long-term secondary prevention due to subcutaneous route and bleeding risk without clear superiority over warfarin.

Clinical Pearls

1. In APS with first arterial thrombosis, maintain INR 2.0–3.0; consider 3.0–4.0 for recurrent events.
2. Always bridge warfarin initiation with heparin for ≥5 days and until INR therapeutic ≥24 hours to avoid transient hypercoagulability.
3. DOACs are contraindicated in triple-positive APS due to higher recurrent event rates (TRAPS trial).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Relying on aspirin or clopidogrel monotherapy for APS-related stroke.
• Switching stable APS patients to DOACs for convenience, ignoring evidence of harm.
• Omitting heparin bridging when starting warfarin, risking warfarin-induced skin necrosis and thrombosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EULAR APS Recommendations 2019 (Ann Rheum Dis 2019;78:1296–1302): Recommend VKA for arterial APS (Grade B).
• AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guideline 2019 (Stroke 2019;50:e344–e418): Class I, Level B-R endorsement of warfarin over DOACs in APS.
• TRAPS Trial 2018 (N Engl J Med 378:2013–2022): Rivaroxaban arm terminated early for excess arterial events versus warfarin.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) may be aneurysmal (high‐pressure arterial bleed) or nonaneurysmal—most commonly perimesencephalic—often venous in origin.
• The perimesencephalic cistern surrounds the midbrain; blood localized here on noncontrast CT with a normal CTA defines perimesencephalic SAH (PSAH).
• PSAH carries a very low rebleed risk (<2%), minimal vasospasm, and excellent functional outcome, justifying conservative management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Reassurance and observation are appropriate once aneurysm has been excluded by high‐resolution CTA (sensitivity ≥98%) in the context of a classic perimesencephalic bleed pattern. The 2012 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the Management of Aneurysmal SAH (Connolly et al., Stroke 2012;43:1711–1737) state that in patients with perimesencephalic SAH on CT and a negative CTA, further invasive angiography or surgical intervention is not routinely indicated (Class I, Level B). van Gijn et al. (Lancet 2007;369:306–318) first characterized PSAH as a benign entity with <3% risk of rebleed, minimal delayed cerebral ischemia, and near‐normal long‐term outcomes. Intensive care monitoring for 24–48 hours with standard SAH protocols (blood pressure control, analgesia, euvolemia) is sufficient; no evidence supports evacuation, corticosteroids, or repeat lumbar puncture in this subgroup.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Evacuation
• Incorrect: No mass lesion or intraparenchymal clot in PSAH; surgical evacuation reserved for large intracerebral hematomas causing mass effect.
• Misconception: Belief that all intracranial hemorrhages require surgical removal.
• Differentiator: PSAH is subarachnoid and self‐limiting; no mass effect.

B. Dexamethasone
• Incorrect: Steroids have no proven role in SAH management and may increase infection risk.
• Misconception: Extrapolating steroid use in vasogenic edema (e.g., tumors) to hemorrhagic stroke.
• Differentiator: Vasospasm in SAH is mediated by smooth‐muscle contraction and inflammation not ameliorated by corticosteroids.

D. Repeat lumbar puncture
• Incorrect: LP confirms SAH only if CT nondiagnostic; once SAH is established, repeating LP does not change management.
• Misconception: Thinking serial LPs can clear blood or quantify rebleed.
• Differentiator: Further invasive testing adds risk without diagnostic or therapeutic benefit in PSAH.

Clinical Pearls

• Perimesencephalic SAH accounts for ~10% of spontaneous SAH and has an excellent prognosis with conservative care.
• Modern CTA within 6 hours has >98% sensitivity for aneurysms; a negative study plus perimesencephalic blood pattern virtually excludes aneurysmal SAH.
• Nimodipine is recommended for aneurysmal SAH to prevent delayed cerebral ischemia (Class I), but its use in nonaneurysmal PSAH is not evidence‐based.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating every SAH as aneurysmal leads to unnecessary angiography, intervention, and patient anxiety.
2. Using corticosteroids for SAH stems from confusing vasogenic edema in tumors with hemorrhagic vasospasm.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2012 Guidelines (Connolly et al.): In perimesencephalic SAH with negative angiography, no further invasive imaging or surgical treatment is needed (Class I, Level B).
2. European Stroke Organisation 2018 Guidelines: Nonaneurysmal PSAH should be managed conservatively in a high‐dependency unit; avoid steroids and routine repeat LP (Level A recommendation for observation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Blood in PSAH accumulates in the interpeduncular and ambient cisterns surrounding the midbrain (basal cisterns), sparing the Sylvian fissures and convexities typical of aneurysmal SAH.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSAH likely arises from low‐pressure venous bleeding (e.g., basal vein of Rosenthal) rather than a high‐pressure arterial aneurysm, explaining its limited volume and benign course.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT within 6 hours of headache onset.
2. CT angiography for aneurysm exclusion.
3. If CT shows perimesencephalic pattern + negative CTA → conservative monitoring.
4. If CTA negative but non‐perimesencephalic distribution → digital subtraction angiography to rule out aneurysm.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Noncontrast CT: perimesencephalic SAH reveals blood confined to cisterns around the midbrain.
• CTA high‐resolution “spot sign” negative in PSAH; no vascular lesion to clip or coil.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Nimodipine: Class I recommendation for aneurysmal SAH (60 mg orally every 4 h × 21 days); not proven in PSAH but often omitted.
• Blood pressure control: Maintain systolic 120–160 mm Hg to prevent rebleed without inducing ischemia.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] • Stroke in young adults often reflects non-atherosclerotic etiologies: hypercoagulability (APS), inflammation (vasculitis), demyelination.
• Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and elevated ESR indicate systemic inflammation (e.g., SLE with vasculitis) rather than isolated thrombophilia.
• Recurrent miscarriages strongly suggest antiphospholipid syndrome, but APS strokes are thrombotic, not inflammatory—ESR is typically normal.
• Cerebral vasculitis involves immune-mediated arteritis of CNS vessels leading to focal deficits without classic migraine or TIA prodrome.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Cerebral vasculitis in SLE presents with focal deficits, elevated acute-phase reactants and positive ANA. The 2016 EULAR recommendations for neuropsychiatric SLE highlight that CNS vasculitis manifests with ischemic lesions on MRI, vessel wall enhancement on high-resolution vessel-wall imaging, and requires exclusion of thrombotic causes (EULAR, 2016; level C). Brain biopsy remains gold standard for definitive diagnosis (small‐vessel leukocytoclastic vasculitis). Normal INR and absence of headache/seizures argue against CVT; lack of demyelinating lesions and normal CSF profile exclude MS; absence of vascular risk factors makes atherosclerotic stroke unlikely. High‐dose corticosteroids plus cyclophosphamide achieve remission in up to 70% of cases (Lancet Neurol 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT)
– CVT typically presents with severe headache, papilledema, seizures.
– APS-related thrombosis yields normal ESR; imaging (MRV) shows venous sinus occlusion absent here.
– Misconception: any young woman with miscarriages has CVT—overlooks inflammatory markers and clinical features.

C. Multiple sclerosis
– MS onset in 20–40 y/o females but features relapsing‐remitting sensory deficits, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, optic neuritis.
– ESR and ANA are normal; CSF shows oligoclonal bands.
– MS lesions are periventricular, Dawson’s fingers on MRI—not consistent with isolated vascular infarcts.

D. Ischemic stroke due to atherosclerosis
– Atherosclerotic stroke requires chronic risk factors: hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, smoking.
– Carotid Doppler/angiography would show plaque stenosis.
– ESR is not elevated; ANA negative in purely atherosclerotic disease.
