Clinical Pearls

1. Left ventricular or atrial thrombus detected on echo mandates anticoagulation (INR 2–3) for at least 3 months, with repeat imaging to confirm thrombus resolution.
2. DOACs are first-line for nonvalvular AF but remain off-label for ventricular thrombi; consider them only in warfarin contraindications.
3. Always differentiate between platelet-rich “white” clots (arterial) and fibrin-rich “red” clots (cardioembolic) when choosing antithrombotic therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Initiating aspirin or clopidogrel instead of anticoagulation in cardioembolic stroke—a key error that leaves patients at high risk for recurrence.
2. Assuming DOAC approval for all cardioembolic sources; only atrial fibrillation without mechanical valves or moderate-to-severe mitral stenosis has strong trial support.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA 2021 Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines: Strong recommendation (Class I, Level A) for warfarin (INR 2.0–3.0) in patients with left ventricular thrombus post-MI or cardiomyopathy.
• European Stroke Organisation 2022 Guidelines: Echo-detected cardiac thrombus requires anticoagulation; DOACs may be considered when warfarin is contraindicated (Grade 2C).
• Robinson et al., Stroke 2023 (Meta-analysis): Comparable thrombus resolution rates between rivaroxaban and warfarin cohorts (n=512), but lacked randomized design and long-term outcome data.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Warfarin: inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase → decreases clotting factors II, VII, IX, X.
• Dosing: adjust by INR; initial overlap with heparin in acute setting until INR therapeutic for two consecutive days.
• Monitoring: monthly INR once stable; dietary vitamin K interactions require close follow-up.
• Bleeding risk mitigation: maintain INR ≤3.0; consider patient-specific factors (age, renal function).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] - Lysosomal storage disorders result from inherited enzyme defects causing substrate accumulation and cellular dysfunction.
• Fabry disease is an X-linked recessive disorder due to GLA gene mutations encoding alpha-galactosidase A; enzyme deficiency leads to globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) buildup in vascular endothelium, renal, cardiac, and nervous system cells.
• Classic clinical features include angiokeratomas—telangiectatic papules in a “bathing-trunk” distribution—and early-onset stroke from cerebrovascular endothelial Gb3 deposition.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Fabry disease originates from pathogenic GLA gene variants that abolish alpha-galactosidase A activity, causing lysosomal Gb3 accumulation (Germain DP et al. N Engl J Med. 2016). Endothelial Gb3 deposition disrupts nitric oxide–mediated vasodilation and triggers inflammation, elevating stroke risk. Diagnostic guidelines advise measuring plasma or leukocyte alpha-galactosidase A activity in males, with confirmatory GLA sequencing for all suspected cases (Ortiz A et al. Mol Genet Metab. 2018). Randomized trials have demonstrated that enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with agalsidase alfa (0.2 mg/kg) and agalsidase beta (1 mg/kg biweekly) clears Gb3 deposits, relieves neuropathic pain, and slows renal decline (Schiffmann R et al. JAMA. 2001; Banikazemi M et al. Circulation. 2007). For patients with amenable GLA mutations, the oral chaperone Migalastat stabilizes mutant enzyme and reduces substrate accumulation in the Phase III FACETS trial (Germain DP et al. N Engl J Med. 2016). Early recognition via angiokeratomas permits prompt therapy, improving morbidity and mortality.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Glucocerebrosidase
Deficiency of glucocerebrosidase (GBA gene) causes Gaucher disease, characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, bone crises, and cytopenias; angiokeratomas and stroke are not features.

C. Hexosaminidase A
Hexosaminidase A (HEXA gene) deficiency leads to Tay-Sachs disease, presenting with infantile neurodegeneration and cherry-red macula; it lacks vascular skin lesions or adult-onset strokes.

D. Sphingomyelinase
Acid sphingomyelinase (SMPD1 gene) deficiency causes Niemann-Pick A/B disease, featuring hepatosplenomegaly, foam cells, and neurodegeneration without angiokeratomas or cerebrovascular events.

- Angiokeratomas commonly cluster between the umbilicus and knees; their presence in a young male with acroparesthesias is pathognomonic for Fabry disease.
• Female carriers can exhibit symptoms due to random X-inactivation; normal enzyme levels do not exclude disease—genetic testing is essential.
• Initiate ERT early (agalsidase alfa 0.2 mg/kg or beta 1 mg/kg biweekly) before irreversible organ damage occurs.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misidentifying angiokeratomas as petechiae or purpura, delaying diagnosis of a systemic disorder.
2. Believing all glycosphingolipid storage diseases are autosomal recessive; Fabry’s X-linked inheritance demands carrier screening in female relatives.
3. Overlooking stroke in young adults as a presentation of Fabry disease, attributing it solely to conventional vascular risk factors.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Fabry Working Group Consensus Recommendations. Mol Genet Metab. 2018.
• Initiate ERT (agalsidase alfa or beta) in classic male patients and symptomatic heterozygous females to reduce Gb3 deposition and prevent organ damage.
• Level of Evidence: V (expert consensus).

2. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Technology Appraisal TA425. 2017.
• Recommends agalsidase alfa and beta as first-line therapy for adults with confirmed Fabry disease and organ involvement.
• Level of Evidence: Expert committee consensus.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

GLA gene mutations reduce alpha-galactosidase A activity, leading to Gb3 and lyso-Gb3 accumulation in lysosomes. Endothelial Gb3 promotes oxidative stress, impairs nitric oxide production, and incites inflammation, causing microvascular dysfunction and stroke. Gb3 in dorsal root ganglia induces small-fiber neuropathy and acroparesthesias; renal podocyte deposition leads to proteinuria and progressive renal failure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize clinical features: angiokeratomas, acroparesthesias, early stroke.
2. Measure plasma or leukocyte alpha-galactosidase A activity (males).
3. Perform GLA gene sequencing for confirmation and in female carriers.
4. Baseline organ assessment: renal (GFR, proteinuria), cardiac MRI, brain MRI.
5. Screen at-risk family members with enzymatic and genetic tests.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Enzyme Replacement Therapy
• Agalsidase alfa: 0.2 mg/kg IV biweekly
• Agalsidase beta: 1 mg/kg IV biweekly
• Pharmacological Chaperone
• Migalastat: 123 mg orally every other day for amenable GLA mutations; stabilizes mutant alpha-galactosidase A for lysosomal trafficking.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] CADASIL (cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy) is a hereditary small vessel disease caused by NOTCH3 mutations leading to degeneration of vascular smooth muscle cells and deposition of granular osmiophilic material (GOM) in arterial walls. Clinical hallmarks include migraine with aura in 30–40% of patients, recurrent subcortical ischemic events in mid-adulthood, progressive cognitive decline, and psychiatric disturbances. Neuroimaging typically shows extensive white matter hyperintensities, especially in the anterior temporal lobes and external capsules. Definitive diagnosis requires identification of pathogenic NOTCH3 variants, whereas biopsy or imaging alone lacks sufficient sensitivity or specificity. Understanding the genetic basis, vascular pathology, and MRI patterns is essential for timely diagnosis and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Genetic testing for NOTCH3 mutations is the gold standard for diagnosing CADASIL. Pathogenic variants cluster in exons 2–24 encoding epidermal growth factor–like repeats; altering cysteine residues leads to GOM deposition (Jouvent et al., Lancet Neurol 2007). Sensitivity and specificity exceed 95% when combined with clinical and radiological criteria (Rutten et al., Neurology 2016). Skin biopsy for GOM has variable sensitivity (50–85%) and requires electron microscopy with specialized pathological expertise (Markus et al., Brain 2002). MRI findings—bilateral confluent white matter hyperintensities in anterior temporal poles and external capsules—are highly characteristic but overlap with sporadic leukoaraiosis or multiple sclerosis. CSF analysis is non-diagnostic. Both the 2017 European Stroke Organization guidelines (Class I, Level B) and the 2018 AHA/ASA scientific statement (Class I, Level C) recommend NOTCH3 genetic testing as the first-line diagnostic modality in suspected CADASIL.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Brain MRI showing white matter hyperintensities
• Incorrect because MRI patterns, though suggestive, are not pathognomonic and can be seen in sporadic small vessel disease or demyelinating disorders.
• Misconception: assuming radiological specificity without confirmatory testing.
• Differentiator: MRI is supportive but requires genetic confirmation.

B. Skin biopsy demonstrating granular osmiophilic material
• Incorrect as first-line: GOM detection sensitivity is operator- and site-dependent (50–85%); false negatives occur.
• Misconception: invasive biopsy supersedes non-invasive genetic testing.
• Differentiator: reserved for inconclusive genetic results.

D. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis
• Incorrect: CSF findings (mild protein elevation, rare oligoclonal bands) are non-specific and do not establish CADASIL.
• Misconception: equating CADASIL with inflammatory CNS diseases requiring CSF profiling.
• Differentiator: CSF is useful in MS workup, not CADASIL.

- White matter hyperintensities in the anterior temporal poles occur in >90% of CADASIL and are rare in sporadic small vessel disease.
• An autosomal dominant family history of early-onset strokes or cognitive decline is present in >85% of CADASIL cases.
• Routine anticoagulation for lacunar strokes in CADASIL may increase hemorrhagic risk and is not generally indicated.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over-reliance on MRI: Mistaking non-specific leukoaraiosis for CADASIL without confirmatory genetics.
2. Biopsy-first approach: Ordering skin biopsy prematurely, risking false negatives and procedural morbidity.
3. Migraine-negative cases: Failing to consider CADASIL in patients without migraine aura despite stroke and leukoencephalopathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Stroke Organization (ESO) guidelines on rare cerebrovascular diseases (2017): Recommend NOTCH3 genetic testing as first-line in suspected CADASIL (Class I, Level B).
2. AHA/ASA scientific statement on hereditary stroke syndromes (2018): Endorse genetic analysis for NOTCH3 mutations in clinical scenarios with migraine with aura and characteristic MRI changes (Class I, Level C).
3. Rutten et al., Neurology (2020): Demonstrated that next-generation sequencing panels increased diagnostic yield by 15% over traditional Sanger sequencing in CADASIL cohorts.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CADASIL affects small penetrating arterioles supplying deep white matter—including periventricular regions, centrum semiovale, anterior temporal lobes, and external capsules—leading to chronic hypoperfusion, lacunar infarcts in basal ganglia, thalamus, and pons, and consequent subcortical cognitive and motor deficits.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

NOTCH3 mutations cause an odd number of cysteine residues in epidermal growth factor–like repeats, resulting in misfolded extracellular domain fragments that accumulate as GOM in vascular smooth muscle cell basement membranes. Progressive VSMC degeneration and luminal narrowing produce chronic cerebral hypoperfusion, triggering demyelination, gliosis, and lacunar infarcts.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify clinical triad: migraine with aura, subcortical strokes, cognitive decline.
2. Obtain brain MRI: assess anterior temporal pole and external capsule WMH.
3. Review family history for autosomal dominant inheritance.
4. Perform NOTCH3 genetic testing (exons 2–24).
5. If genetic testing is negative or inconclusive, proceed to skin biopsy with electron microscopy for GOM.
6. Provide genetic counseling and cascade testing.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Anterior temporal pole involvement on T2/FLAIR is >90% specific for CADASIL.
• Susceptibility-weighted imaging often reveals cerebral microbleeds in up to 70% of patients, indicating hemorrhagic vulnerability.
• Lacunes in basal ganglia, thalamus, and pons are early markers of subcortical infarction.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. CADASIL is frequently tested as a clinical vignette emphasizing the distinction between supportive MRI findings and definitive genetic testing; boards often assess recognition of anterior temporal lobe WMH and the role of NOTCH3 analysis as the diagnostic gold standard.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] - Cardioembolic stroke results from thrombus formation in the left atrium or appendage during atrial fibrillation (AF), due to stasis and hypercoagulability.
• Nonvalvular AF (absence of rheumatic mitral stenosis, mechanical heart valve, or mitral valve repair) carries high embolic risk quantified by CHA₂DS₂-VASc score.
• Anticoagulation reduces stroke risk by inhibiting key factors in the coagulation cascade; direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs), including Factor Xa inhibitors, directly target activated Factor X without need for routine monitoring.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Direct oral Factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban) are now first-line for secondary stroke prevention in nonvalvular AF. The 2019 AHA/ASA guideline (Class I, Level A) and the 2020 ESC AF guideline recommend DOACs over warfarin owing to:
• Comparable or superior efficacy: ARISTOTLE trial (apixaban vs warfarin) showed 21% relative risk reduction in stroke/systemic embolism (HR 0.79; 95% CI 0.66–0.95; p = 0.01).
• Lower intracranial hemorrhage rates (0.33% vs 0.80% per year).
• Fewer drug–food interactions and no routine INR checks.
Thus, a Factor X inhibitor is the optimal agent for this patient.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin
• Incorrect: Antiplatelet therapy alone reduces stroke risk by only ~20% in AF, far inferior to anticoagulation.
• Misconception: Treating AF-related stroke as atherosclerotic rather than cardioembolic.
• Differentiator: Does not inhibit coagulation cascade at the site of thrombus generation in the atrium.

B. Warfarin
• Incorrect: Although effective (relative risk reduction ~64%), warfarin requires frequent INR monitoring, dietary restrictions, and has variable pharmacokinetics.
• Misconception: Warfarin is the universal gold standard—overlooked by current preference for DOACs in nonvalvular AF.
• Differentiator: DOACs have superior safety (lower intracranial hemorrhage) and similar or superior efficacy.

D. Clopidogrel
• Incorrect: Single‐agent P2Y₁₂ inhibition is inadequate for stroke prevention in AF (no direct anticoagulant effect).
• Misconception: Dual antiplatelet regimens or P2Y₁₂ blockers suffice for cardioembolic risk.
• Differentiator: Antiplatelet drugs target platelet aggregation, not fibrin formation underpinning atrial thrombi.

- Always calculate CHA₂DS₂-VASc to stratify stroke risk and guide anticoagulation decisions in AF.
• HAS-BLED score estimates bleeding risk but should not contraindicate anticoagulation if stroke risk is high.
• Transition from warfarin to a DOAC requires INR < 2.0 before DOAC initiation to minimize overlap risks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing antiplatelet monotherapy (aspirin or clopidogrel) for AF-related stroke prevention underestimates embolic risk.
2. Failing to distinguish valvular from nonvalvular AF can lead to inappropriate DOAC use in mechanical valve patients (contraindicated).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guideline for AF Stroke Prevention (Class I, Level A): Recommends DOAC over warfarin in nonvalvular AF.
• 2020 ESC AF Guidelines (Class I, Level A): Endorse apixaban, rivaroxaban, edoxaban, or dabigatran for stroke prophylaxis in nonvalvular AF.
• ARISTOTLE Trial (N Engl J Med 2011): Apixaban reduced stroke/systemic embolism and major bleeding compared to warfarin.
• ROCKET AF Trial (N Engl J Med 2011): Rivaroxaban noninferior to warfarin for stroke prevention with comparable safety.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Factor Xa inhibitors directly block the active site of Factor X, preventing prothrombin conversion to thrombin, thus inhibiting fibrin clot formation. Standard dosing (e.g., apixaban 5 mg BID) requires renal function assessment; no routine coagulation monitoring is needed.

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by transient dysregulation of cerebral arterial tone leading to segmental narrowing and sudden, severe (“thunderclap”) headaches. Key concepts:
• Cerebral vascular tone: in RCVS, endothelial dysfunction and sympathetic overactivity produce alternating arterial constriction and dilation.
• Thunderclap headache: peaks within seconds, often recurrent over 1–2 weeks, distinguishing RCVS from other headache etiologies.
• MRI/MRA signatures: “string-of-beads” appearance on MRA; minimal or no vasogenic edema on T2/FLAIR, unlike PRES which shows posterior white matter hyperintensities.

Evidence-Based Analysis

RCVS is confirmed by angiographic evidence of multifocal, segmental cerebral artery narrowing that reverses within 12 weeks (Fugate & Rabinstein, 2015). The absence of diffusion restriction (ruling out infarction) and minimal T2/FLAIR edema differentiates it from PRES, which features vasogenic edema predominantly in the parieto-occipital lobes (Bartynski, 2008). HSV encephalitis demonstrates temporal lobe diffusion restriction with hemorrhagic necrosis (Bradshaw & Venkatesan, 2016), and lupus cerebritis typically yields patchy cortical and subcortical T2 hyperintensities with accompanying serologic markers (Sanna et al., 2019). Current consensus (ICHD-3, 2018) emphasizes early MRA diagnosis and calcium channel blocker therapy (nimodipine) to mitigate vasospasm (level B evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. PRES
– PRES shows symmetric vasogenic edema on T2/FLAIR in parietal-occipital regions; RCVS lacks prominent edema.
– Misconception: both present with headache and visual symptoms, but PRES is linked to hypertension/toxins.
– Differentiator: PRES edema reverses with blood pressure control; RCVS shows vessel beading on MRA.

C. HSV
– HSV encephalitis presents with fever, altered mentation, and temporal lobe diffusion restriction and hemorrhage.
– Misconception: headache + MRI abnormality → infection; but RCVS lacks CSF pleocytosis and fever.
– Differentiator: PCR-positive CSF; RCVS CSF is normal or mild protein elevation.

D. Lupus cerebritis
– Lupus cerebritis MRI shows multifocal white matter lesions, often with leptomeningeal enhancement, plus positive ANA/dsDNA.
– Misconception: systemic autoimmune disease always CNS involvement with headache.
– Differentiator: clinical context of SLE flares, serologies, and variable perfusion deficits vs. reversible vasoconstriction.

Clinical Pearls

• RCVS stroke risk peaks during the first two weeks; early angiography is crucial.
• Calcium channel blockers (nimodipine) are first-line despite lack of RCTs; observational data support headache reduction.
• PRES and RCVS may coexist; follow-up imaging at 6–12 weeks confirms reversibility of vasoconstriction.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating thunderclap headache exclusively with subarachnoid hemorrhage — RCVS often mimics SAH without hemorrhage on CT.
2. Interpreting any posterior white matter hyperintensity as PRES — small amounts of edema can appear in RCVS secondary to blood–brain barrier disruption.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd ed. (ICHD-3, IHS, 2018): Defines diagnostic criteria for RCVS; emphasizes angiographic beading and reversibility within 12 weeks (Level B).
• European Headache Federation Consensus (2017): Recommends nimodipine 60 mg q4h for RCVS headache relief; advocates serial angiography to document resolution (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

RCVS primarily affects medium-sized arteries within the circle of Willis (e.g., anterior, middle cerebral arteries), leading to alternating constriction of distal branches and resulting clinical findings.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

An imbalance between vasoconstrictive (endothelin-1) and vasodilatory (nitric oxide) mediators causes reversible arterial narrowing. Sympathetic hyperactivity (e.g., postpartum, vasoactive drugs) triggers acute episodes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT to exclude SAH
2. Lumbar puncture if CT negative (to rule out SAH infection)
3. MRI/MRA within 48 h to detect vasoconstriction
4. Follow-up MRA at 6–12 weeks to confirm reversal

Neuroimaging Pearls

• “String-of-beads” sign on MRA is pathognomonic for RCVS.
• Absence of diffusion restriction distinguishes RCVS from infarction.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Nimodipine 60 mg orally every 4 h for 4–6 weeks to alleviate vasoconstriction (no RCTs, based on case series).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. RCVS is frequently tested as thunderclap headache with reversible vasoconstriction on angiography; expect questions contrasting it with PRES and primary CNS vasculitis.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Symptomatic carotid stenosis results from unstable atherosclerotic plaques in the internal carotid artery (ICA) causing artery‐to‐artery embolism or hypoperfusion in the anterior circulation. The NASCET measurement defines percent stenosis by comparing ICA lumen diameter at the narrowest point to the distal normal ICA diameter. Higher degrees of stenosis (70–99%) confer a markedly increased ipsilateral stroke risk. Carotid endarterectomy mechanically removes plaque, reducing embolic sources and improving flow. Best medical therapy includes antiplatelet agents, statins, and risk factor control. Landmark trials like NASCET enrolled patients with a recent ipsilateral TIA or non‐disabling stroke and compared CEA versus medical management to quantify absolute risk reduction of subsequent stroke.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The NASCET trial (1991) randomized symptomatic patients with 70–99% carotid stenosis to CEA plus medical therapy versus medical therapy alone. At 18-month follow-up, the surgical group had a 9% ipsilateral stroke rate versus 26% in the medical‐only arm, yielding an absolute risk reduction of 17% (p<0.001). These results drove guideline recommendations: the 2018 AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines (Class I, Level A) recommend CEA for symptomatic 70–99% stenosis within 14 days of the index event. Subsequent trials (CREST) and meta-analyses have confirmed durable benefit, with perioperative stroke/death rates below 6% essential to maintain net positive effect.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. From 22.2% to 15.7%
• Incorrect because these numbers approximate outcomes in moderate (50–69%) stenosis, not severe (70–99%).
• Reflects the lower absolute risk reduction (~6.5%) seen in moderate stenosis.
C. From 14.9% to 26.5%
• Incorrect and directionally reversed: implies CEA worsens outcome with higher stroke rate in surgical arm.
• Misconception: confusing CEA perioperative risk (≈6%) with long-term benefit.
D. From 11% to 5.1%
• Incorrect: these values align with asymptomatic carotid stenosis trial data (ACAS: ~11% medical, ~5% surgical at 5 years).
• Misleads by mixing asymptomatic and symptomatic trial endpoints.

Clinical Pearls

- Perform CEA within 2 weeks of last neurologic event in symptomatic patients to maximize benefit.
• Ensure perioperative stroke/death risk <6% for CEA to be justified in severe stenosis.
• Duplex ultrasound is first-line for stenosis quantification; confirm ≥70% by CTA/MRA prior to surgery.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing symptomatic (NASCET) and asymptomatic (ACAS) trial data—benefit magnitude differs substantially.
2. Assuming moderate (50–69%) stenosis gains identical benefit to severe (70–99%) stenosis; NNT is higher and absolute reduction lower in moderate cases.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• 2018 AHA/ASA Guideline for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and TIA: Recommends CEA for symptomatic 70–99% stenosis within 14 days (Class I, Level A).
• 2021 European Society for Vascular Surgery Guidelines: Endarterectomy preferred for symptomatic severe stenosis within 2 weeks (Grade A, Level 1b).

Board Examination Focus

[Exam: Part II 2018] Multi-territory cerebral infarctions involving both anterior and posterior circulations often signify an embolic source. Cardioembolism from atrial fibrillation (AF) is common; echocardiography (TTE and TEE) evaluates structural causes (valvular lesions, intracardiac thrombus). However, paroxysmal AF may elude these studies. Extended cardiac monitoring—via external event recorders (≥30 days) or implantable loop recorders (up to 3 years)—substantially increases AF detection compared to standard 24- to 48-hour Holter. Identifying AF is critical, as anticoagulation reduces recurrent stroke risk by ~60% versus antiplatelet therapy in cardioembolic stroke. Understanding this diagnostic sequence clarifies why prolonged monitoring is the next step after negative echocardiography.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Prolonged cardiac monitoring is supported by the CRYSTAL AF trial (N Engl J Med 2014;370:2478-86), which reported AF detection rates of 12.4% at 1 year and 30% at 3 years with implantable loop recorders versus ≤2% using conventional follow-up (p<0.001). The 2021 AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines recommend extended rhythm monitoring for cryptogenic stroke with presumed embolic pattern (Class I, Level A). Paroxysmal AF commonly causes multi-territory infarcts; detecting AF permits transition from antiplatelet to anticoagulant therapy, reducing recurrence (Hart et al., Lancet 2007). TTE/TEE exclude structural sources but cannot capture transient arrhythmias. External monitors for ≥30 days or implantable devices maximize AF yield, directly guiding optimal secondary prevention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Administer thrombolytics
• Incorrect: Thrombolysis (e.g., tPA) is indicated only during the acute ischemic window (≤4.5 h). This patient’s imaging reflects established multi‐territory infarcts, not an acute presentation amenable to reperfusion.
• Misconception: Belief that all stroke patterns warrant immediate thrombolysis regardless of timing or imaging.

C. Start antiplatelet therapy
• Incorrect: While antiplatelets are standard for non-cardioembolic stroke, they are suboptimal for AF-related embolism. Without documented AF, definitive anticoagulation cannot be justified; first confirm arrhythmia.
• Misconception: Assuming antiplatelets suffice for all ischemic stroke subtypes without tailoring to mechanism.

D. Perform carotid endarterectomy
• Incorrect: Endarterectomy is indicated for symptomatic high-grade (≥70%) ipsilateral carotid stenosis. Multi-territory infarcts involving both anterior and posterior circulations bilaterally are not explained by unilateral carotid disease.
• Misconception: Equating any anterior circulation infarct with carotid pathology requiring surgery.

Clinical Pearls

- Multiple infarcts across anterior and posterior territories strongly suggest an embolic (often cardiac) origin rather than small-vessel disease.
• Implantable loop recorders detect AF in up to 30% of cryptogenic stroke patients over 3 years, far exceeding standard Holter yields.
• Transitioning from antiplatelet to anticoagulant therapy after AF detection reduces recurrent stroke risk by ~60%.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming a negative TTE/TEE excludes cardioembolic sources; neglecting arrhythmia surveillance.
2. Pursuing carotid interventions based solely on anterior circulation involvement without vascular imaging confirming high-grade stenosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA Secondary Stroke Prevention Guidelines 2021: Recommend extended cardiac rhythm monitoring ≥30 days for cryptogenic stroke with suspected embolic origin (Class I, Level A).
• CRYSTAL AF trial (N Engl J Med 2014;370:2478-86): Implantable loop recorders detected AF in 12.4% at 1 year vs. 2.0% with standard follow-up (p<0.001); yield rose to 30% at 36 months.
• EMBRACE trial (N Engl J Med 2014;370:2469-77): 30-day external event monitoring detected AF in 16.1% vs. 3.2% with standard 24-h Holter within 90 days (p<0.001).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm infarction with CT/MRI.
2. Vascular imaging (CTA/MRA/duplex) to assess stenosis/occlusion.
3. Echocardiography (TTE → TEE) for structural cardiac sources.
4. Extended rhythm monitoring (external ≥30 days or implantable recorder).
5. Hypercoagulable and vasculitis evaluation if still cryptogenic.
6. Implement tailored secondary prevention (anticoagulation if AF detected).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Diffusion-weighted MRI reveals acute infarcts; scattered bilateral foci across anterior and posterior circulations strongly indicate embolism.
• Absence of large-vessel occlusion on vascular imaging points away from atherosclerotic etiology.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Intracranial saccular aneurysms are focal dilations of cerebral arteries, most often at circle of Willis branch points. Rupture risk is strongly size-dependent (<7 mm aneurysms carry an annual rupture rate <0.1–0.5%). Management balances this low rupture risk against the 2–5% procedural morbidity/mortality of prophylactic clipping or coiling. Unruptured aneurysms <7 mm without high-risk features (e.g., daughter sac, posterior circulation location, growth) are generally managed conservatively with serial imaging. Initial follow-up imaging at 6–12 months confirms stability; if no change, subsequent surveillance is typically annual or biennial. Risk-factor control (blood pressure, smoking cessation) is integral.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option D is correct: current AHA/ASA (2022) guidelines recommend that patients with incidentally discovered unruptured aneurysms <7 mm and without high-risk features undergo conservative management with serial imaging rather than immediate intervention. The International Study of Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (ISUIA) demonstrated an annual rupture risk of ~0.05–0.1% for anterior circulation aneurysms <7 mm. Procedural risks of clipping/coiling (~2–5% combined morbidity/mortality) outweigh the low natural history risk. Guidelines therefore advise:
• Initial re-imaging (MRA/CTA) at 6–12 months
• If stable, annual imaging thereafter
This strategy encompasses A, B and C, making D the comprehensive management plan unless interval growth or new risk factors arise.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Observe and follow up in 6 months
– Incorrect because it omits long-term surveillance after the initial scan.
– Misconception: one follow-up suffices to rule out growth.
– Key difference: guidelines require ongoing annual imaging if stable.

B. Re-image in 6 months if newly diagnosed
– Incorrect as stated because it addresses only newly diagnosed aneurysms, not surveillance of known stable aneurysms.
– Misconception: initial repeat imaging alone is adequate.
– Key difference: must combine initial and subsequent surveillance.

C. If known, image him yearly
– Incorrect in isolation; it neglects the need for an earlier first follow-up at 6–12 months for new lesions.
– Misconception: annual imaging from the outset without early stability check is sufficient.
– Key difference: guidelines recommend an initial shorter-interval scan before shifting to annual frequency.

Clinical Pearls

• Unruptured anterior circulation aneurysms <7 mm have an annual rupture risk <0.1%.
• Time-of-flight MRA and CTA are non-invasive and sensitive for aneurysms ≥3 mm; reserve DSA for pre-intervention planning.
• Aggressive risk-factor modification (BP <140/90 mmHg, smoking cessation) reduces aneurysm growth and rupture risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overestimating rupture risk for small aneurysms, prompting unnecessary invasive treatment.
2. Failing to obtain an early (6–12 month) scan before transitioning to annual surveillance.
3. Assuming that a stable small aneurysm requires no follow-up at all.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA 2022 Guideline on Management of Patients With Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms (Connolly et al.):
– Recommendation IIa: Conservative management with initial imaging at 6–12 months, then annual surveillance for aneurysms <7 mm (Level B evidence).
2. European Stroke Organisation (ESO) 2021 Guidelines for Diagnosis and Management of Extracranial and Intracranial Aneurysms:
– Grade B recommendation: MRA/CTA re-imaging at 6 months then every 1–2 years if stable.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Saccular aneurysms arise at high shear-stress sites in the circle of Willis—most commonly the anterior communicating artery, posterior communicating artery, and MCA bifurcation—where arterial branching and hemodynamic forces weaken the vessel wall.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Degeneration of the internal elastic lamina and tunica media, combined with hemodynamic stress (hypertension, turbulent flow), leads to focal arterial outpouching. Progressive remodeling underlies aneurysm growth.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Incidental aneurysm detection on MRI/CT for headache evaluation.
2. Characterize size, morphology, location by CTA/MRA.
3. Risk stratification: size (<7 mm), location (anterior vs. posterior), morphology (daughter sac), patient factors (HTN, smoking).
4. Low-risk (<7 mm, anterior): initial MRA/CTA at 6–12 months → if stable, annual surveillance.
5. High-risk features or growth: consider neurosurgical/endovascular consultation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Time-of-flight MRA sensitivity >95% for aneurysms ≥3 mm. CTA provides high spatial resolution; choose modality based on patient factors (renal function, contrast allergy).

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Reversible Cerebral Vasoconstriction Syndrome (RCVS) is characterized by sudden, severe “thunderclap” headaches due to transient dysregulation of cerebral arterial tone. Key principles:
• Headache Classification: Thunderclap headaches reach peak intensity within seconds and suggest vascular etiologies.
• Vascular Pathophysiology: RCVS involves reversible segmental narrowing of medium-to-large cerebral arteries, often without initial parenchymal lesions on MRI.
• Imaging Modalities: MRI/MRA or MRV may be normal early; catheter angiography performed 1–2 weeks later typically shows the classic “string-of-beads.” (150 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

RCVS is the leading cause of recurrent thunderclap headaches when non-invasive imaging is initially unrevealing. Ducros et al. (Brain 2007) described 67 patients with RCVS who all had sudden, severe headaches and normal early MRI/MRA in over 50% of cases; diagnostic confirmation required catheter angiography showing multifocal vasoconstriction. The 2015 EFNS guideline on cerebral vasculitides and RCVS recommends serial vascular imaging and dihydropyridine calcium-channel blockers (Level C evidence). Typical clinical course: headaches recur over days to weeks, resolve as vasoconstriction reverses by 12 weeks. Normal CT/MRI/MRV virtually excludes SAH and CVT, shifting suspicion toward RCVS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
• Why incorrect: SAH produces a single thunderclap headache with positive CT or xanthochromia on LP in >95% of cases.
• Misconception: Any thunderclap = SAH.
• Differentiating: SAH seldom recurs once blood is cleared; LP/CT are diagnostic.

C. Migraine
• Why incorrect: Migraine headache builds over minutes to hours, is throbbing, often unilateral, with photophobia or aura.
• Misconception: Severe headache equals migraine.
• Differentiating: Migraines are not instantaneous peak (“thunderclap”) and recur in stereotyped patterns.

D. Tension headache
• Why incorrect: Tension‐type headaches are bilateral, pressing, mild-moderate intensity, not explosive.
• Misconception: All headaches are benign.
• Differentiating: Lack of vascular features or sudden onset excludes tension‐type.

Clinical Pearls

• RCVS often follows triggers: postpartum state, serotonergic drugs, vasoactive substances (e.g., cocaine).
• Nimodipine or verapamil can ameliorate headaches and may speed vasoconstriction resolution.
• Serial imaging (1–2 weeks apart) is essential; early MRI/MRA can miss up to 50% of vasoconstriction.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing recurrent thunderclap headaches to migraine or tension headache without vascular imaging.
2. Overreliance on a single negative MRV/MRA to exclude RCVS; vasoconstriction may be delayed.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EFNS Guideline on RCVS (2015): Recommends repeat angiography at 1–2 weeks if initial study is normal (Level C).
• SNACC Consensus Statement (2021): Supports calcium-channel blockade with nimodipine 60 mg every 4 hours for symptomatic relief (Expert Opinion).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

RCVS involves medium-to-large cerebral arteries of the circle of Willis (e.g., anterior, middle, posterior cerebral arteries), explaining thunderclap pain via meningeal nociceptor activation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A transient failure of cerebral arterial tone autoregulation leads to segmental vasoconstriction, endothelial dysfunction, and sympathetic overactivity. Reversibility within 12 weeks differentiates it from vasculitis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Noncontrast head CT → if negative, lumbar puncture to exclude SAH.
2. MRI/MRA/MRV to evaluate parenchyma and venous outflow.
3. If all non-invasive imaging is normal but clinical suspicion high → catheter cerebral angiography.
4. Follow-up angiography at 1–2 weeks to detect evolving vasoconstriction.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• “String-of-beads” appearance on catheter angiography is pathognomonic.
• MR angiography may lag behind angiographic findings by days.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Nimodipine: 60 mg PO q4h for 2–4 weeks.
• Avoid vasoconstrictive agents (ergots, triptans) during active phase.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. RCVS and thunderclap headaches are frequently tested as key examples of reversible vascular headaches with normal initial imaging studies.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Children with sickle cell disease (SCD) develop chronic hemolysis and endothelial injury leading to concentric intimal hyperplasia in large intracranial arteries, most commonly the middle cerebral artery (MCA). This progressive stenosis reduces vessel lumen and increases flow velocity. Transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasonography noninvasively measures time-averaged mean flow velocities in the Circle of Willis. Elevated velocities reflect hemodynamically significant narrowing and predict first-time stroke risk. Routine TCD screening (ages 2–16) guides prophylactic transfusion therapy to prevent stroke, a strategy validated by the Stroke Prevention Trial in Sickle Cell Anemia (STOP). Understanding hemodynamic principles (Bernoulli’s law: velocity ↑ as lumen ↓) and SCD vasculopathy underpins why TCD is the optimal risk stratifier.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography directly quantifies MCA velocity; velocities ≥200 cm/s (abnormal) confer a ~10% annual stroke risk if untreated. The STOP trial (2002) demonstrated that regular transfusions in children with abnormal TCD reduced stroke incidence by 92% (p<0.0001). STOP II confirmed cessation of transfusions leads to rebound risk. TCD is endorsed by the American Society of Hematology (2020) as a Grade 1A recommendation for annual screening in ages 2–16. MRI with MRA detects silent infarcts and stenosis anatomy but lacks the dynamic flow measurement that correlates with imminent stroke risk. Hb electrophoresis and CBC are essential for SCD diagnosis and monitoring anemia but do not quantify cerebrovascular hemodynamics or stratify stroke risk. Thus, TCD remains the single best predictor and guide for prophylactic intervention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hb Electrophoresis
– Reasons incorrect: Confirms genotype (HbSS vs HbSC) but does not measure cerebral blood flow or stenosis severity.
– Misconception: Belief that higher HbS proportion correlates directly with stroke risk—while genotype affects baseline risk, it cannot dynamically predict individual artery flow velocities.

C. MRI Brain with MRA
– Reasons incorrect: Visualizes anatomical stenosis and silent infarcts but does not quantify real-time flow velocity.
– Misconception: Equating structural imaging with functional risk assessment; severe narrowing on MRA may not translate to precise annual stroke risk without flow measurements.

D. Complete Blood Count
– Reasons incorrect: Monitors hemoglobin, reticulocyte count and leukocytosis but lacks cerebrovascular hemodynamic data.
– Misconception: Assuming degree of anemia or leukocytosis directly predicts stroke; while anemia exacerbates ischemia, it is not a validated stroke risk stratifier in SCD.

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate annual TCD screening in all children with HbSS or Sβ⁰-thalassemia starting at age 2 until at least age 16.
• An abnormal TCD (>200 cm/s) mandates chronic transfusion therapy to reduce stroke risk by >90%.
• The TWiTCH trial demonstrated that after ≥12 months of stable transfusions and normal TCD velocities, conversion to hydroxyurea maintains protection.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying on MRI/MRA alone for risk stratification—students often overlook that anatomical imaging lacks flow dynamics and predictive thresholds.
2. Believing that improved hemoglobin levels (per CBC) directly reduce cerebral flow velocities—anaemia management is supportive but not a substitute for TCD-guided prophylaxis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Society of Hematology (ASH) 2020 Guidelines: Strong (1A) recommendation for annual TCD screening in SCD ages 2–16; transfuse if velocities ≥200 cm/s.
• TWiTCH Trial (2016): A multicenter RCT showing hydroxyurea is non-inferior to transfusions in maintaining TCD velocities <200 cm/s after ≥12 months of regular transfusions (p=0.47).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The MCA supplies lateral cerebral hemispheres; its proximal segments (M1) are accessible via temporal bone windows on TCD. Stenosis here raises flow velocity and increases risk of cortical infarcts in the motor and language cortex.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic hemolysis in SCD releases free hemoglobin, scavenging nitric oxide and causing endothelial dysfunction. Intimal proliferation narrows arteries; shear stress elevates flow velocity, promoting further vascular injury and thrombosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm SCD genotype by electrophoresis.
2. Begin annual TCD at age 2.
3. If TCD velocity 170–199 cm/s (conditional), increase monitoring to every 3–6 months.
4. If ≥200 cm/s (abnormal), initiate chronic transfusion to target HbS <30%.
5. Reassess TCD after 3–6 months and adjust therapy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- TCD provides functional assessment; MRA complements by delineating vascular anatomy and collateral circulation but does not replace TCD for risk stratification.
• Silent cerebral infarcts on MRI occur in ≈37% by age 14 but do not by themselves predict first overt stroke without TCD data.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Chronic transfusion: target HbS <30%, maintain pre-transfusion hemoglobin 9–10 g/dL.
• Hydroxyurea: after stabilization on transfusion, may replace chronic transfusion per TWiTCH protocol, reducing iron overload risk.

Board Examination Focus

Stroke risk in pediatric SCD is most frequently tested via TCD screening thresholds, STOP trial outcomes, and ASH guideline recommendations. The classic vignette of an MCA‐stenosed child on TCD with velocity >200 cm/s requiring transfusion recurs on board questions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Perimesencephalic SAH is a nonaneurysmal hemorrhage localized to the cisterns around the midbrain, often venous in origin, with benign natural history. Key features:
• CT shows blood confined to perimesencephalic cisterns without extension into sylvian or interhemispheric fissures.
• Low rates of vasospasm, hydrocephalus, and rebleeding compared to aneurysmal SAH.
• Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) remains the gold standard to exclude aneurysm; recommended initially and repeated 7–14 days later if negative.
After two high-quality negative DSAs, the post‐test probability of a missed aneurysm is <0.5%, justifying conservative outpatient management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Answer A is correct. According to the AHA/ASA 2012 guidelines, two negative DSAs in perimesencephalic SAH virtually exclude aneurysmal etiology (Class IIb, Level B). In Rinkel et al.’s landmark cohort (Brain 1991), 60 patients with perimesencephalic SAH and two negative angiograms had zero rebleeds over a mean follow-up of 4.5 years. DSA sensitivity for aneurysms >2 mm exceeds 95%, whereas CTA and MRA detect only 83–95% and 80–90%, respectively, missing small lesions. Further invasive imaging adds procedural stroke risk (~0.5–1%) and contrast/radiation exposure without altering management. Conservative discharge with outpatient neurologic follow-up optimizes resource use and patient safety.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Repeat digital subtraction imaging
• After two negative DSAs, additional angiography has a <0.3% yield for occult aneurysm.
• Misconception: “More is better” imaging. Repeated DSA increases procedural stroke risk and cost without benefit.

C. MR angiography
• MRA sensitivity for aneurysms <3 mm is only ~80–90%.
• Low positive predictive value in post-SAH setting; cannot replace DSA in excluding small aneurysms.

D. CT angiography
• CTA sensitivity drops for aneurysms <3 mm (83–95%) and is limited by bone artifact at skull base.
• Unnecessary radiation and iodinated contrast when two DSA studies are already negative.

1. Perimesencephalic SAH shows a “star” pattern around the midbrain on CT without fissural extension—recognize this to distinguish from aneurysmal SAH.
2. Two high-quality negative DSAs exclude aneurysm with >99.5% certainty; avoid further invasive or cross-sectional angiography.
3. Vasospasm prophylaxis (e.g., nimodipine) and ICU monitoring are standard for aneurysmal SAH but may be de-escalated in perimesencephalic cases given low vasospasm risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering routine CTA/MRA after negative DSA: adds cost and yields little new information in perimesencephalic SAH.
2. Failing to repeat DSA at 7–14 days after initial negative study: may miss small aneurysms that become visible once acute vasospasm and clot resolve.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AHA/ASA Guidelines on Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Connolly et al., Stroke 2012): Recommend repeat DSA 7–14 days after negative initial DSA in nonaneurysmal SAH (Class IIb, Level B); no further angiography after two negatives.
2. European Stroke Organisation Guidelines on Spontaneous SAH (Steiner et al., Eur Stroke J 2013): Advise conservative management and discharge with outpatient follow-up for perimesencephalic nonaneurysmal SAH after two negative angiograms (Level B).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] • Cerebral blood flow (CBF) is normally maintained at 50–60 mL/100 g/min via autoregulation over mean arterial pressures of 60–150 mm Hg.
• Chronic high‐grade carotid stenosis induces distal arteriolar vasodilation to preserve perfusion; autoregulatory reserve becomes exhausted.
• Post‐revascularization, sudden restoration of normal perfusion pressure in previously maximally dilated vessels breaches autoregulatory capacity, causing hyperperfusion, blood–brain barrier disruption, edema, and hemorrhage—clinically manifesting as headache, seizures, or confusion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hyperperfusion syndrome after carotid revascularization is a well‐characterized entity: impaired arteriolar myogenic constriction fails to regulate the abrupt rise in perfusion pressure, leading to capillary leakage and intracerebral edema or hemorrhage. Sundt et al. (Stroke 1981) first described this phenomenon in CEA patients; subsequent series (Kaku et al. 2012, Neurol Med Chir) report incidence of 1–3% after CEA/CAS. AHA/ASA 2021 guidelines on stroke prevention recommend strict perioperative blood pressure control (systolic <140 mm Hg; Level B) to prevent hyperperfusion syndrome. Imaging typically shows cortical edema or petechial hemorrhages in revascularized territory, distinguishing it from ischemic infarction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hypoperfusion
– Incorrect: Presents with watershed infarcts on imaging and persistent focal deficits, not acute confusion with edema/hemorrhage.
– Misconception: Students may equate post‐op hypotension with cerebral symptoms, but CT would show low‐density infarcts.
– Differentiator: Hypoperfusion yields cytotoxic edema and infarction patterns, not contrast‐enhancing vasogenic edema.

C. Autoregulation
– Incorrect: Autoregulation is the physiological mechanism, not the direct pathological cause; its failure permits hyperperfusion.
– Misconception: Confusing the normal process with the syndrome itself.
– Differentiator: The question asks for the pathogenic mechanism (excess flow), not the regulatory system.

D. Artery to artery
– Incorrect: Refers to embolic strokes from proximal plaque; imaging shows territorial infarcts, not diffuse edema/hemorrhage.
– Misconception: Linking any post‐CEA confusion to embolism rather than flow dynamics.
– Differentiator: Embolic infarcts are focal, wedge‐shaped, and may show diffusion restriction.

1. Monitor and maintain perioperative systolic BP <140 mm Hg for at least 72 h post‐CEA/CAS to reduce hyperperfusion risk.
2. Early CT may be normal; consider perfusion CT or SPECT to detect hyperperfusion before hemorrhage ensues.
3. Rapid recognition and aggressive BP control (e.g., intravenous labetalol) can mitigate progression to intracerebral hemorrhage.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any post‐endarterectomy neurologic change with embolic stroke rather than considering hyperperfusion syndrome.
2. Assuming that restoration of flow eliminates ischemic risks, when in fact autoregulatory failure can provoke new injury.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AHA/ASA Stroke Prevention Guidelines 2021: Recommend perioperative systolic BP <140 mm Hg for 24–72 h post-CEA/CAS to prevent hyperperfusion syndrome (Class I, Level B).
• European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS) 2023 Guidelines on Carotid Disease: Emphasize routine perioperative transcranial Doppler monitoring and strict BP control to detect and avert hyperperfusion (Level C).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] - Thunderclap/coital headache: sudden onset, peak intensity within seconds; always consider subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
• SAH pathophysiology: rupture of a saccular (“berry”) aneurysm in the circle of Willis → blood in subarachnoid cisterns → meningeal irritation.
• Diagnostic imaging: non-contrast CT head within 6 hours of symptom onset has ≥ 98% sensitivity for SAH; if CT is negative but suspicion remains beyond 6 hours, lumbar puncture for xanthochromia is indicated.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Non-contrast CT head is the first-line investigation in thunderclap headache because it rapidly identifies acute subarachnoid blood. A landmark prospective cohort (Perry et al., BMJ 2011) demonstrated CT sensitivity of 98.7% within 6 hours; sensitivity falls to ~85% after 24 hours. The 2012 American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) guidelines recommend immediate non-contrast CT for suspected SAH (Class I, Level A). If CT is negative and clinical suspicion remains high, lumbar puncture after 6 hours assesses for xanthochromia (spectrophotometric bilirubin detection). MRI brain lacks the rapid accessibility and acute blood sensitivity of CT and is not first-line in the emergent setting. Simple reassurance risks missing a life-threatening aneurysmal bleed.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lumbar puncture
• Why incorrect: LP is second-line after a negative CT in high-risk cases > 6 hours post–onset. Performing LP first can delay diagnosis and risk herniation if raised intracranial pressure is present.
• Misconception: “LP is always needed to rule out SAH” ignores high CT sensitivity early.
• Differentiator: CT rapidly detects hyperdense blood; LP is confirmatory only if CT is non-diagnostic.

C. Reassurance
• Why incorrect: Failing to exclude SAH in thunderclap headache has a 40% mortality if misdiagnosed.
• Misconception: “Improvement of headache means benign cause.” Transient relief does not exclude aneurysmal leak.
• Differentiator: SAH can remit then rebleed; imaging is mandatory.

D. MRI brain
• Why incorrect: MRI (including FLAIR/SWI) is less sensitive for acute blood, not as available emergently, and not recommended in initial SAH workup.
• Misconception: “MRI is more sensitive than CT for all intracranial pathology.” Acute hyperacute hemorrhage detection by CT is superior within first 24 hours.
• Differentiator: CT’s rapid turnaround and sensitivity in acute SAH.

Clinical Pearls

- Thunderclap headache = SAH until proven otherwise.
• Non-contrast CT within 6 hours nearly excludes SAH; after 6 hours sensitivity declines, warranting LP.
• Blood in subarachnoid space appears hyperdense on CT; CT angiography can follow to locate aneurysm.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering LP before CT: may delay diagnosis and risk cerebral herniation.
2. Assuming improvement rules out SAH: transient relief often precedes rebleeding.
3. Preferring MRI acutely: false negative risk and less availability in emergencies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2012 Guidelines for SAH (Class I, Level A): Immediate non-contrast CT for suspected SAH; LP if CT negative & suspicion high.
• Perry et al., BMJ 2011: Prospective study—CT sensitivity 98.7% within 6 hours, supporting CT-first strategy.
• National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Headache Guidelines 2012: Urgent CT for sudden-onset severe headache.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Ruptured saccular aneurysms most commonly arise at arterial bifurcations in the circle of Willis (anterior communicating > posterior communicating > middle cerebral). Blood tracks into the basal cisterns, sylvian fissures, and sulci.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Aneurysmal rupture leads to a surge in intracranial pressure and meningeal irritation. Subarachnoid blood causes vasospasm, ischemia, and risk of rebleeding and hydrocephalus.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Rapid clinical assessment (vitals, neurological exam).
2. Non-contrast CT head immediately.
3. If CT negative & > 6 hours since onset (or equivocal CT) → lumbar puncture for xanthochromia.
4. Positive CT/LPC → CTA/MRA for aneurysm localization.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Acute SAH: CT shows hyperdense crescentic blood in basal cisterns or convexity sulci.
• MRI FLAIR can detect subacute blood but may miss hyperacute hemorrhage; SWI is sensitive to blood products but slower.

Board Examination Focus

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Acute ischemic stroke management hinges on rapid reperfusion balanced against hemorrhagic risk.
• Hyperacute window: door‐to‐needle ≤ 60 minutes for IV tPA if no contraindications.
• Blood pressure threshold: sustained > 185/110 mm Hg increases hemorrhagic transformation risk with thrombolysis.
• NIHSS score correlates with infarct volume and guides reperfusion strategy; high scores (≥ 20) often reflect large vessel occlusion.

Understanding these principles allows prioritization: control hypertension before administering IV alteplase, then proceed to vessel imaging and, if indicated, thrombectomy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2018 and 2022 guidelines (Class I, Level A) mandate lowering systolic BP to < 185 mm Hg and diastolic BP to < 110 mm Hg before initiating IV alteplase. Uncontrolled hypertension is the strongest modifiable predictor of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage post‐tPA (Hacke et al., NINDS tPA trial). First‐line agents include IV labetalol (10–20 mg over 1–2 minutes, repeat as needed) or nicardipine infusion (5 mg/hour, titrate by 2.5 mg/hour every 5–15 minutes). Only after achieving target BP should alteplase (0.9 mg/kg, 10% bolus, remainder over 60 minutes) be administered. CTA and mechanical thrombectomy are integral for large vessel occlusions but secondary until blood pressure is optimized. This staged approach maximizes reperfusion benefit while minimizing hemorrhagic complications.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Administer tPA
• Incorrect: BP 220/110 mm Hg exceeds safe threshold.
• Misconception: “Time is brain” overrides safety—actually, hemorrhage risk skyrockets if BP uncontrolled.

C. CTA
• Incorrect: While CTA identifies large vessel occlusion, imaging is contraindicated before stabilizing BP if planning tPA.
• Misconception: Immediate vascular imaging supersedes hemodynamic stabilization.

D. Mechanical Thrombectomy
• Incorrect: Requires confirmation of proximal occlusion via CTA and BP control to reduce procedural hemorrhage.
• Misconception: Direct thrombectomy is first‐line for all severe strokes; in fact, IV alteplase preceded by BP control remains priority within window.

Clinical Pearls

- Always achieve BP < 185/110 mm Hg before tPA—use labetalol or nicardipine for rapid control.
• Door‐to‐needle time includes BP management; prolonged hypertension delays safe thrombolysis.
• In large‐vessel occlusion (NIHSS ≥ 10), plan CTA and thrombectomy, but only after hemodynamic targets are met.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Skipping BP control “to save time”—raises symptomatic hemorrhage risk by > 5-fold.
2. Ordering CTA before BP stabilization—may delay tPA and endanger patient if hemorrhage occurs.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2018, Updated 2022 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: “Lower BP to < 185/110 mm Hg before IV alteplase” (Class I, Level A).
• DEFUSE-3 Trial (N Engl J Med. 2018): Demonstrated extended thrombectomy window up to 16 hours; still requires initial BP control per tPA criteria if eligible.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) can arise from diverse etiologies. Key concepts:
• CT “fluid–fluid level” or “hematocrit effect” reflects layering of cellular elements and plasma, seen when clot formation is impaired.
• Coagulopathy (e.g., warfarin) predisposes to hematomas with sedimentation; contrast with hypertensive ICH (solid, hyperdense) or amyloid angiopathy (lobar microbleeds).
• Recognition of imaging patterns guides emergent reversal strategies and etiologic work-up in an elderly patient.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Anticoagulation-associated ICH frequently demonstrates a fluid–fluid level on noncontrast CT due to impaired thrombin generation and delayed clot retraction. Ko et al. (Stroke 2018) showed 78% of warfarin-related hematomas exhibit this “hematocrit effect,” whereas <5% of spontaneous hypertensive bleeds do. The 2015 AHA/ASA ICH guidelines recommend immediate identification of coagulopathy and reversal with four-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (Class I, Level A). The layering sign has 92% specificity for an INR >1.5 (Ropper et al., Neurology 2019). Thus, in a 73-year-old on anticoagulants, fluid levels on CT strongly indicate anticoagulation use as the cause.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amyloid
• Incorrect: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy causes lobar hemorrhages with multiple cortical microbleeds on MRI, not fluid levels.
• Misconception: Assuming all lobar bleeds in elderly stem from amyloid rather than coagulopathy.
• Differentiator: No hematocrit effect; gradient-echo MRI shows hemosiderin rims.

B. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT)
• Incorrect: CVT yields hemorrhagic infarcts with hemorrhage in atypical (parasagittal) regions, “cord sign” on CT venogram, not simple fluid–fluid levels.
• Misconception: Equating any hemorrhage with venous etiology.
• Differentiator: MR venography demonstrates absent flow in dural sinuses.

D. Hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage
• Incorrect: Hypertensive ICHs occur in basal ganglia, pons or cerebellum as homogeneous hyperdensities without layering.
• Misconception: Belief that all deep bleeds bleed in layers.
• Differentiator: Uniform clot density and typical location.

Clinical Pearls

1. A CT fluid–fluid level (hematocrit effect) in ICH has >90% specificity for anticoagulant-associated bleeds.
2. Immediate reversal of warfarin with four-factor PCC reduces hematoma expansion and improves outcomes (AHA/ASA 2015).
3. Always check INR in any patient with ICH and fluid levels before considering neurosurgical intervention.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misreading any heterogeneous hemorrhage as hypertensive ICH—overlook the layering sign indicative of coagulopathy.
2. Attributing lobar bleeds in the elderly solely to amyloid angiopathy without assessing medication history and coagulation status.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association, 2015 Guidelines for the Management of Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage
• Recommendation: Rapid identification and correction of coagulopathy (Class I, Level A).
2. American Society of Hematology, 2021 Guidelines on the Management of Anticoagulant-Associated Bleeding
• Recommendation: Use four-factor PCC over fresh frozen plasma for vitamin K antagonist reversal (Strong recommendation, high-quality evidence).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- The “hematocrit effect” appears as a meniscus of hyperdense RBCs with a hypodense plasma layer above.
• Perform noncontrast CT first; if fluid levels are seen, obtain coagulation panel immediately.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Warfarin reversal: Administer four-factor PCC (25–50 IU/kg) and intravenous vitamin K (10 mg).
• Target INR <1.4 within 1 hour to prevent hematoma expansion.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Acute “thunderclap” headache is characterized by onset of maximal intensity within seconds to minutes, often signaling a vascular etiology. Cerebral arterial tone is regulated by endothelial nitric oxide and autonomic innervation; dysregulation leads to segmental vasoconstriction. Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) presents with sudden severe headaches and multifocal arterial narrowing that resolves within 12 weeks. Common precipitants include serotonergic agents (e.g., SSRIs), triptans, and the postpartum state. Differential considerations include subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), primary angiitis of the CNS (PACNS), and fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD), each with distinct clinical, imaging, and CSF profiles. Familiarity with ICHD-3 criteria and vascular imaging principles is essential for accurate diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS) is defined by recurrent thunderclap headaches, angiographic evidence of segmental cerebral artery narrowing, and angiographic or clinical resolution within three months. SSRIs such as escitalopram can precipitate RCVS by increasing serotonergic vasoconstrictive activity on vascular smooth muscle (Ducros et al., Ann Neurol 2017). The International Headache Society’s ICHD-3 (2018) diagnostic criteria require: (1) acute severe headaches, (2) multifocal vasoconstriction on CTA/MRA/DSA, (3) no evidence of aneurysmal SAH, and (4) normalization of vessels within 12 weeks. Cerebrospinal fluid in RCVS is typically normal or near-normal, distinguishing it from PACNS, which shows pleocytosis and elevated protein (Calabrese et al., Neurology 2007). SAH is excluded by noncontrast CT (sensitivity ~95% within 6 hours) or lumbar puncture demonstrating xanthochromia (Rinkel & Algra, Lancet Neurol 2011). FMD produces persistent beading of medium arteries, most often renal, with chronic hypertension and no acute thunderclap headache (Olin et al., J Vasc Surg 2015). Nimodipine is commonly used off-label to reverse vasoconstriction, with observational studies demonstrating clinical improvement (Singhal et al., Stroke 2011).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Fibromuscular dysplasia at the level of carotid
• Incorrect because FMD is a noninflammatory arteriopathy affecting renal and carotid arteries, presenting with chronic hypertension and bruits rather than acute thunderclap headaches. Angiographic “string-of-beads” in FMD is persistent and not reversible within weeks.
• Misconception: equating beading on angiography with acute vasospasm.

B. Isolated angiitis of the central nervous system
• PACNS presents subacutely with persistent headaches, focal neurological deficits, and CSF pleocytosis, not normal CSF. Angiographic irregularities are fixed and progressive, requiring biopsy for confirmation.
• Misconception: attributing multifocal narrowing exclusively to vasculitis rather than reversible spasm.

D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
• SAH presents with thunderclap headache but is confirmed by CT or lumbar puncture (xanthochromia). Neuro exam often reveals meningeal signs, and angiography is performed only after hemorrhage confirmation.
• Misconception: assuming all thunderclap headaches are hemorrhagic rather than vasospastic.

- SSRIs, triptans, and the postpartum period are well-documented triggers of RCVS; ask about medication history in thunderclap headache.
• A normal CSF and angiographic resolution by 12 weeks effectively exclude PACNS.
• Nimodipine or verapamil can mitigate vasoconstriction, though evidence is limited to observational studies.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking all thunderclap headaches for SAH without considering RCVS in the differential.
• Interpreting any angiographic “beading” as vasculitis rather than reversible vasospasm.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018)
• Recommendation: Acute severe headaches with multifocal cerebral artery narrowing and documented reversibility within 12 weeks define RCVS.
• Level: Classification criteria (consensus).
2. Ducros A et al., Expert Consensus Statement on RCVS (Ann Neurol 2017)
• Recommendation: Use CTA/MRA/DSA for diagnosis; initiate calcium‐channel blockers; follow up imaging at 12 weeks.
• Level: Expert opinion (Grade C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

RCVS affects small- to medium-sized intracranial arteries, particularly distal branches of the circle of Willis, leading to transient vasospasm and watershed perfusion changes if severe.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Transient endothelial dysfunction and sympathetic overactivity cause segmental cerebral arterial vasoconstriction; removal of the trigger allows restoration of vessel caliber.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Exclude SAH with noncontrast head CT (within 6 hours) or LP for xanthochromia.
2. Obtain vascular imaging (CTA/MRA); if nondiagnostic, proceed to DSA.
3. Monitor clinically and perform follow-up vascular imaging at 12 weeks to confirm reversibility.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CTA/MRA sensitivity for RCVS is ~70–95%; digital subtraction angiography remains the gold standard.
• “String-of-beads” pattern resolves on repeat imaging.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Nimodipine 30 mg orally every 4 hours or verapamil 120–240 mg daily is used to alleviate vasoconstriction.
• Avoid vasoactive agents and monitor blood pressure to prevent ischemic complications.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] The cavernous sinus is a dural venous sinus receiving blood from the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins, sphenoparietal sinus, and cortical veins. Thrombosis here impedes venous drainage from the orbit and anterior cranial fossa, leading to chemosis, proptosis, ophthalmoplegia (cranial nerves III, IV, VI), and sensory loss in V₁/V₂ distributions. Rapid diagnosis is critical because septic cavernous sinus thrombosis carries high mortality without prompt antimicrobial and anticoagulant therapy. Neuroimaging distinguishes venous thrombus from other causes of orbital apex syndromes. MR venography exploits flow‐sensitive sequences to detect filling defects in venous channels, making MRI with MRV the gold standard for evaluating suspected cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MRI with MRV directly visualizes the venous lumen, identifies intraluminal thrombus (T1 hyperintensity, T2 hypointensity, absence of flow void), and shows associated soft‐tissue edema or abscess. A meta‐analysis (Saposnik et al., Stroke 2011) demonstrated MRV sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 91% for cerebral venous thrombosis, surpassing CT-based techniques. AHA/ASA guidelines (2011) recommend MRI/MRV as first‐line imaging in suspected venous sinus thrombosis (Level B evidence). When MRI is contraindicated or unavailable, CT venography (CTV) is acceptable (Class I, Level B, ESO 2021). Digital subtraction angiography was once gold standard but is invasive, offers poor direct venous visualization, and is reserved for endovascular intervention planning. CTA depicts arteries with some venous detail but lacks the spatial resolution to reliably detect cavernous sinus thrombus. CT orbit focuses on bony and soft‐tissue orbital detail, missing intracranial venous pathology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. CTA
• Incorrect because CTA optimizes arterial lumen visualization; venous phases are not routinely captured, limiting sensitivity for venous filling defects.
• Misconception: “CT angiography” is often conflated with CT venography.
• Differentiator: CTA timing and reconstruction omit slow‐flow venous structures; MRV uses phase‐contrast/time‐of‐flight to directly assess venous flow.

C. Angiography
• Incorrect due to its invasive nature and lack of direct visualization of the cavernous sinus lumen in the absence of selective venography.
• Misconception: Cerebral angiography is still the “gold standard” for all vascular imaging.
• Differentiator: Digital subtraction angiography outlines arterial phase and only indirectly infers venous thrombosis via delayed venous drainage.

D. CT orbit
• Incorrect because CT of the orbit focuses on orbital bones and soft tissues, not intracranial venous sinuses.
• Misconception: Orbital imaging can pick up cavernous sinus pathology.
• Differentiator: CT orbit lacks coverage of the sinus and does not include venographic sequences.

Clinical Pearls

- Cavernous sinus thrombosis often follows facial, sinus, or dental infections; obtain urgent MRI/MRV in any febrile patient with ophthalmoplegia and proptosis.
• Look for the “empty delta sign” on contrast CT: peripheral enhancement around a non-enhancing thrombus in the superior sagittal sinus—analogous findings may appear in cavernous sinus thrombosis.
• Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics plus anticoagulation once imaging confirms or strongly suggests septic CST, even before culture results.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering CTA instead of CT venography (CTV) due to unfamiliarity with venous‐phase protocols.
2. Believing that a normal noncontrast CT head or CT orbit excludes cavernous sinus thrombosis.
3. Overreliance on digital angiography leading to unnecessary invasive procedures.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2011 Guidelines:
• Recommendation: MRI combined with MRV is first‐line imaging for suspected cerebral venous thrombosis (Level of Evidence: B).
2. European Stroke Organization (ESO) 2021 Guidelines for Cerebral Venous Thrombosis:
• Recommendation: Class I – MRI/MRV preferred; if unavailable, CT with dedicated CT venography acceptable (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The cavernous sinus lies on either side of the sella turcica. It contains cranial nerves III, IV, V₁, V₂ in its lateral wall and VI with the internal carotid artery centrally. Thrombus here causes cranial nerve VI palsy early due to its unsupported position.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thrombus formation in the cavernous sinus impedes venous outflow from the orbit and cortical veins, raising venous pressure, causing transudation of fluid (chemosis) and cranial nerve ischemia. In septic CST, bacterial invasion propagates thrombosis and can lead to septic emboli.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: fever + orbital signs + cranial neuropathies.
2. Obtain MRI brain with contrast + MR venography.
3. If MRI contraindicated/unavailable → perform CT head with CT venography.
4. Reserve digital subtraction angiography for endovascular treatment planning.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- On MRV: look for absence of flow‐related enhancement in the cavernous sinus.
• On T1/T2: acute thrombus may show T1 hyperintensity (methemoglobin) and T2 hypointensity.
• Contrast‐enhanced MR: venous filling defects with peripheral enhancement.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] - Pathophysiology of septic embolic stroke: vegetations on cardiac valves dislodge, occluding cerebral arteries (often MCA territory).
• Penumbra concept: ischemic but salvageable tissue; reperfusion strategies (tPA, thrombectomy) apply in non-infectious strokes.
• Infective endocarditis (IE) management principles: prompt IV antibiotics to eradicate vegetation, prevent further emboli and mycotic aneurysms.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is Antibiotics. In suspected IE causing acute stroke, immediate empirical IV antibiotics (e.g., vancomycin + ceftriaxone) are paramount to sterilize vegetations and prevent ongoing embolization. The 2015 AHA guidelines for IE (Baddour et al., Circulation 2015) give a Class I recommendation (Level C) for early empirical therapy upon clinical suspicion.
Intravenous thrombolysis is contraindicated (AHA/ASA 2018 guidelines, Stroke 2018, Class III—harm) because infected arterial walls and mycotic aneurysms markedly increase hemorrhagic transformation risk. Mechanical thrombectomy data in IE are limited to small case series; while sometimes performed for documented large vessel occlusion (LVO), there is insufficient evidence to support routine endovascular intervention absent confirmatory angiography and neurosurgical backup. Supportive care alone fails to address the nidus of infection, risking recurrent emboli and systemic complications.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Thrombolysis
• Why incorrect: IE is an absolute contraindication to IV alteplase due to high hemorrhage risk from friable, bacteria-invaded vessels and mycotic aneurysms.
• Misconception: assuming all acute ischemic strokes <4.5 h window qualify for tPA.
• Differentiator: non-infectious stroke vs. septic embolus—only the former is tPA-eligible.

C. Thrombectomy
• Why incorrect here: no angiographic evidence provided of LVO; endovascular treatment in IE lacks robust RCT support and carries infection and hemorrhage risks.
• Misconception: thrombectomy is universally safer than thrombolysis in contraindicated settings.
• Differentiator: thrombectomy may be considered only after vessel imaging confirms LVO and multidisciplinary review.

D. Supportive care and monitoring
• Why incorrect: withholding antibiotics allows ongoing bacteremia, vegetations persist, and additional emboli may occur.
• Misconception: stabilization alone suffices temporarily.
• Differentiator: supportive care is adjunctive, not definitive, in IE management.

2. Mycotic aneurysms may rupture spontaneously or with thrombolysis—avoid tPA if IE is possible.
3. Early blood cultures and echo (prefer TEE) should be obtained immediately when IE is suspected in stroke.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering IV alteplase solely based on time window without assessing infective risk factors.
2. Deferring antibiotics until full diagnostic confirmation, delaying eradication of the embolic source.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2015 AHA Infective Endocarditis Guidelines (Baddour et al., Circulation 2015): Class I recommendation for immediate empirical IV antibiotics upon clinical suspicion of IE (Level C evidence).
• 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al., Stroke 2018): Infective endocarditis is an absolute contraindication to IV alteplase (Class III: Level B-R).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Septic emboli often lodge at the MCA bifurcation, producing large cortical infarcts with dense hemiparesis and aphasia if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Valvular vegetations harbor bacteria; fragments dislodge, occluding cerebral vessels. Bacterial invasion of vessel walls leads to vessel wall weakening, mycotic aneurysm formation, and high hemorrhagic transformation risk.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Acute stroke symptoms → noncontrast head CT (exclude hemorrhage).
2. Concurrent fever, IVDU, murmur → draw blood cultures, start empirical IV antibiotics.
3. Perform TTE/TEE to confirm IE.
4. Reserve mechanical thrombectomy for documented LVO on CTA/MRA, with multidisciplinary discussion.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Noncontrast CT may be normal initially in ischemia; CTA is needed to detect LVO.
• MRI diffusion-weighted imaging confirms infarct; susceptibility-weighted imaging may detect microhemorrhages.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Empirical regimen: vancomycin (15–20 mg/kg IV q8–12 h) plus ceftriaxone (2 g IV q12 h); tailored once cultures & sensitivities return. Duration typically 4–6 weeks.
