[Exam: Part II 2019] - Supervision Levels: ACGME defines direct, indirect, and oversight supervision. Direct supervision (faculty physically present) is required until competence is demonstrated.
• Competency-Based Progression: Medical trainees advance by safely performing procedures under supervision, building judgment and manual dexterity.
• Patient Safety & Non-Maleficence: Ethical principle of “do no harm” mandates that trainees avoid unsupervised high-stakes tasks beyond their proven abilities.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer, “Wait for the supervisor,” aligns with ACGME Common Program Requirements (2019) stating that any invasive or intermediate procedure must be directly supervised until the resident attains documented competence (Level 1 and 2 supervision). A 2015 JAMA study (Cohen et al.) demonstrated a 45% reduction in procedural complications when direct faculty oversight was present. Indirect consultation (calling) does not meet the requirement for direct physical oversight required for novice operators. While a more experienced colleague may assist, institutional bylaws often specify that only credentialed faculty may provide the formal supervision needed for initial procedures. Waiting ensures patient safety, respects institutional policy, and upholds professional standards.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Do it alone
• Incorrect because performing an invasive procedure without any supervision violates both ACGME requirements and ethical standards.
• Reflects the misconception that theoretical knowledge equals procedural competence.
• Lacks direct oversight, increasing risk of technical error and patient harm.

C. Call the supervisor for guidance
• Although phone consultation provides advice, it does not satisfy the requirement for direct physical supervision during a novice’s first procedures.
• Misinterprets “supervision” as verbal-only rather than in-person guidance.
• Leaves the intern without immediate backup if complications arise.

D. Ask a more experienced colleague for help
• While peer support can improve technique, most training institutions require faculty-level oversight for credentialing and medico-legal accountability.
• Mistakenly conflates informal mentoring with formal supervisory roles.
• The “more experienced colleague” may not have the authority or credential to sign off on competence.

- Confirm institutional supervision policies before scheduling any new procedure.
• Document procedural experience and supervisor sign-offs to track progression toward autonomy.

[Exam: Part II 2019] Euthanasia comes from the Greek for “good death” and refers to the intentional act of ending a patient’s life to relieve intractable suffering. Key distinctions:
• Active vs. passive: active involves a direct intervention (e.g., lethal injection), passive involves withholding or withdrawing treatment.
• Voluntary vs. non-voluntary vs. involuntary: voluntary requires the patient’s competent request.
• Physician-assisted suicide vs. euthanasia: in PAS the patient self-administers a prescribed lethal agent; in euthanasia the physician administers it.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A defines voluntary active euthanasia: a physician directly administers a lethal dose at the patient’s request. The World Medical Association, American Medical Association (AMA Code of Medical Ethics Opinion 9.23, 2016), and European countries (e.g., the Netherlands’ Termination of Life on Request and Assisted Suicide Act, 2002) distinguish active euthanasia from other end-of-life practices based on intent and agent. The AMA explicitly prohibits physician participation in euthanasia, whereas palliative care guidelines (e.g., EAPC Framework on Palliative Sedation, 2020) delineate relief of suffering as the primary intent, not hastening death.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Refusal of life-sustaining treatment is an exercise of patient autonomy and leads to passive allowance of natural death, not an active killing. Misconception: equating passive withdrawal with euthanasia.
C. Administration of analgesics or sedatives under the principle of double effect aims to relieve suffering; any life-shortening is unintended. Misconception: any hastening of death equals euthanasia.
D. Stopping artificial nutrition and hydration allows underlying disease to cause death; this is considered withdrawal of burdensome treatment under autonomy, not an intentional act to kill. Misconception: passive withholding is active killing.

Clinical Pearls

- The principle of double effect permits administration of pain relief even if it may shorten life, provided the primary intent is symptom control.
• Physician-assisted suicide differs from euthanasia: in PAS, the patient self-administers.
• In jurisdictions permitting euthanasia (e.g., Belgium, Netherlands), strict safeguards include multiple requests, psychiatric evaluation, and waiting periods.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Conflating passive withdrawal of treatment (B, D) with active euthanasia (A).
• Misunderstanding the principle of double effect (C) as euthanasia.
• Failing to distinguish euthanasia from physician-assisted suicide (physician administration vs. patient administration).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AMA Code of Medical Ethics Opinion 9.23 (2016): “Physician-assisted suicide and euthanasia are unethical”; consensus-based guidance.
2. EAPC Framework on Palliative Sedation (2020): Clarifies indications for sedation in refractory symptoms and distinguishes it from euthanasia; expert consensus (Level C).

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Malignant skin tumors differ in origin cell, growth pattern and routes of spread. Melanoma arises from melanocytes in the basal epidermis. Key concepts:
• Malignant transformation and vertical growth phase allow invasion into dermal capillary plexus, facilitating hematogenous dissemination.
• Breslow thickness and ulceration correlate with risk of distant metastasis; lesions >1 mm thickness have high propensity for blood‐borne spread.
• In contrast, basal cell carcinomas invade locally; squamous cell carcinomas favor lymphatic spread to regional nodes; Merkel cell carcinoma is neuroendocrine with early nodal but less frequent distant hematogenous metastasis. (Word count: 104)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Skin melanoma is the only common cutaneous malignancy with a high rate of hematogenous metastasis to lung, liver, brain and bone. Depth of invasion (Breslow thickness >1 mm) and presence of vascular invasion predict distant spread (Gershenwald et al., CA Cancer J Clin 2021). Immunohistochemical markers (S-100, HMB-45, MART-1) confirm diagnosis. NCCN Guidelines (2024) recommend sentinel lymph node biopsy for staging (Category 2A). PET/CT or CT imaging is indicated for stage IIIB or higher to detect visceral metastases (ESMO 2022, Level A). Early detection of metastatic melanoma is critical since adjuvant immunotherapies (nivolumab, pembrolizumab) have shown significant recurrence‐free survival benefit (CheckMate 238, NEJM 2017; KEYNOTE-054, Lancet Oncol 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Basal cell carcinoma
 • Incorrect because BCC almost never metastasizes (<0.1%); grows locally via basaloid keratinocytes.
 • Misconception: all skin cancers metastasize; key distinction is lack of vascular invasion in BCC.

B. Squamous cell carcinoma
 • SCC metastasizes primarily via lymphatics; distant hematogenous spread is rare (<5%).
 • Pitfall: equating local aggressiveness with systemic spread—SCC usually first involves regional lymph nodes.

C. Merkel cell carcinoma
 • Highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor with early nodal spread; distant metastasis occurs but lymphatic route predominates.
 • Confusion arises from its rapid growth, but hematogenous dissemination is less characteristic than in melanoma.

• Sentinel lymph node biopsy is standard for melanoma ≥0.8 mm or ulcerated lesions.
• Distant staging with PET/CT is indicated for stage III/IV to guide systemic therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming squamous cell carcinoma frequently metastasizes to lung—rare without nodal involvement.
2. Believing basal cell carcinoma can seed distant organs—virtually no hematogenous spread.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology: Cutaneous Melanoma, Version 2.2024 – recommend sentinel lymph node biopsy for primary melanomas >0.8 mm or ulcerated (Category 2A).
• ESMO Clinical Practice Guidelines, Cutaneous Melanoma (2022) – advise PET/CT or contrast‐enhanced CT for staging of stage III/IV to evaluate hematogenous metastases (Level A).
• CheckMate 238 Trial (NEJM 2017) – adjuvant nivolumab vs ipilimumab in resected stage III–IV melanoma improved recurrence‐free survival (HR 0.65; 95% CI 0.51–0.83) (Level 1B).
• KEYNOTE-054/EORTC 1325-MG (Lancet Oncol 2018) – adjuvant pembrolizumab significantly reduced recurrence risk in high‐risk stage III melanoma (HR 0.57; 95% CI 0.43–0.74) (Level 1A).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Malignant melanocytes acquire mutations (BRAF, NRAS) leading to loss of cell-cycle control. Vertical growth crosses basement membrane into dermis, encountering vasculature. Tumor cells intravasate, survive shear stress, extravasate at distant sites, and colonize target organs.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical inspection: ABCDE criteria (Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variegation, Diameter >6 mm, Evolving)
2. Excisional biopsy with narrow margins → histopathology (assess Breslow depth, ulceration)
3. Sentinel lymph node biopsy for staging if thickness ≥0.8 mm or high-risk features
4. Imaging (CT/PET-CT) for stage III–IV to detect hematogenous metastases

[Exam: Part I 2019] - Four core principles of biomedical ethics (Beauchamp & Childress, 2013):
• Beneficence: proactive duty to promote patient well-being
• Non-maleficence: duty to avoid causing harm
• Autonomy: respect for patient self-determination
• Justice: fair distribution of healthcare resources
• In neurology, beneficence underlies decisions such as initiating disease-modifying therapy in multiple sclerosis to improve long-term outcomes.
• Differentiating positive duties (beneficence) from negative duties (non-maleficence) guides both clinical care and research ethics.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Beneficence obligates physicians to act for the patient’s benefit by maximizing potential gains and minimizing risks. The AMA Code of Medical Ethics Opinion 1.1.1 (2016) states that “a physician’s primary responsibility is to the patient,” reinforcing beneficence as a central tenet of clinical decision-making. The Belmont Report (1979) further codified beneficence in research settings. In neurology, AAN stroke guidelines (2018) recommend timely thrombolysis to improve functional outcomes (Level A evidence), exemplifying beneficence in acute care. Unlike non-maleficence, which mandates only the avoidance of harm, beneficence requires active promotion of patient welfare.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Justice
• Incorrect: Concerns equitable distribution of resources across populations, not individualized best-interest decisions.
• Misconception: Equating fairness in allocation with patient-centered benefit.

C. Autonomy
• Incorrect: Protects the patient’s right to choose, even if choices differ from physician’s view of “best interest.”
• Misconception: Confusing patient self-determination with physician-led welfare actions.

D. Non-maleficence
• Incorrect: Requires avoidance of harm but does not demand positive actions to benefit the patient.
• Misconception: Assuming “do no harm” inherently means “do good.”

Clinical Pearls

- Always document how a chosen intervention benefits the patient when invoking beneficence.
• Early aggressive treatment in conditions like autoimmune encephalitis exemplifies beneficence balanced against risk.
• Avoid paternalism: even well-intended actions must be paired with informed consent to respect autonomy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Conflating non-maleficence (“do no harm”) with beneficence (“do good”).
• Overemphasizing autonomy at the expense of beneficence when patients defer decisions to the physician.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AMA Code of Medical Ethics Opinion 1.1.1 (2016): Physicians must prioritize patient welfare above personal or institutional interests (Expert consensus).
• American Academy of Neurology Position Statement on Physician Aid in Dying (2018): Highlights beneficence in end-of-life care discussions, ensuring interventions align with patient well-being (Expert consensus).
